verses.text: I, Nephi, was born to good parents, so I was taught in all the learning of my father. I have seen many hardships in my life, but I have also been greatly favored by the Lord throughout my days. I have gained a great knowledge of God's goodness and mysteries, so I am making a record of my experiences during my life.
I am writing this record in my father's language, which uses the learning of the Jews and the language of the Egyptians.
I know that the record I am making is true, and I am writing it with my own hand, according to my knowledge.

At the beginning of the first year of Zedekiah's reign as king of Judah—when my father Lehi had lived in Jerusalem all his life—many prophets came and told the people that they needed to repent or the great city of Jerusalem would be destroyed.
As my father Lehi went out, he prayed to the Lord with all his heart for his people.
As he prayed to the Lord, a pillar of fire appeared and rested on a rock in front of him. He saw and heard many things, and because of what he saw and heard, he shook and trembled greatly.
He returned to his house in Jerusalem and collapsed on his bed, overwhelmed by the Spirit and the things he had seen.

Overcome by the Spirit, he was carried away in a vision where he saw the heavens open. He thought he saw God sitting on his throne, surrounded by countless groups of angels singing and praising their God.
He saw One coming down from the middle of heaven, and noticed that His brightness was greater than the sun at noon.
He also saw twelve others following him, and they were brighter than the stars in the sky.
They came down and went out onto the earth. The first one came and stood in front of my father, gave him a book, and told him to read it.
As he read, he was filled with the Spirit of the Lord.

He read, saying: "Woe to Jerusalem, for I have seen your abominations! My father read many things about Jerusalem—that it would be destroyed along with its inhabitants; many would die by the sword, and many would be taken captive into Babylon."

When my father had read and seen many great and marvelous things, he exclaimed many things to the Lord, such as: Great and marvelous are your works, O Lord God Almighty! Your throne is high in the heavens, and your power, goodness, and mercy are over all the inhabitants of the earth. Because you are merciful, you will not allow those who come to you to perish.
This is how my father praised his God; his soul rejoiced, and his whole heart was filled because of the things he had seen, which the Lord had shown to him.

Now I, Nephi, am not giving a complete account of the things my father has written, because he has written many things he saw in visions and dreams; and he has also written many things he prophesied and spoke to his children, which I will not give a full account of.

I will write an account of what I have done in my life. I am making a summary of my father's record on plates that I made with my own hands. After I finish summarizing my father's record, I will write about my own life.

I want you to know that after the Lord showed so many marvelous things to my father, Lehi, about the destruction of Jerusalem, he went out among the people and began to prophesy and tell them about the things he had seen and heard.

The Jews mocked him because of the things he testified about them; for he truly testified of their wickedness and their abominations. He also testified that the things he saw and heard, as well as the things he read in the book, clearly showed the coming of the Messiah and the redemption of the world.

When the Jews heard these things, they were angry with him, just as they had been with the prophets of old, whom they had cast out, stoned, and killed. They also tried to take his life. I, Nephi, will show you that the tender mercies of the Lord are over all those he has chosen because of their faith, to make them strong enough to be delivered.

The Lord spoke to my father in a dream and said, "You are blessed, Lehi, because of what you have done; and because you have been faithful and declared to this people the things I commanded you, they are now seeking to take your life."
The Lord commanded my father in a dream to take his family and leave into the wilderness.
He was obedient to the word of the Lord and did as the Lord commanded him.

He left for the wilderness, leaving behind his house, his inherited land, his gold, his silver, and his valuable possessions. He took nothing with him except his family, some provisions, and tents, and went into the wilderness.

He went down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea and traveled in the wilderness along the areas closest to the Red Sea. He journeyed in the wilderness with his family, which included my mother Sariah and my older brothers, Laman, Lemuel, and Sam.
After he had traveled three days in the wilderness, he set up his tent in a valley beside a river.
He built an altar of stones, made an offering to the Lord, and gave thanks to the Lord our God.
He named the river Laman, and it flowed into the Red Sea. The valley was along the borders near the river's mouth.
When my father saw that the river flowed into the Red Sea, he spoke to Laman and said, "I wish you could be like this river, always running into the source of all righteousness."
He also said to Lemuel, "I wish you could be like this valley—firm, steadfast, and immovable in keeping the commandments of the Lord."

He said this because Laman and Lemuel were stubborn; they complained a lot against their father because he was a visionary man and had led them out of Jerusalem, leaving behind their inheritance, their gold, their silver, and their valuable possessions, to die in the wilderness. They said he did this because of the foolish ideas in his heart.
Laman and Lemuel, being the oldest, complained against their father because they didn't understand how God, who created them, works.
They didn't believe that Jerusalem, that great city, could be destroyed as the prophets had said. They were like the Jews in Jerusalem who tried to kill my father.

My father spoke to them in the valley of Lemuel with power, being filled with the Spirit, until they trembled before him. He confounded them so they didn't dare speak against him, so they did as he commanded.
My father lived in a tent.

I, Nephi, was very young but large in stature and had a strong desire to understand the mysteries of God. So I prayed to the Lord, and he visited me and softened my heart so that I believed all the words my father had spoken. Because of this, I did not rebel against him like my brothers did.
I spoke to Sam and told him about the things the Lord had shown me through His Holy Spirit. He believed what I said.
Laman and Lemuel would not listen to my words, and because I was upset by the hardness of their hearts, I prayed to the Lord for them.
The Lord spoke to me, saying, "You are blessed, Nephi, because of your faith, for you have sought me diligently with humility."
If you keep my commandments, you will prosper and be led to a land of promise—a land I have prepared for you, a land that is better than all other lands.
If your brothers rebel against you, they will be cut off from the presence of the Lord.
If you keep my commandments, you will become a leader and a teacher over your brothers.
On the day they rebel against me, I will curse them with a severe curse, and they will have no power over your descendants unless your descendants also rebel against me.
If they rebel against me, they will be a scourge to your descendants, to remind them and help them remember.
I, Nephi, returned from speaking with the Lord to my father's tent.
He said to me, "I have had a dream in which the Lord has commanded me that you and your brothers must return to Jerusalem."
Laban has the record of the Jews and also a genealogy of my forefathers, and they are engraved on brass plates.
The Lord has commanded me that you and your brothers should go to Laban's house, get the records, and bring them here into the wilderness.
Now your brothers are complaining, saying that what I've asked them to do is too hard; but I haven't asked it of them—this is a commandment from the Lord.
Go, my son, and you will be favored by the Lord because you have not complained.

I, Nephi, said to my father, "I will go and do the things the Lord has commanded, because I know that the Lord doesn't give commandments to the children of men without preparing a way for them to accomplish what he commands."
When my father heard these words, he was extremely glad, because he knew that I had been blessed by the Lord.
I, Nephi, and my brothers traveled through the wilderness with our tents to go up to the land of Jerusalem.
When we had gone up to the land of Jerusalem, my brothers and I discussed things together.
We cast lots to decide which of us should go into Laban's house. The lot fell to Laman, so Laman went into Laban's house and talked with him while he was sitting there.
He asked Laban for the records engraved on the brass plates, which contained my father's genealogy.
Laban became angry and threw him out of his presence, refusing to give him the records. He said to him, "You are a robber, and I will kill you."
But Laman ran away from him and told us what Laban had done. We became extremely sad, and my brothers were about to return to my father in the wilderness.
I told them, as surely as the Lord lives and as we live, we will not go back to our father in the wilderness until we have done what the Lord has commanded us.

Let's be faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord. Let's go down to the land of our father's inheritance, because he left gold, silver, and all kinds of riches there. He has done all this because of the commandments of the Lord.
He knew that Jerusalem had to be destroyed because of the wickedness of the people.
They have rejected the words of the prophets. So, if my father were to stay in the land after he has been commanded to leave, he would also die. Therefore, he must leave the land.
God, in His wisdom, wants us to obtain these records so that we can preserve our fathers' language for our children.
And also so we can preserve for them the words spoken by all the holy prophets, which have been given to them by the Spirit and power of God since the world began, right up to now.
After speaking to my brothers in this way, I persuaded them to be faithful in keeping God's commandments.
We went down to the land of our inheritance and gathered our gold, our silver, and our valuable possessions.
After we gathered these things together, we went again to Laban's house.
We went to Laban and asked him to give us the records engraved on the brass plates, offering him our gold, our silver, and all our valuable possessions in exchange.
When Laban saw our property and realized it was extremely valuable, he wanted it so much that he forced us out and sent his servants to kill us so he could take our property.
We ran away from the servants of Laban, and we had to leave our property behind, so it ended up in Laban's hands.
We ran into the wilderness, and the servants of Laban didn't catch us, and we hid in the hollow of a rock.
Laman was angry with me and with my father, and Lemuel was too, because he listened to Laman. Laman and Lemuel spoke many harsh words to us, their younger brothers, and they even hit us with a rod.

As they were hitting us with a rod, an angel of the Lord came and stood in front of them and said, "Why are you hitting your younger brother with a rod? Don't you know that the Lord has chosen him to be a ruler over you because of your sins? You will go up to Jerusalem again, and the Lord will deliver Laban into your hands."
After the angel finished speaking to us, he left.

After the angel left, Laman and Lemuel started complaining again, saying, "How is it possible that the Lord will deliver Laban into our hands? He is a powerful man and can command fifty men—he could even kill fifty; so why not us?"

I spoke to my brothers, saying, "Let's go up again to Jerusalem and be faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord. He is more powerful than anyone on earth, so why wouldn't he be more powerful than Laban and his fifty men, or even his tens of thousands?"

So let's go; let's be strong like Moses. He really spoke to the waters of the Red Sea and they divided, and our ancestors came through, out of captivity, on dry ground, while Pharaoh's armies followed and were drowned in the waters of the Red Sea.

You know this is true, and you also know that an angel has spoken to you. How can you doubt? Let's go; the Lord is able to deliver us just as He delivered our ancestors and to destroy Laban as He did the Egyptians.
After I said these things, they were still angry and kept complaining, but they followed me until we reached outside the walls of Jerusalem.
It was nighttime, and I had them hide outside the city walls. After they hid, I, Nephi, quietly entered the city and went toward Laban's house.
I was guided by the Spirit, not knowing ahead of time what I should do.
I went forward, and as I approached Laban's house, I saw a man who had collapsed on the ground in front of me because he was drunk with wine.
When I reached him, I saw that it was Laban.
I saw his sword and pulled it out of its sheath. The hilt was made of pure gold, and the craftsmanship was extremely fine. I noticed that the blade was made of the most precious steel.
I was compelled by the Spirit to kill Laban, but I said in my heart, "I have never shed anyone's blood." I hesitated and wished that I wouldn't have to kill him.

And the Spirit said to me again: The Lord has delivered him into your hands. I also knew that he had tried to take my life, and he would not listen to the commandments of the Lord, and he also took away our property.
The Spirit said to me again, "Kill him, for the Lord has delivered him into your hands."
The Lord destroys the wicked to accomplish his righteous purposes. It is better for one man to die than for a whole nation to dwindle and perish in unbelief.
When I, Nephi, heard these words, I remembered what the Lord had said to me in the wilderness: As long as your descendants keep my commandments, they will prosper in the promised land.
I also thought that they could not keep the commandments of the Lord according to the law of Moses unless they had the law.
I also knew that the law was engraved on the brass plates.
I also knew that the Lord had given Laban into my hands so that I could obtain the records as he had commanded.
So I obeyed the voice of the Spirit, took Laban by the hair of his head, and cut off his head with his own sword.
After I cut off his head with his own sword, I took Laban's clothes and put them on myself, every piece, and I put his armor around my waist.

After I had done this, I went to the treasury of Laban. As I was going toward the treasury, I saw Laban's servant who had the keys to the treasury. I told him, using Laban's voice, to come with me into the treasury.
He thought I was his master, Laban, because he saw the clothes I was wearing and the sword strapped around my waist.
He spoke to me about the elders of the Jews, knowing that his master, Laban, had been out by night among them.
And I spoke to him as if I were Laban.
I also told him that I would take the engravings on the brass plates to my older brothers, who were outside the walls.
I also told him to follow me.
He thought I was talking about the members of the church and that I was really Laban, whom I had killed, so he followed me.
He spoke to me many times about the elders of the Jews as I went to my brothers, who were outside the walls.
When Laman saw me, he was extremely frightened, as were Lemuel and Sam. They ran away from me because they thought I was Laban, and that he had killed me and was now trying to kill them too.
I called after them, and they heard me, so they stopped running away from me.
When Laban's servant saw my brothers, he started to tremble and was about to run away from me and go back to the city of Jerusalem.
I, Nephi, was a large man and had received great strength from the Lord, so I grabbed Laban's servant and held him so he couldn't run away.
I told him that if he would listen to my words—as surely as the Lord lives and as I live—if he would listen to us, we would spare his life.
I spoke to him and promised with an oath that he didn't need to be afraid; that he would be a free man like us if he would come with us into the wilderness.
I also said to him, "Surely the Lord has commanded us to do this; shouldn't we be diligent in keeping His commandments? So if you go into the wilderness to my father, you can stay with us."

Zoram was encouraged by the words I spoke. Zoram was the name of the servant, and he promised that he would go down into the wilderness to our father. He also swore an oath to us that he would stay with us from that time on.
We wanted him to stay with us so that the Jews wouldn't find out about our escape into the wilderness, because they might chase after us and destroy us.
When Zoram made an oath to us, our fears about him went away.
We took the brass plates and Laban's servant, left into the wilderness, and traveled to our father's tent.
After we came down into the wilderness to our father, he was filled with joy, and my mother Sariah was extremely glad, because she had truly mourned for us.

She thought we had died in the wilderness, and she also complained to my father, telling him that he was a visionary man, saying, "You have led us out from the land of our inheritance, and my sons are gone, and we are dying in the wilderness."
My mother complained against my father in this way.

My father spoke to her, saying, "I know that I am a visionary man. If I had not seen the things of God in a vision, I would not have known the goodness of God, but would have stayed in Jerusalem and died with my brothers."
But I have obtained a land of promise, and I rejoice in it; and I know that the Lord will deliver my sons from the hands of Laban and bring them back to us in the wilderness.
In this way, my father Lehi comforted my mother Sariah about us as we traveled in the wilderness to Jerusalem to get the record of the Jews.
When we returned to my father's tent, their joy was complete, and my mother was comforted.

She said, "Now I know for sure that the Lord has commanded my husband to flee into the wilderness, and I also know for sure that the Lord has protected my sons, delivered them from Laban, and given them the power to accomplish what He commanded them."
They rejoiced greatly and offered sacrifices and burnt offerings to the Lord, giving thanks to the God of Israel.
After they gave thanks to the God of Israel, my father Lehi took the records engraved on the brass plates and searched through them from the beginning.
He saw that they contained the five books of Moses, which give an account of the creation of the world, and also of Adam and Eve, who were our first parents.
And also a record of the Jews from the beginning, down to the start of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah.
It also contains the prophecies of the holy prophets from the beginning up to the start of Zedekiah's reign, as well as many prophecies spoken by Jeremiah.

My father, Lehi, also found on the brass plates a genealogy of his ancestors, so he knew that he was a descendant of Joseph—the same Joseph who was the son of Jacob, who was sold into Egypt and was preserved by the Lord so he could save his father, Jacob, and all his household from dying in the famine.
They were also led out of captivity and out of the land of Egypt by the same God who had preserved them.
So my father, Lehi, learned about his ancestors' genealogy. Laban was also a descendant of Joseph, so he and his family had kept the records.
When my father saw all these things, he was filled with the Spirit and began to prophesy about his descendants—
These brass plates would be shared with all nations, families, languages, and people who were his descendants.
He said that these brass plates would never be destroyed, and they would never fade with time. He also prophesied many things about his descendants.
So far, my father and I had kept the commandments the Lord had given us.

We had obtained the records the Lord had commanded us to get, and we searched them and found that they were desirable and very valuable to us, so that we could preserve the commandments of the Lord for our children.
So, it was wise of the Lord for us to take them with us as we traveled in the wilderness toward the promised land.

Now I, Nephi, am not including the genealogy of my fathers in this part of my record, and I will not include it later on these plates I am writing, because it is already given in the record kept by my father, so I am not writing it in this work.
It's enough for me to say that we are descendants of Joseph.

It doesn't matter to me that I'm not giving a full account of everything about my father, because those things can't be written on these plates. I want to save the space so I can write about the things of God.
My main purpose is to persuade people to come to the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, and be saved.
I do not write the things that please the world, but the things that please God and those who are not of the world.
I will command my descendants not to fill these plates with things that are not valuable to the children of men.

I want you to know that after my father Lehi finished prophesying about his descendants, the Lord spoke to him again, telling him that it was not right for Lehi to take his family into the wilderness alone; his sons should marry daughters so they could have children for the Lord in the promised land.
The Lord commanded that I, Nephi, and my brothers should return to Jerusalem and bring Ishmael and his family into the wilderness.
I, Nephi, once again went with my brothers into the wilderness to go up to Jerusalem.
We went to Ishmael's house, and he was pleased with us, so we spoke to him the words of the Lord.
The Lord softened the heart of Ishmael and his household, so they traveled with us into the wilderness to our father's tent.

As we traveled in the wilderness, Laman and Lemuel, two of Ishmael's daughters, the two sons of Ishmael and their families rebelled against us—against me, Nephi, Sam, their father Ishmael, his wife, and his three other daughters.
During this rebellion, they wanted to return to the land of Jerusalem.

Now I, Nephi, was upset because their hearts were so hard, so I spoke to them, even to Laman and Lemuel: You are my older brothers, so how is it that your hearts are so hard and your minds so blind that I, your younger brother, need to speak to you and set an example for you?
How is it that you have not listened to the word of the Lord?
How could you forget that you have seen an angel of the Lord?
And how have you forgotten the great things the Lord has done for us by delivering us from Laban and helping us obtain the record?
How have you forgotten that the Lord is able to do all things according to his will for the children of men, if they have faith in him? So let us be faithful to him.

If we are faithful to him, we will receive the promised land; and you will know in the future that the word of the Lord will be fulfilled about the destruction of Jerusalem, because everything the Lord has spoken about the destruction of Jerusalem must happen.

The Spirit of the Lord will soon stop striving with them, because they have rejected the prophets, and they have put Jeremiah in prison. They have also tried to take my father's life, so much that they have driven him out of the land.

I tell you, if you return to Jerusalem, you will die with them. If you choose, go back to the city, but remember what I am telling you—that if you do, you will die; because the Spirit of the Lord is compelling me to say this.

When I, Nephi, had spoken these words to my brothers, they became angry with me. They grabbed me because they were extremely angry, and they tied me up with cords, wanting to kill me by leaving me in the wilderness to be eaten by wild animals.
I prayed to the Lord, saying, "O Lord, according to my faith in you, will you deliver me from the hands of my brothers? Please give me strength so I can break these bands that I am bound with."
When I said these words, the bands came loose from my hands and feet, and I stood in front of my brothers and spoke to them again.

They were angry with me again and tried to grab me, but one of Ishmael's daughters, along with her mother and one of Ishmael's sons, pleaded with my brothers so much that their hearts softened, and they stopped trying to take my life.
They were sorrowful because of their wickedness, so much that they bowed down before me and pleaded with me to forgive them for what they had done against me.

I completely forgave them for everything they had done, and I encouraged them to pray to the Lord their God for forgiveness. They did so, and after they finished praying to the Lord, we continued our journey toward our father's tent.

We went down to our father's tent. After my brothers, I, and all of Ishmael's family arrived at my father's tent, they gave thanks to the Lord their God and offered sacrifice and burnt offerings to Him.
We gathered all kinds of seeds, including every type of grain and every kind of fruit seed.
While my father stayed in the wilderness, he spoke to us, saying, "I have had a dream; in other words, I have seen a vision."
Because of what I have seen, I have reason to rejoice in the Lord because of Nephi and also Sam; for I have reason to believe that they, and many of their descendants, will be saved.
Laman and Lemuel, I am very worried because of you; I thought I saw a dark and dreary wilderness in my dream.
I saw a man dressed in a white robe, and he came and stood in front of me.
He spoke to me and told me to follow him.
As I followed him, I saw that I was in a dark and dreary wilderness.
After I had traveled for many hours in darkness, I began to pray to the Lord, asking him to have mercy on me according to his great compassion.
After I prayed to the Lord, I saw a large and spacious field.
I saw a tree with fruit that was desirable because it could make someone happy.
I went forward and ate the fruit, and I saw that it was the sweetest I had ever tasted. I also saw that the fruit was whiter than anything I had ever seen.
As I ate the fruit, it filled my soul with incredibly great joy. I wanted my family to eat it too, because I knew it was more desirable than any other fruit.
As I looked around, hoping to see my family, I saw a river of water running nearby, close to the tree where I was eating the fruit.

I looked to see where it came from, and I saw the beginning of it a little way off. At the beginning, I saw your mother Sariah, Sam, and Nephi, and they stood there as if they didn't know where they should go.
I called out to them and told them in a loud voice to come to me and eat the fruit, which was more desirable than any other fruit.
They came to me and also ate the fruit.
I wanted Laman and Lemuel to come and eat the fruit too, so I looked toward the head of the river, hoping I might see them.
I saw them, but they would not come to me and eat the fruit.
I saw a rod of iron that ran along the bank of the river and led to the tree where I was standing.

I also saw a straight and narrow path that ran alongside the rod of iron, leading to the tree where I was standing. The path also passed by the head of the fountain and went to a large and spacious field, as if it were a world.
I saw countless groups of people, many of whom were moving forward, trying to reach the path that led to the tree where I was standing.
They came forward and started on the path that led to the tree.
A thick mist of darkness arose, so great that those who had started on the path lost their way, wandered off, and became lost.

I saw others moving forward, and they came and grabbed the end of the iron rod. They continued through the mist of darkness, holding tightly to the iron rod, until they reached the tree and ate its fruit.
After they had eaten the fruit from the tree, they looked around as if they were ashamed.
I looked around and saw, on the other side of the river, a large and spacious building; it appeared to be suspended in the air, high above the ground.
It was filled with people, both old and young, male and female; they were dressed very finely and were mocking and pointing their fingers at those who had come and were eating the fruit.
After they tasted the fruit, they felt ashamed because others were mocking them, so they left and wandered off into forbidden paths and were lost.
Now I, Nephi, am not repeating all the words of my father.

To be brief, he saw other crowds moving forward; they came and grabbed the end of the rod of iron, and they kept moving forward, always holding tightly to the rod of iron, until they reached the tree, fell down, and ate the fruit.
He also saw other crowds making their way toward that great and spacious building.
Many drowned in the depths of the fountain, and many were lost from his view, wandering on unfamiliar paths.
A large crowd went into that strange building. After they entered, they pointed at me and those who were eating the fruit, mocking us; but we ignored them.
My father said that everyone who listened to them had turned away.
And my father said that Laman and Lemuel did not eat the fruit.

After my father finished telling us all the words of his dream or vision, which were many, he told us that because of what he saw, he was extremely worried about Laman and Lemuel; he was afraid they might be cast out from the presence of the Lord.
He urged them with all the love of a caring parent to listen to his words, hoping that the Lord would be merciful to them and not reject them. My father preached to them.
After he preached to them and prophesied to them about many things, he told them to keep the commandments of the Lord, and then he stopped speaking to them.
My father saw, heard, and spoke all these things while he lived in a tent in the valley of Lemuel, and many other things as well, which cannot be written on these plates.

Now, as I have spoken about these plates, they are not the ones on which I make a complete record of my people's history. The plates on which I make a full account I have named Nephi, so they are called the plates of Nephi, after my own name. These plates are also called the plates of Nephi.
However, I have received a commandment from the Lord to make these plates for the specific purpose of recording an account of the ministry of my people.

On the other plates, I was to engrave an account of the reign of the kings, and the wars and conflicts of my people. These plates are mostly for the record of the ministry, while the other plates are mainly for the reign of the kings and the wars and conflicts of my people.
The Lord has commanded me to make these plates for a wise purpose known to Him, a purpose I do not know.

But the Lord knows all things from the beginning; so he prepares a way to accomplish all his works among the children of men, for he has all power to fulfill all his words. And that's how it is. Amen.
Now I, Nephi, am going to write on these plates about my experiences, my leadership, and my ministry. To continue my account, I need to talk a little about my father and my brothers.
After my father finished telling them about his dream and encouraging them to be diligent, he spoke to them about the Jews—

After they are destroyed—even that great city Jerusalem—and many are taken captive to Babylon, according to the Lord's timing, they will return and be brought back out of captivity. After they are brought back, they will once again possess the land of their inheritance.
Six hundred years after my father left Jerusalem, the Lord God will raise up a prophet among the Jews—a Messiah, or in other words, a Savior of the world.
He also spoke about the prophets, how many had testified of these things concerning this Messiah, whom he had mentioned, or this Redeemer of the world.
All mankind was in a lost and fallen state, and would always remain so unless they relied on this Redeemer.
He also spoke about a prophet who would come before the Messiah to prepare the way of the Lord—

He would go out and call in the wilderness, saying, "Prepare the way of the Lord and make his paths straight, for there is someone among you whom you do not know; he is mightier than I am, and I am not worthy to untie his shoe." My father spoke a lot about this.
My father said he would baptize in Bethabara, beyond the Jordan, and that he would baptize with water—even that he would baptize the Messiah with water.
After he baptized the Messiah with water, he would see and testify that he had baptized the Lamb of God, who would take away the sins of the world.

After my father finished speaking, he talked to my brothers about the gospel that would be preached among the Jews, and about how the Jews would fall into unbelief. After they killed the Messiah, who would come, and after he was killed, he would rise from the dead and reveal himself, through the Holy Ghost, to the Gentiles.
My father also spoke a lot about the Gentiles and the house of Israel, saying they should be compared to an olive tree whose branches would be broken off and scattered over the entire earth.
He said that we must be led together into the promised land to fulfill the word of the Lord, that we would be scattered across the entire earth.

After the house of Israel is scattered, they will be gathered together again. After the Gentiles have received the fullness of the Gospel, the natural branches of the olive tree, or the remnants of the house of Israel, will be grafted in, or come to know the true Messiah, their Lord and Redeemer.

In this way, my father prophesied and spoke to my brothers, and also said many other things that I have not written in this book, because I have written as many of them as were necessary in my other book.
All these things I've talked about happened while my father lived in a tent in the valley of Lemuel.

After I, Nephi, heard all the words of my father about the things he saw in a vision, and also the things he spoke by the power of the Holy Ghost—which power he received by faith in the Son of God, who is the Messiah who would come—I, Nephi, also wanted to see, hear, and know these things by the power of the Holy Ghost, which is the gift of God to all who diligently seek him, both in times past and when he would reveal himself to the children of men.
He is the same yesterday, today, and forever; and the way has been prepared for everyone since the foundation of the world, if they repent and come to him.

Anyone who diligently seeks will find; and the mysteries of God will be revealed to them by the power of the Holy Ghost, just as much now as in ancient times, and just as much in ancient times as in times to come. The ways of the Lord are one eternal round.
So remember, everyone will be judged for everything they do.
If you have tried to do evil during your time of testing, then you will be found unclean before the judgment seat of God, and nothing unclean can live with God; so you must be cast out forever.
And the Holy Ghost gives me authority to say these things, and I do not deny them.

After I wanted to know what my father had seen, and believed that the Lord could show them to me, as I sat thinking deeply, I was taken by the Spirit of the Lord to a very high mountain that I had never seen or been on before.
The Spirit said to me, "What do you desire?"
I said, "I want to see the things my father saw."
And the Spirit said to me, "Do you believe that your father saw the tree he talked about?"
And I said, you know that I believe all the words of my father.

After I spoke these words, the Spirit called out loudly, saying: Hosanna to the Lord, the Most High God, for he is God over all the earth, even above everything. And you are blessed, Nephi, because you believe in the Son of the Most High God; so you will see the things you have desired.

This will be given to you as a sign: after you have seen the tree that produced the fruit your father tasted, you will also see a man coming down from heaven, and you will witness him. After you have seen him, you will testify that he is the Son of God.

The Spirit said to me, "Look!" I looked and saw a tree that was like the one my father had seen. Its beauty was far greater than anything I had ever seen, and its whiteness was brighter than freshly fallen snow.
After I saw the tree, I said to the Spirit, "You have shown me the tree that is more precious than anything else."
And he said to me, "What do you want?"

I said to him, "To know what it means, " because I spoke to him as one person speaks to another. I saw that he was in the form of a man, but I knew he was the Spirit of the Lord, and he spoke to me as one person speaks with another.
He said to me, "Look!" I looked as if to look at him, but I didn't see him, because he had left my presence.
I looked and saw the great city of Jerusalem, as well as other cities. I saw the city of Nazareth; and in Nazareth, I saw a virgin who was extremely fair and pure.
I saw the heavens open, and an angel came down and stood in front of me. He said to me, "Nephi, what do you see?"
I said to him, "A virgin, the most beautiful and fair above all other virgins."
He said to me, "Do you know the condescension of God?"
I said to him, "I know that he loves his children, but I do not know the meaning of all things."
He said to me, "The virgin you see is the mother of the Son of God, in the way of the flesh."
I saw that she was carried away by the Spirit; and after she had been carried away for a while, the angel spoke to me and said, "Look!"
I looked and saw the virgin again, holding a child in her arms.
The angel said to me, "The Lamb of God, the Son of the Eternal Father! Do you know the meaning of the tree your father saw?"
I answered him, saying: It is the love of God, which spreads throughout the hearts of the children of men; it is the most desirable of all things.
He said to me, "Yes, and it is the most joyous to the soul."
After he said these words, he told me, "Look!" I looked and saw the Son of God going among the children of men, and I saw many people fall down at his feet and worship him.

I saw that the rod of iron, which my father had seen, was the word of God, which led to the fountain of living waters, or to the tree of life. These waters represent the love of God, and I also saw that the tree of life represents the love of God.
The angel said to me again, "Look and see the condescension of God!"

I saw the Redeemer of the world, the one my father had talked about. I also saw the prophet who would prepare the way before him. The Lamb of God went and was baptized by him, and after he was baptized, I saw the heavens open and the Holy Ghost come down from heaven and remain on him in the form of a dove.
I saw that he went out to serve the people with power and great glory. Large crowds gathered to hear him, but I saw that they cast him out from among them.
I also saw twelve others following him. Then they were taken away in the Spirit from in front of me, and I didn't see them anymore.
The angel spoke to me again and said, "Look!" I looked and saw the heavens open again, and I saw angels coming down to the children of men and ministering to them.

He spoke to me again, saying, "Look!" I looked and saw the Lamb of God going among the children of men. I saw many people who were sick and suffering from all kinds of diseases, and who were troubled by devils and unclean spirits. The angel showed me all these things. They were healed by the power of the Lamb of God, and the devils and unclean spirits were cast out.
The angel spoke to me again and said, "Look!" I looked and saw the Lamb of God being taken by the people. The Son of the everlasting God was judged by the world, and I saw it and testify of it.
And I, Nephi, saw that he was lifted up on the cross and killed for the sins of the world.
After he was killed, I saw crowds of people from all over the earth gathering to fight against the apostles of the Lamb, for that is what the angel of the Lord called the twelve.

The people of the earth were gathered together, and I saw that they were in a large and spacious building, like the one my father saw. The angel of the Lord spoke to me again and said, "Look at the world and its wisdom. The house of Israel has gathered together to fight against the twelve apostles of the Lamb."

I saw and testify that the great and spacious building represented the pride of the world; it fell, and its fall was extremely great. The angel of the Lord spoke to me again, saying, "This is how all nations, families, languages, and people who fight against the twelve apostles of the Lamb will be destroyed."

The angel said to me, "Look at your descendants and also the descendants of your brothers." I looked and saw the promised land, and I saw large groups of people, as numerous as the sand on the seashore.
I saw large groups of people gathered to fight against each other; I saw wars, rumors of wars, and great killings with the sword among my people.
I saw many generations pass away, marked by wars and conflicts in the land; and I saw many cities—so many that I could not count them.

I saw a mist of darkness over the land of promise. I saw lightning, heard thunder, earthquakes, and all kinds of loud noises. I saw the earth and rocks split apart, mountains breaking into pieces, plains breaking up, many cities sinking, many burned with fire, and many collapsing to the ground because of the earthquakes.
After I saw these things, I saw the vapor of darkness pass from the face of the earth; and I saw multitudes who had not fallen because of the great and terrible judgments of the Lord.
I saw the heavens open, and the Lamb of God came down from heaven and showed himself to them.
I also saw and testify that the Holy Ghost came upon twelve others; they were ordained and chosen by God.
The angel spoke to me, saying: These are the twelve disciples of the Lamb, who are chosen to minister to your descendants.

He said to me, "Do you remember the twelve apostles of the Lamb? They are the ones who will judge the twelve tribes of Israel. So, the twelve ministers from your descendants will be judged by them, because you are part of the house of Israel."
These twelve ministers you see will judge your descendants. They are righteous forever; because of their faith in the Lamb of God, their garments are made white in his blood.

The angel said to me, "Look." I looked and saw three generations pass away in righteousness, and their garments were as white as the Lamb of God. The angel said to me, "These have been made white in the blood of the Lamb because of their faith in him."
I, Nephi, also saw that many people of the fourth generation died faithfully.
I saw the multitudes of the earth gathered together.
The angel said to me, "Look at your descendants and also the descendants of your brothers."
I saw the people who came from me gathered in large groups against the descendants of my brothers, and they were assembled for battle.
The angel spoke to me, saying: The fountain of filthy water your father saw, and the river he talked about, represent the depths of hell.
The mists of darkness are the temptations of the devil, which blind the eyes and harden the hearts of the children of men, and lead them away into broad roads, so that they perish and are lost.

The large and spacious building your father saw represents vain imaginations and the pride of humanity. A great and terrible gulf separates them—the word of the justice of the Eternal God, and the Messiah who is the Lamb of God, whom the Holy Ghost has testified of from the beginning of the world until now, and from now on and forever.

As the angel spoke these words, I saw that the descendants of my brothers fought against my descendants, just as the angel said. Because of the pride of my people and the temptations of the devil, I saw that my brothers' descendants overpowered my people.
I saw that the descendants of my brothers had defeated my descendants, and they spread out in large numbers across the land.
I saw them gathered in large groups, and I saw wars and rumors of wars among them. Through these wars and rumors of wars, I watched many generations pass away.
The angel said to me, "These people will fall into unbelief."
After they had dwindled in unbelief, they became a dark, loathsome, and filthy people, full of idleness and all kinds of abominations.
The angel spoke to me and said, "Look!" I looked and saw many nations and kingdoms.
The angel said to me, "What do you see?" I answered, "I see many nations and kingdoms."
He said to me, "These are the nations and kingdoms of the Gentiles."
I saw among the nations of the Gentiles the formation of a great church.

The angel said to me: This is the formation of a church that is more abominable than all other churches. It kills the saints of God, tortures them, binds them, puts a yoke of iron on them, and brings them into captivity.
I saw this great and abominable church, and I saw that the devil was its founder.
I also saw gold, silver, silks, scarlet cloth, fine-twined linen, and all kinds of precious clothing; and I saw many prostitutes.
The angel said to me, "The gold, the silver, the silks, the scarlets, the fine-twined linen, the precious clothing, and the prostitutes are the desires of this great and abominable church."
They also destroy God's saints and bring them into captivity for the praise of the world.
I looked and saw many waters that separated the Gentiles from the descendants of my brothers.
The angel said to me, "The wrath of God is upon the descendants of your brothers."

I saw a man among the Gentiles who was separated from my brothers' descendants by a vast ocean. I saw the Spirit of God come down and influence this man, and he traveled across the ocean to the descendants of my brothers, who were in the promised land.
I saw the Spirit of God influence other Gentiles, and they left captivity and crossed the many waters.
I saw many groups of Gentiles on the promised land, and I saw that the wrath of God was upon the descendants of my brothers; they were scattered before the Gentiles and were struck down.

I saw that the Spirit of the Lord was upon the Gentiles, and they prospered and obtained the land as their inheritance. I saw that they were white, extremely fair, and beautiful, like my people were before they were killed.
I, Nephi, saw that the Gentiles who had come out of captivity humbled themselves before the Lord, and the power of the Lord was with them.
I saw that their mother Gentiles gathered together on the waters and on the land to fight against them.
I saw that God's power was with them, and that God's anger was upon everyone who gathered together to fight against them.
And I, Nephi, saw that the Gentiles who had escaped captivity were freed by the power of God from the control of all other nations.
I, Nephi, saw that they prospered in the land; and I saw a book, and it was carried among them.
The angel said to me, "Do you know the meaning of the book?"
And I said to him, "I don't know."

He said, "It comes from the mouth of a Jew." I, Nephi, saw it, and he said to me, "The book you see is a record of the Jews. It contains the covenants the Lord has made with the house of Israel, and it also includes many prophecies from the holy prophets. It is a record similar to the engravings on the plates of brass, except there aren't as many. Still, they contain the covenants the Lord has made with the house of Israel, so they are very valuable to the Gentiles."

The angel of the Lord said to me, "You have seen that the book came from the mouth of a Jew, and when it came from the mouth of a Jew, it contained the fullness of the gospel of the Lord, about whom the twelve apostles testify; and they testify according to the truth that is in the Lamb of God."
These things go from the Jews in purity to the Gentiles, according to the truth that is in God.

After the twelve apostles of the Lamb take the gospel from the Jews to the Gentiles, you see the rise of a great and abominable church, more abominable than any other church, because they have removed many plain and most precious parts from the gospel of the Lamb, as well as many covenants of the Lord.
They have done all this to distort the right ways of the Lord, so they can blind the eyes and harden the hearts of the children of men.
You see that after the book has passed through the hands of the great and abominable church, many plain and precious things are taken away from the book, which is the book of the Lamb of God.

After these plain and precious things were taken away, it goes out to all the nations of the Gentiles; and after it goes out to all the nations of the Gentiles, even across the many waters you have seen with the Gentiles who have gone out of captivity, you see—because so many plain and precious things have been taken out of the book, which were clear to the understanding of people, according to the plainness in the Lamb of God—because these things are taken away from the gospel of the Lamb, a very great many people stumble, so much that Satan has great power over them.

You see that the Gentiles who have come out of captivity have been lifted up by the power of God above all other nations on the land that is more choice than any other, which is the land the Lord God promised your father would be the inheritance of his descendants. You see that the Lord God will not allow the Gentiles to completely destroy the mixture of your descendants who are among your brothers.
He will not allow the Gentiles to destroy the descendants of your brothers.

The Lord God will not allow the Gentiles to remain forever in that terrible state of blindness you see them in, caused by the plain and most precious parts of the gospel of the Lamb that have been kept back by that abominable church you have seen formed.
The Lamb of God says: I will show mercy to the Gentiles, and I will visit the remnant of the house of Israel with great judgment.

The angel of the Lord spoke to me, saying: The Lamb of God says, after I have visited the remnant of the house of Israel—and this remnant I speak of is your father's descendants—after I have visited them in judgment and struck them by the hand of the Gentiles, and after the Gentiles stumble greatly because the most plain and precious parts of the gospel of the Lamb have been kept back by that abominable church, the mother of harlots, the Lamb says—I will be merciful to the Gentiles in that day, so much that I will bring forth to them, by my own power, much of my gospel, which will be plain and precious, says the Lamb.

The Lamb says: I will show myself to your descendants, and they will write many things that I will teach them, which will be clear and valuable. After your descendants are destroyed and fall into unbelief, and also the descendants of your brothers, these things will be hidden, to come forth to the Gentiles by the gift and power of the Lamb.
And my gospel will be written in them, says the Lamb, as well as my rock and my salvation.

Blessed are those who try to build my Zion in that day, for they will have the gift and power of the Holy Ghost. If they endure to the end, they will be lifted up at the last day and will be saved in the everlasting kingdom of the Lamb. Whoever spreads peace and brings news of great joy will be beautiful upon the mountains.

I saw the remnant of my brothers' descendants, and also the book of the Lamb of God, which had come from the mouth of the Jew, and it was delivered by the Gentiles to the remnant of my brothers' descendants.

After it had come to them, I saw other books, which came by the power of the Lamb from the Gentiles to them, to convince the Gentiles, the remnant of my brothers' descendants, and also the Jews who were scattered across the earth, that the records of the prophets and the twelve apostles of the Lamb are true.

The angel said to me, "These last records you have seen among the Gentiles will confirm the truth of the first records, which are from the twelve apostles of the Lamb. They will reveal the plain and precious things that have been taken away from them, and will make known to all nations, languages, and people that the Lamb of God is the Son of the Eternal Father and the Savior of the world. Everyone must come to Him, or they cannot be saved."

They will come according to the words established by the mouth of the Lamb, and the words of the Lamb will be made known in the records of your descendants, as well as in the records of the twelve apostles of the Lamb. Both will be united, for there is one God and one Shepherd over all the earth.

The time will come when he will show himself to all nations, both to the Jews and to the Gentiles. After he has shown himself to the Jews and also to the Gentiles, then he will show himself to the Gentiles and also to the Jews, and the last will be first, and the first will be last.
If the Gentiles listen to the Lamb of God in that day, he will show himself to them through his word, his power, and his actions, removing the things that cause them to stumble—

If they do not harden their hearts against the Lamb of God, they will be counted among your father's descendants; they will be counted as part of the house of Israel, and they will be a blessed people on the promised land forever. They will no longer be brought into captivity, and the house of Israel will no longer be confused or scattered.

And that great pit, which has been dug for them by that great and abominable church, which was founded by the devil and his children to lead the souls of men down to hell—that great pit which has been dug for the destruction of men will be filled by those who dug it, leading to their complete destruction, says the Lamb of God; not the destruction of the soul, except for being cast into that endless hell.
This is according to the captivity of the devil, and also according to the justice of God, upon all those who choose to do wickedness and abomination before him.

The angel spoke to me, Nephi, saying: You have seen that if the Gentiles repent, it will be well for them; and you also know about the covenants the Lord made with the house of Israel; and you have also heard that whoever does not repent will perish.
So, sorrow will come to the Gentiles if they harden their hearts against the Lamb of God.

The Lamb of God says that the time is coming when I will do a great and marvelous work among the children of men—a work that will last forever, either to convince them to have peace and eternal life, or to let them be given over to the hardness of their hearts and the blindness of their minds, leading them into captivity and destruction, both physically and spiritually, according to the captivity of the devil that I have spoken about.
After the angel finished speaking, he asked me, "Do you remember the covenants the Father made with the house of Israel?" I answered him, "Yes."
He said to me, "Look at that great and abominable church, the mother of abominations, whose founder is the devil."

He said to me: There are only two churches; one is the church of the Lamb of God, and the other is the church of the devil. Whoever does not belong to the church of the Lamb of God belongs to that great church, which is the mother of abominations, and she is the whore of all the earth.
I looked and saw the whore of all the earth, and she sat on many waters; she had power over the whole earth, among all nations, families, languages, and people.

I saw the church of the Lamb of God, and its numbers were few because of the wickedness and abominations of the whore who sat on many waters. Still, I saw that the church of the Lamb, who were the saints of God, were also spread across the whole earth, but their influence was small because of the wickedness of the great whore I saw.
I saw that the great mother of abominations gathered crowds from all over the earth, from every nation of the Gentiles, to fight against the Lamb of God.

I, Nephi, saw the power of the Lamb of God come down upon the saints of the church of the Lamb and upon the covenant people of the Lord, who were scattered across the whole earth; and they were armed with righteousness and with the power of God in great glory.
I saw that the wrath of God was poured out on that great and abominable church, so much that there were wars and rumors of wars among all the nations and families of the earth.

As wars and rumors of wars started among all the nations that belonged to the mother of abominations, the angel spoke to me, saying: The wrath of God is upon the mother of harlots; and you see all these things—

When the day comes that God's wrath is poured out on the mother of harlots, which is the great and abominable church of all the earth, whose founder is the devil, then, on that day, the Father's work will begin to prepare the way to fulfill the covenants he has made to his people who are of the house of Israel.
The angel spoke to me and said, "Look!"
I looked and saw a man who was dressed in a white robe.
The angel said to me, "One of the twelve apostles of the Lamb."
He will see and write the rest of these things, as well as many things that have happened in the past.
He will also write about the end of the world.

The things he will write are just and true; they are written in the book you saw coming from the mouth of the Jew. When they first came from the mouth of the Jew, or when the book first came from the mouth of the Jew, the things written were plain, pure, most precious, and easy for everyone to understand.
The things that this apostle of the Lamb will write are many of the things you have seen, and you will see the rest.
But you must not write the things you will see next, because the Lord God has appointed the apostle of the Lamb of God to write them.

And he has also shown all things to others who have lived, and they have written them; these writings are sealed to come forth in their purity, according to the truth that is in the Lamb, at the Lord's own appointed time, to the house of Israel.
I, Nephi, heard and testify that the name of the apostle of the Lamb was John, just as the angel said.
I, Nephi, am forbidden to write the rest of the things I saw and heard; so what I have written is enough for me, and I have only written a small part of what I saw.
I testify that I saw the things my father saw, and the angel of the Lord made them known to me.
I will now finish talking about the things I saw while I was carried away in the spirit. Even if not everything I saw is written here, what I have written is true. That's how it is. Amen.
After I, Nephi, had been carried away in the Spirit and seen all these things, I returned to my father's tent.
I saw my brothers, and they were arguing with each other about the things my father had told them.
He really spoke many great things to them that were hard to understand unless someone asked the Lord; and because their hearts were hard, they didn't turn to the Lord as they should have.
I, Nephi, was saddened because of how hard their hearts were, and also because of the things I had seen and knew must happen because of the great wickedness of the children of men.
I was overwhelmed by my suffering, because I felt my afflictions were greater than any others, since my people had been destroyed and I had seen their downfall.
After I regained my strength, I spoke to my brothers, wanting to know why they were arguing.
They said, "We can't understand the words our father has spoken about the natural branches of the olive tree, or about the Gentiles."
And I said to them, "Have you asked the Lord?"
They answered me, "We haven't, because the Lord hasn't made anything like that known to us."
I said to them, "How is it that you do not keep the commandments of the Lord? How is it that you will perish because of the hardness of your hearts?"

Don't you remember what the Lord has said? If you don't harden your hearts and ask me in faith, believing that you will receive, and are diligent in keeping my commandments, these things will be made known to you.

I tell you, the house of Israel was compared to an olive tree by the Spirit of the Lord that was in our father. Aren't we broken off from the house of Israel, and aren't we a branch of the house of Israel?

What our father means about grafting in the natural branches through the fullness of the Gentiles is that in the last days, after our descendants have fallen into unbelief for many years and generations following the Messiah being revealed in the flesh to humanity, then the fullness of the Messiah's gospel will come to the Gentiles, and from the Gentiles to the remnant of our descendants—

At that time, the remnant of our descendants will know that they are part of the house of Israel and that they are the Lord's covenant people. Then they will come to understand their ancestors and also learn about the gospel of their Redeemer, which he taught to their fathers. They will come to know their Redeemer and the key points of his teachings, so they will know how to come to him and be saved.

And on that day, won't they rejoice and praise their everlasting God, their rock and their salvation? On that day, won't they receive strength and nourishment from the true vine? Won't they come to the true fold of God?
I tell you, yes, they will be remembered again among the house of Israel; they will be grafted in, being a natural branch of the olive tree, into the true olive tree.

This is what our father means: it won't happen until after they are scattered by the Gentiles. He means it will come through the Gentiles so the Lord can show his power to them, because he will be rejected by the Jews, or the house of Israel.

Our father has not spoken only about our descendants, but also about all the house of Israel, referring to the covenant that will be fulfilled in the last days—the covenant the Lord made with our father Abraham, saying, "In your descendants all the families of the earth will be blessed."
I, Nephi, talked to them a lot about these things. I spoke to them about the restoration of the Jews in the last days.

I repeated to them the words of Isaiah, who spoke about the restoration of the Jews, or the house of Israel; and after they were restored, they would no longer be confused or scattered again. I spoke many words to my brothers, and they were calmed and humbled themselves before the Lord.
They spoke to me again and asked, "What does this thing our father saw in a dream mean? What does the tree he saw mean?"
I told them it was a symbol of the tree of life.
They asked me, "What does the rod of iron that our father saw, which led to the tree, mean?"

I told them that it was the word of God, and that whoever listens to the word of God and holds tightly to it will never perish; the temptations and fiery darts of the adversary cannot overpower them or blind them to lead them to destruction.

I, Nephi, urged them to pay attention to the word of the Lord. I encouraged them with all the energy of my soul and with all the ability I had, that they would listen to the word of God and remember to always keep his commandments in everything.
And they said to me, "What does the river of water that our father saw mean?"
I told them that the water my father saw was filthy, and his mind was so focused on other things that he didn't notice how dirty the water was.
I told them that it was a terrible gulf that separated the wicked from the tree of life, and also from the saints of God.
I told them that it was a symbol of that terrible hell, which the angel told me was prepared for the wicked.
I told them that our father also saw that God's justice separates the wicked from the righteous. Its brightness was like a flaming fire that rises up to God forever and never ends.

And they said to me, "Does this mean the torment of the body during our time of testing, or does it mean the final state of the soul after the death of the physical body, or is it talking about things that are physical?"

I told them that it was a symbol of things both physical and spiritual, because the day will come when they must be judged for their actions, even the things they did in their physical bodies during their time of testing.

If they die in their wickedness, they must also be cut off from spiritual things related to righteousness. They will have to stand before God to be judged for their works; and if their works have been filthy, they will be filthy. If they are filthy, they cannot live in the kingdom of God, because if they could, the kingdom of God would be filthy too.
I tell you, the kingdom of God is not filthy, and no unclean thing can enter it; so there must be a place of filthiness prepared for what is filthy.

There is a place prepared, that awful hell I have spoken about, and the devil is the one who prepared it. The final state of the souls of men is either to live in the kingdom of God or to be cast out because of the justice I have mentioned.

The wicked are separated from the righteous and from the tree of life, whose fruit is the most precious and most desirable above all other fruits. It is the greatest of all the gifts of God. I spoke these things to my brothers. Amen.
After I, Nephi, finished speaking to my brothers, they said to me, "You have told us difficult things, more than we can handle."

I told them that I knew I had spoken harsh things against the wicked, according to the truth; and I have justified the righteous and testified that they will be lifted up at the last day. The guilty see the truth as harsh, because it cuts them to their very core.

Now my brothers, if you were righteous and willing to listen to the truth and pay attention to it so you could live uprightly before God, then you wouldn't complain about the truth or say, "You're speaking harsh things against us."
I, Nephi, urged my brothers with all diligence to keep the commandments of the Lord.
They humbled themselves before the Lord, so I felt joy and had great hope for them, that they would follow the paths of righteousness.
All these things were said and done while my father lived in a tent in the valley he named Lemuel.
I, Nephi, married one of the daughters of Ishmael. My brothers also married some of the daughters of Ishmael, and Zoram married the oldest daughter of Ishmael.
So my father had completed all the commandments the Lord had given him. I, Nephi, had also been greatly blessed by the Lord.
The voice of the Lord spoke to my father at night and commanded him to begin his journey into the wilderness the next day.

As my father got up in the morning and went to the tent door, he was greatly astonished to see a round ball made with intricate workmanship lying on the ground. It was made of fine brass, and inside the ball were two spindles; one of them pointed the direction we should go in the wilderness.
We gathered everything we needed to take into the wilderness, along with all the rest of the provisions the Lord had given us. We also took seeds of every kind to bring with us into the wilderness.
We took our tents and left into the wilderness, crossing the river Laman.
We traveled for four days in a nearly south-southeast direction, and then we set up our tents again and named the place Shazer.

We took our bows and arrows and went into the wilderness to hunt food for our families. After we had killed food for our families, we returned to them in the wilderness at the place called Shazer. Then we went out again into the wilderness, following the same direction and staying in the most fertile areas near the borders of the Red Sea.
We traveled for many days, hunting for food along the way with our bows and arrows, stones, and slings.
We followed the directions of the ball, which led us through the more fertile parts of the wilderness.
After we had traveled for many days, we set up our tents for a while so we could rest and get food for our families.
As I, Nephi, went out to hunt for food, I broke my bow, which was made of fine steel. After I broke my bow, my brothers were angry with me because we had no way to get food.
We returned to our families without food, and because we were very tired from our journey, they suffered greatly from hunger.

Laman, Lemuel, and the sons of Ishmael began to complain a lot because of their suffering and hardships in the wilderness. My father also started to complain against the Lord his God, and they were all extremely sorrowful, so much that they murmured against the Lord.
I, Nephi, suffered along with my brothers because my bow was lost and their bows had lost their springs. It became extremely difficult, so much that we couldn't get any food.
I, Nephi, spoke at length to my brothers because they had hardened their hearts again and were complaining against the Lord their God.
I, Nephi, made a bow out of wood and an arrow from a straight stick. I armed myself with a bow and arrow, along with a sling and stones. I said to my father, "Where should I go to find food?"
He prayed to the Lord, because they had humbled themselves after hearing my words; I spoke many things to them with all the energy of my soul.
The voice of the Lord came to my father, and he was truly chastened because he had complained against the Lord, to the point that he was brought down into deep sorrow.
The voice of the Lord said to him, "Look at the ball and see what is written."
When my father saw the things written on the ball, he was very afraid and trembled greatly, as did my brothers, the sons of Ishmael, and our wives.
I, Nephi, saw that the pointers in the ball worked according to the faith, diligence, and attention we gave to them.

There was also new writing on them that was easy to read, which helped us understand the ways of the Lord. The writing changed from time to time, depending on the faith and diligence we gave to it. This shows that the Lord can accomplish great things through small means.
I, Nephi, went up to the top of the mountain, following the directions given on the ball.
I killed wild animals and was able to get food for our families.

I returned to our tents, carrying the animals I had killed. When they saw that I had brought back food, they were filled with great joy. They humbled themselves before the Lord and gave thanks to Him.
We continued our journey, traveling nearly the same route as before. After traveling for many days, we set up our tents again so we could stay there for a while.
Ishmael died and was buried in the place called Nahom.

The daughters of Ishmael mourned deeply because they had lost their father and were suffering in the wilderness. They complained against my father for bringing them out of Jerusalem, saying, "Our father is dead, and we have wandered so much in the wilderness. We have suffered greatly—affliction, hunger, thirst, and exhaustion. After all these hardships, we will die here in the wilderness from hunger."
They complained against my father and against me, and they wanted to go back to Jerusalem.
Laman said to Lemuel and to the sons of Ishmael, "Let's kill our father and our brother Nephi, who has made himself our ruler and our teacher, even though we are his older brothers."

He says that the Lord has spoken to him, and that angels have ministered to him. But we know he's lying to us; he says these things and does many things with his cunning tricks to deceive us, maybe thinking he can lead us into some strange wilderness. After he leads us away, he plans to make himself king and ruler over us, so he can do whatever he wants with us. This is how my brother Laman stirred up their hearts to anger.

The Lord was with us, and the voice of the Lord spoke many words to them and chastened them greatly. After they were chastened by the voice of the Lord, they turned away their anger and repented of their sins, so the Lord blessed us again with food, and we did not perish.
We continued our journey in the wilderness, traveling almost directly east from that time on. We went through many hardships in the wilderness, and our women gave birth to children there.

The Lord blessed us so much that even though we lived on raw meat in the wilderness, our women were able to nurse their children well and were strong, just like the men; they began to endure their journeys without complaining.

We see that God's commandments must be fulfilled. If people keep God's commandments, he nourishes them, strengthens them, and provides ways for them to accomplish what he has commanded. He provided for us while we traveled in the wilderness.
We traveled and lived in the wilderness for many years, even eight years.

We arrived at the land we called Bountiful because it had plenty of fruit and wild honey. The Lord had prepared all these things so we wouldn't perish. We saw the sea, which we called Irreantum, meaning many waters.

We set up our tents by the seashore. Even though we had suffered many hardships and difficulties—so many that we can't write them all—we were extremely happy when we arrived at the seashore. We named the place Bountiful because it had so much fruit.

After I, Nephi, had been in the land of Bountiful for many days, the voice of the Lord came to me, saying, "Arise and go into the mountain." So I got up, went into the mountain, and prayed to the Lord.
The Lord spoke to me, saying, "You will build a ship in the way that I will show you, so I can carry your people across these waters."
And I said, Lord, where should I go to find ore to melt, so I can make tools to build the ship the way you have shown me?
The Lord told me where I should go to find ore so that I could make tools.
I, Nephi, made a bellows out of animal skins to blow on the fire. After I made the bellows so I could keep the fire going, I struck two stones together to make a fire.
The Lord had not allowed us to make much fire as we traveled in the wilderness, because he said, "I will make your food taste good so you don't have to cook it."

I will also be your light in the wilderness, and I will prepare the way before you if you keep my commandments. As long as you keep my commandments, you will be led toward the promised land, and you will know that it is by me that you are led.

And the Lord also said that after you have arrived in the promised land, you will know that I, the Lord, am God, and that I, the Lord, delivered you from destruction, and that I brought you out of the land of Jerusalem.
So I, Nephi, tried to keep the commandments of the Lord, and I encouraged my brothers to be faithful and diligent.
I made tools from the ore that I melted out of the rock.

When my brothers saw that I was about to build a ship, they started to complain about me, saying, "Our brother is a fool, because he thinks he can build a ship, and he also thinks he can cross these great waters."
So my brothers complained about me and didn't want to work, because they didn't believe I could build a ship; they also didn't believe that I was guided by the Lord.

I, Nephi, was extremely sorrowful because of how hard their hearts were. When they saw that I was sad, they were glad and even rejoiced over me, saying, "We knew you couldn't build a ship, because we knew you lacked good judgment; so you can't accomplish such a great task."

You are just like our father, being led by the foolish ideas in his heart. He has led us out of Jerusalem, and we have wandered in the wilderness for many years. Our women have worked hard while pregnant; they have given birth in the wilderness and suffered everything except death. It would have been better if they had died before leaving Jerusalem than to suffer these hardships.
All these years we have suffered in the wilderness, when we could have enjoyed our possessions and the land of our inheritance, and we could have been happy.

We know that the people in Jerusalem were righteous because they kept the statutes and judgments of the Lord and all his commandments according to the law of Moses. So we know they are righteous, but our father has judged them and has led us away because we were willing to listen to his words. Our brother is just like him. This is how my brothers murmured and complained against us.
I, Nephi, said to them, "Do you believe that our ancestors, the children of Israel, would have been led out of the hands of the Egyptians if they had not listened to the words of the Lord?"
Do you think they would have been led out of bondage if the Lord had not commanded Moses to lead them out?
You know that the children of Israel were in bondage, and you know they were burdened with tasks that were hard to bear. So, you know it must have been good for them to be brought out of bondage.
You know that Moses was commanded by the Lord to do that great work, and you know that by his word the waters of the Red Sea were divided in both directions, and they passed through on dry ground.
You know that the Egyptians, who were Pharaoh's armies, were drowned in the Red Sea.
And you also know that they were fed with manna in the wilderness.
You also know that Moses, by his word and the power of God in him, struck the rock, and water came out so the children of Israel could quench their thirst.

Even though they were being led, with the Lord their God, their Redeemer, going before them, guiding them by day and giving them light at night, and doing everything for them that was necessary for people to receive, they hardened their hearts, blinded their minds, and spoke against Moses and against the true and living God.
As he promised, he destroyed them; as he promised, he led them; as he promised, he did everything for them; and nothing happened except by his word.
After they crossed the river Jordan, he made them powerful enough to drive out the people of the land and scatter them to destruction.
Do you think the people who lived in this promised land, who were driven out by our ancestors, were righteous? I tell you, no.
Do you think our ancestors would have been more favored than them if they had been righteous? I'm telling you, no.

The Lord values all people equally; those who are righteous are favored by God. But this people rejected every word of God and were full of wickedness, so the fullness of God's wrath was upon them. The Lord cursed the land against them and blessed it for our ancestors. He cursed it against them for their destruction and blessed it for our ancestors so they could have power over it.
The Lord has created the earth so it can be inhabited, and he has created his children so they can possess it.
He raises up a righteous nation and destroys the nations of the wicked.
He leads the righteous into precious lands, and destroys the wicked, and curses the land for their sake.
He rules high in the heavens, for that is his throne, and this earth is his footstool.

He loves those who accept him as their God. He loved our ancestors and made covenants with them—even Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—and he remembered the covenants he had made, so he brought them out of the land of Egypt.

He disciplined them in the wilderness with his rod because they hardened their hearts, just as you have. The Lord disciplined them because of their sins. He sent fiery flying serpents among them, and after they were bitten, he provided a way for them to be healed. All they had to do was look, but because the way was so simple and easy, many of them died.
