The Lamanites kept coming out to attack us from time to time, trying to destroy us with their strategies; but we couldn't fight them directly because they kept retreating to their strongholds.
We waited in these difficult circumstances for many months, until we were about to die from lack of food.

We received food, which was brought to us by an army of two thousand men to help us; and this was all the assistance we received to defend ourselves and our country from falling into the hands of our enemies, to fight against an enemy that was countless.
We didn't know why they hadn't sent us more help, and because of this we were troubled and afraid that God's judgments might come upon our land, leading to our defeat and complete destruction.

So we poured out our souls in prayer to God, asking him to strengthen us and deliver us from our enemies, and also to give us strength to keep our cities, our lands, and our possessions for the support of our people.
The Lord our God visited us with assurances that he would deliver us; he spoke peace to our souls, gave us great faith, and caused us to hope for our deliverance in him.
We gained courage with the small force we had received, and we were determined to defeat our enemies and to protect our lands, our possessions, our wives, our children, and the cause of our freedom.
So we went forward with all our strength against the Lamanites in the city of Manti, and we set up our tents by the edge of the wilderness, which was near the city.
The next day, when the Lamanites saw that we were near the edge of the wilderness by the city, they sent out their spies around us to find out the number and strength of our army.

When they saw that we weren't strong based on our numbers, and were afraid we might cut them off from their support unless they came out to fight us and kill us, and since they thought they could easily destroy us with their large armies, they started getting ready to come out and fight us.

When we saw that they were getting ready to come out against us, I had Gid take a small group of men and hide in the wilderness, and I also had Teomner with a small group of men hide in the wilderness as well.

Gid and his men were on the right and the others on the left; after they hid themselves, I stayed with the rest of my army in the same place where we had first set up our tents, waiting for the Lamanites to come out to battle.
The Lamanites came out with their large army against us. When they arrived and were about to attack us with their swords, I had my men, those who were with me, retreat into the wilderness.

The Lamanites chased after us quickly because they were very eager to catch us and kill us. They followed us into the wilderness, and we passed by Gid and Teomner in such a way that the Lamanites didn't notice them.
When the Lamanites, or their army, had passed by, Gid and Teomner came out of their hiding places and stopped the Lamanite spies so they couldn't return to the city.
When they had cut them off, they ran to the city and attacked the guards who were left to guard it, destroying them and taking possession of the city.
This happened because the Lamanites allowed their entire army, except for a few guards, to be led away into the wilderness.
Gid and Teomner were able to take control of their strongholds this way. After traveling a long distance through the wilderness toward the land of Zarahemla, we continued on our way.

When the Lamanites saw that they were marching toward the land of Zarahemla, they became extremely afraid, worried that there was a plan to lead them to destruction. So they began to retreat into the wilderness again, going back the same way they had come.

It was night, and they set up their tents, because the chief captains of the Lamanites thought the Nephites were tired from their march. Believing they had driven out the entire Nephite army, they didn't worry about the city of Manti.
That night, I had my men stay awake and march by a different route toward the land of Manti.
Because we marched at night, the next day we were ahead of the Lamanites and arrived at the city of Manti before they did.
So by using this strategy, we took control of the city of Manti without any bloodshed.

When the armies of the Lamanites arrived near the city and saw that we were prepared to meet them, they were extremely astonished and struck with great fear, so much that they fled into the wilderness.
The armies of the Lamanites fled from this entire part of the land, but they took many women and children with them when they left.

All the cities that the Lamanites had taken are now in our possession, and our fathers, women, and children are returning to their homes, except for those who have been taken prisoner and carried away by the Lamanites.
Our armies are too small to maintain such a large number of cities and so many possessions.
We trust in our God, who has given us victory over those lands, so that we have regained those cities and lands, which were ours.
We don't know why the government isn't giving us more support, and the men who joined us also don't know why we haven't received more help.
We do not know if you have been unsuccessful and have drawn the forces into that part of the land; if so, we do not want to complain.
And if this isn't true, we're afraid there's a faction in the government that isn't sending more men to help us, because we know they have more people than those they've sent.
But it doesn't matter—we trust that God will deliver us, despite the weakness of our armies, and He will deliver us from the hands of our enemies.
This is the twenty-ninth year, near the end, and we have control of our lands; the Lamanites have fled to the land of Nephi.

Those sons of the people of Ammon, whom I have spoken so highly of, are with me in the city of Manti; and the Lord has supported them and kept them from falling by the sword, so that not even one soul has been killed.

They have received many wounds; nevertheless, they remain firm in the freedom that God has given them, and they are careful to remember the Lord their God every day. They keep his statutes, his judgments, and his commandments continually, and their faith is strong in the prophecies about what is to come.

My beloved brother Moroni, may the Lord our God, who has redeemed us and made us free, keep you always in his presence; and may he bless this people, so that you may succeed in regaining everything the Lamanites have taken from us, which was for our support. I now close my letter. I am Helaman, the son of Alma.

In the thirtieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, after Moroni received and read Helaman's letter, he was extremely happy because of Helaman's well-being and the great success he had in reclaiming the lands that had been lost.
He let all his people in the surrounding area know so they could also rejoice.

He immediately sent a letter to Pahoran, asking him to gather men to strengthen Helaman, or Helaman's armies, so that he could more easily maintain the part of the land he had been so miraculously helped to regain.
After Moroni sent this letter to the land of Zarahemla, he began again to make plans to regain the rest of the possessions and cities that the Lamanites had taken from them.
While Moroni was making preparations to go fight the Lamanites, the people of Nephihah—who had gathered from the cities of Moroni, Lehi, and Morianton—were attacked by the Lamanites.
Even those who had been forced to flee from the land of Manti and the surrounding areas had come and joined the Lamanites in this part of the land.
Because they were extremely numerous and growing stronger every day, by Ammoron's command they attacked the people of Nephihah and began killing them in a very great slaughter.
Their armies were so large that the rest of the people of Nephihah had to flee from them, and they went and joined Moroni's army.

Moroni had assumed that men would be sent to the city of Nephihah to help the people defend it, and knowing that it was easier to keep the city from falling into Lamanite hands than to take it back from them, he thought they would be able to hold the city without much difficulty.
So he kept all his troops to defend the places he had taken back.
When Moroni saw that the city of Nephihah was lost, he was extremely sorrowful and began to doubt, because of the wickedness of the people, whether they would fall into the hands of their brethren.
This was true for all his chief captains. They doubted and were amazed because of the wickedness of the people, and this was because the Lamanites were having success against them.
Moroni was angry with the government because of their indifference about the freedom of their country.

He wrote again to the governor of the land, Pahoran, and these are the words he wrote: I am sending my letter to Pahoran in the city of Zarahemla, who is the chief judge and governor over the land, and also to all those who have been chosen by the people to govern and manage the affairs of this war.

I have something to say to them as a warning; you know that you have been given the responsibility to gather men, arm them with swords, scimitars, and all kinds of weapons of war, and send them out against the Lamanites wherever they enter our land.
I want you to know that my men, Helaman and his men, and I have suffered extremely; we've endured hunger, thirst, exhaustion, and all kinds of hardships.
If this were all we had suffered, we would not complain.

There has been great slaughter among our people; thousands have died by the sword, when it could have been different if you had given our armies enough strength and support. Your neglect toward us has been great.
We want to know the reason for this extremely great neglect; we want to understand why you are being so careless.
Do you think you can just sit on your thrones in a careless daze while your enemies spread death around you, killing thousands of your brothers?

Even those who have looked to you for protection have put you in a position where you could have helped them. You could have sent armies to strengthen them and saved thousands of them from being killed by the sword.

But this is not all—you have withheld your provisions from them, so that many have fought and died because of their strong desire for the welfare of this people. They did this even when they were about to die from hunger because of your extreme neglect toward them.

Now, my beloved brothers—for you should be beloved, and you should have worked harder for the welfare and freedom of this people—but you have neglected them so much that the blood of thousands will be on your heads for vengeance, because God knew all their cries and all their sufferings.
Do you think you can just sit on your thrones and, because God is so good, do nothing and still expect him to deliver you? If you've thought this, you're mistaken.
Do you think that so many of your brothers have been killed because of their wickedness? I tell you, if you think this, you are wrong; many have died by the sword, and it is to your condemnation.

The Lord allows the righteous to be killed so that his justice and judgment can come upon the wicked. You should not think that the righteous are lost because they are killed; they enter into the rest of the Lord, their God.

Now I tell you, I am very afraid that God's judgments will come upon this people because of their extreme laziness, especially the laziness of our government and their great neglect toward their brothers, especially those who have been killed.
If it weren't for the wickedness that started with our leaders, we could have resisted our enemies so they wouldn't have gained any power over us.

If it hadn't been for the war that broke out among ourselves—if it hadn't been for these king-men, who caused so much bloodshed among us—at the time we were fighting among ourselves, if we had united our strength as we had done before; if it hadn't been for the desire for power and authority that those king-men had over us; if they had been true to the cause of our freedom and united with us, and gone out against our enemies instead of taking up their swords against us, which caused so much bloodshed among ourselves—if we had gone out against them with the strength of the Lord, we would have scattered our enemies, because it would have happened according to the fulfillment of his word.

Now the Lamanites are coming against us, taking over our lands, and they are killing our people with the sword—our women and our children—and also carrying them away as captives, making them suffer all kinds of afflictions. This is happening because of the great wickedness of those who are seeking power and authority, even those king-men.
But why should I say more about this? We don't know if you yourselves are seeking power. We don't know if you are also betraying your country.
Or is it that you have neglected us because you are in the center of our country and surrounded by safety, so you don't send us food or men to strengthen our armies?
Have you forgotten the commandments of the Lord your God? Have you forgotten the captivity of our fathers? Have you forgotten the many times we have been delivered out of the hands of our enemies?
Do you think the Lord will still deliver us if we just sit on our thrones and don't use the resources He has given us?

Will you sit in idleness while you are surrounded by thousands, even tens of thousands, who are also sitting in idleness, while there are thousands around the borders of the land who are falling by the sword, wounded and bleeding?

Do you think that God will consider you innocent while you sit and watch these things happen? I tell you, no. Remember that God has said the inside must be cleaned first, and then the outside will be cleaned as well.

If you don't repent of what you've done and start taking action by sending us food and men—and also send them to Helaman so he can support the areas of our country he has regained, and so we can recover the rest of our possessions in these areas—it will be necessary for us to stop fighting the Lamanites until we have first cleansed ourselves, even the main leadership of our government.

Unless you respond to my letter, come out and show me a true spirit of freedom, work to strengthen and support our armies, and provide them with food, I will leave some of my freemen to defend this part of our land, and I will leave them with the strength and blessings of God so that no other power can prevail against them—
And this is because of their great faith and their patience during their trials—

I will come to you, and if anyone among you still desires freedom, even if there is only a spark of it left, I will stir up rebellions among you until those who want to take power and authority are completely removed.

I do not fear your power or your authority, but I fear my God; and it is by his commandments that I take up my sword to defend my country, and it is because of your wickedness that we have suffered so much loss.

It is time—the time is now—that unless you take action to defend your country and your children, the sword of justice hangs over you, and it will fall on you and bring about your complete destruction.

I am waiting for help from you; and unless you give us relief, I will come to you in the land of Zarahemla and attack you with the sword, so that you will have no more power to hinder this people in the cause of our freedom.
The Lord will not allow you to live and grow strong in your sins to destroy his righteous people.

Do you think the Lord will spare you and judge the Lamanites, when their hatred comes from the traditions of their fathers and has been made even stronger by those who have left us, while your wrongdoing is because of your love of glory and the vain things of the world?

You know that you are breaking the laws of God, and you know that you are disregarding them. The Lord has told me: If those you have appointed as your governors do not repent of their sins and wrongdoings, you will go up to battle against them.
Now I, Moroni, am obligated by the covenant I made to keep God's commandments; so I ask you to follow God's word and quickly send me your supplies and men, and also send them to Helaman.
If you won't do this, I will come to you quickly; God will not allow us to die from hunger, so he will give us your food, even if it has to be by the sword. Make sure you fulfill God's word.

I am Moroni, your chief captain. I do not seek power, but to bring it down. I do not seek worldly honor, but the glory of my God, and the freedom and welfare of my country. This is how I close my letter.
Soon after Moroni sent his letter to the chief governor, he received a letter from Pahoran, the chief governor. These are the words he received:

I, Pahoran, the chief governor of this land, am sending these words to Moroni, the chief captain of the army. Moroni, I want you to know that I do not rejoice in your great afflictions; it deeply grieves my soul.

There are people who actually take pleasure in your suffering, so much so that they have rebelled against me, along with some of my people who are freemen, and those who have risen up are very numerous.

Those who have tried to take the judgment seat from me are the cause of this great wickedness. They have used flattery and led many people astray, which will bring serious trouble among us. They have withheld our supplies and discouraged our freemen so that they have not come to you.
They have driven me out before them, and I have fled to the land of Gideon with as many men as I could gather.
I have sent a proclamation throughout this part of the land, and people are coming to us every day, taking up arms to defend their country and their freedom, and to avenge our wrongs.
They have come to us, so that those who have rebelled against us are now defying us, and they are so afraid of us that they don't dare come out to fight us in battle.

They have taken control of the land, or the city, of Zarahemla. They have appointed a king over themselves, and he has written to the king of the Lamanites, making an alliance with him. In this alliance, he has agreed to maintain the city of Zarahemla, believing that by doing so, the Lamanites will be able to conquer the rest of the land, and he will be made king over the people when they are brought under Lamanite control.

In your letter you criticized me, but it doesn't matter; I'm not angry, and I rejoice in the greatness of your heart. I, Pahoran, do not seek power, except to keep my position as chief judge so I can protect the rights and freedom of my people. My soul remains firm in the liberty that God has given us.
We will stand against wickedness, even if it leads to bloodshed. We wouldn't shed the blood of the Lamanites if they would remain in their own land.
We would not kill our brothers if they did not rebel and take up arms against us.
We would submit ourselves to slavery if God's justice required it, or if he commanded us to do so.
He does not command us to submit to our enemies, but wants us to put our trust in him, and he will deliver us.

So, my beloved brother Moroni, let's stand against evil, and whatever evil we can't resist with our words—like rebellions and divisions—let's resist with our swords, so we can keep our freedom and rejoice in the great privilege of our church and in the cause of our Redeemer and our God.

So come to me quickly with a few of your men, and leave the rest under the command of Lehi and Teancum. Give them authority to lead the war in that part of the land, guided by the Spirit of God, which is also the Spirit of freedom within them.
I have sent a few provisions to them so they won't perish before you can come to me.
Gather whatever forces you can as you come here, and we will quickly go against those dissenters, relying on the strength of our God according to the faith we have.
We will take control of the city of Zarahemla so we can get more food to send to Lehi and Teancum. We will go against them with the Lord's strength, and we will put an end to this great wickedness.
Moroni, I'm glad to have received your letter, because I was a bit worried about what we should do and whether it would be right for us to go against our own people.
But you have said that unless they repent, the Lord has commanded you to go against them.

Make sure you strengthen Lehi and Teancum in the Lord; tell them not to be afraid, because God will deliver them, and also everyone who remains firm in the freedom that God has given them. Now I close my letter to my beloved brother, Moroni.
When Moroni received this letter, his heart was encouraged and filled with great joy because of Pahoran's faithfulness, knowing that he was not a traitor to the freedom and cause of his country.
But he also mourned deeply because of the wickedness of those who had driven Pahoran from the judgment seat, and especially because of those who had rebelled against their country and their God.
Moroni took a small number of men, as Pahoran wanted, and put Lehi and Teancum in charge of the rest of his army, then marched toward the land of Gideon.
He raised the standard of liberty everywhere he went and gathered whatever forces he could as he marched toward the land of Gideon.
Thousands gathered to his banner and took up their swords to defend their freedom, so they would not be brought into bondage.

When Moroni had gathered all the men he could during his march, he came to the land of Gideon. He joined his forces with Pahoran's, and together they became extremely strong—stronger than the men of Pachus, who was the king of the dissenters that had driven the freemen out of Zarahemla and taken control of the land.
Moroni and Pahoran went with their armies into the land of Zarahemla and marched against the city, where they met the men of Pachus and engaged in battle.
Pachus was killed, his men were taken as prisoners, and Pahoran was restored to his judgment seat.

The men of Pachus were put on trial according to the law, along with the king-men who had been captured and imprisoned. They were executed according to the law. Anyone from the men of Pachus or the king-men who refused to take up arms to defend their country, and instead fought against it, was put to death.
So it was necessary for this law to be strictly followed for the safety of their country, and anyone who was found denying their freedom was quickly executed according to the law.

This is how the thirtieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended. Moroni and Pahoran restored peace to the land of Zarahemla among their own people, putting to death all those who were not loyal to the cause of freedom.

At the beginning of the thirty-first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, Moroni immediately arranged for provisions and an army of six thousand men to be sent to Helaman to help him protect that part of the land.
He also ordered that an army of six thousand men, with enough food, be sent to support the armies of Lehi and Teancum. This was done to strengthen the land against the Lamanites.
Moroni and Pahoran, leaving a large group of men in the land of Zarahemla, marched with another large group toward the land of Nephihah, determined to defeat the Lamanites in that city.
As they were marching toward the land, they captured a large group of Lamanite men, killed many of them, and took their supplies and weapons of war.
After they captured them, they made them promise that they would never again take up weapons of war against the Nephites.
After they made this covenant, they sent them to live with the people of Ammon. There were about four thousand of them who had not been killed.

After they sent them away, they continued their march toward the land of Nephihah. When they arrived at the city of Nephihah, they set up their tents in the plains of Nephihah, which are near the city.

Moroni wanted the Lamanites to come out and fight them on the plains, but the Lamanites, seeing how courageous they were and how many there were, didn't dare come out to fight. So they didn't go to battle that day.
When night came, Moroni went out in the darkness and climbed to the top of the wall to find out where in the city the Lamanites had set up camp with their army.

They were on the east, by the entrance, and all of them were asleep. Moroni returned to his army and had them quickly prepare strong cords and ladders to be lowered from the top of the wall into the inner part of the wall.
Moroni ordered his men to march forward, climb to the top of the wall, and lower themselves into that part of the city on the west, where the Lamanites had not set up their armies.
They were all let down into the city at night using their strong cords and ladders. When morning came, they were all inside the city walls.
When the Lamanites woke up and saw that Moroni's armies were inside the walls, they were extremely frightened and fled out through the pass.

When Moroni saw that they were running away from him, he had his men march against them. They killed many, surrounded many others, and took them as prisoners. The rest fled into the land of Moroni, which was on the borders by the seashore.
Moroni and Pahoran regained control of the city of Nephihah without losing a single person, while many of the Lamanites were killed.
Many of the Lamanites who were prisoners wanted to join the people of Ammon and become a free people.
Everyone who wanted it was given according to their desires.

All the Lamanite prisoners joined the people of Ammon and began working hard, farming the land, growing all kinds of crops, and raising flocks and herds of every kind. In this way, the Nephites were freed from a great burden, so much so that they no longer had any Lamanite prisoners.

After Moroni gained control of the city of Nephihah and took many prisoners, which greatly reduced the Lamanite armies, and after he recovered many Nephites who had been taken prisoner, which greatly strengthened his army, Moroni left the land of Nephihah and went to the land of Lehi.
When the Lamanites saw that Moroni was coming against them, they were frightened again and fled from Moroni's army.

Moroni and his army pursued them from city to city until they were met by Lehi and Teancum. The Lamanites fled from Lehi and Teancum, down to the borders by the seashore, until they came to the land of Moroni.
The armies of the Lamanites were all gathered together in one group in the land of Moroni. Ammoron, the king of the Lamanites, was there with them.
Moroni, Lehi, and Teancum camped with their armies around the borders of the land of Moroni, so that the Lamanites were surrounded by wilderness on the south and on the east.

So they camped for the night. The Nephites and the Lamanites were both exhausted from the long march, so they didn't plan any strategies during the night, except for Teancum. He was extremely angry with Ammoron, because he believed that Ammoron and his brother Amalickiah were responsible for this long and terrible war between them and the Lamanites, which had caused so much fighting, bloodshed, and even famine.

Teancum, angry, went into the Lamanite camp and lowered himself over the city walls. He moved around with a cord until he found the king and threw a javelin at him, piercing him near the heart. But the king woke his servants before he died, and they chased Teancum and killed him.

When Lehi and Moroni learned that Teancum was dead, they were extremely sorrowful, for he had been a man who fought bravely for his country, a true friend to liberty, and he had suffered many severe afflictions. But he was dead, and had passed on like everyone eventually does.

The next day, Moroni marched out and attacked the Lamanites, killing many of them. They drove the Lamanites out of the land, and the Lamanites fled and did not return to fight the Nephites at that time.
That was the end of the thirty-first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi. They had experienced wars, bloodshed, famine, and affliction for many years.
There were murders, arguments, divisions, and all kinds of wickedness among the people of Nephi; but for the sake of the righteous, and because of their prayers, they were spared.

Because the war between the Nephites and the Lamanites lasted so long, many people became hardened, but many others were softened by their afflictions and humbled themselves before God in deep humility.

After Moroni had fortified the parts of the land most exposed to the Lamanites until they were strong enough, he returned to the city of Zarahemla. Helaman also returned to his homeland, and peace was once again established among the people of Nephi.
Moroni gave command of his armies to his son, Moronihah, and he went home to spend the rest of his life in peace.

Pahoran returned to his judgment seat, and Helaman began preaching the word of God to the people again. Because there had been so many wars and conflicts, it was necessary to make new regulations in the church.

So Helaman and his brothers went out and taught the word of God with great power, convincing many people of their wickedness, which led them to repent of their sins and be baptized to the Lord their God.
They reestablished the church of God throughout all the land.
Regulations were made concerning the law, and their judges and chief judges were chosen.
The people of Nephi began to prosper again in the land, multiplying and becoming very strong once more. They also started to grow extremely rich.
But despite their riches, strength, and prosperity, they were not prideful; they quickly remembered the Lord their God and humbled themselves deeply before him.

They remembered the great things the Lord had done for them—how he had saved them from death, from captivity, from prisons, from all kinds of hardships, and how he had delivered them from their enemies.
They prayed to the Lord their God continually, and the Lord blessed them according to his word, so they became strong and prospered in the land.
All these things were accomplished. Helaman died in the thirty-fifth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.
At the beginning of the thirty-sixth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, Shiblon took possession of the sacred things that had been given to Helaman by Alma.
He was a just man who lived uprightly before God. He continually did good and kept the commandments of the Lord his God, and so did his brother.
Moroni also died, and that was the end of the thirty-sixth year of the reign of the judges.

In the thirty-seventh year of the reign of the judges, a large group of five thousand four hundred men, along with their wives and children, left the land of Zarahemla and went into the land to the north.

Hagoth, who was an extremely curious man, went out and built a very large ship on the borders of the land Bountiful, near the land Desolation, and launched it into the west sea by the narrow neck that led to the land northward.
Many of the Nephites entered there and sailed with plenty of provisions, along with many women and children. They traveled north. That was the end of the thirty-seventh year.
In the thirty-eighth year, this man built more ships. The first ship also returned, and many more people boarded it. They took plenty of provisions and set out again toward the land northward.
They were never heard from again. We believe they drowned in the depths of the sea. Another ship also set sail, but we don't know where it went.
That year, many people traveled to the land northward. That was the end of the thirty-eighth year.
In the thirty-ninth year of the reign of the judges, Shiblon also died, and Corianton had traveled by ship to the land northward to deliver provisions to the people who had settled there.
So Shiblon needed to give those sacred things, before he died, to Helaman's son, who was also named Helaman after his father.
All the engravings that Helaman had were written down and sent out among the people throughout the land, except for the parts that Alma had commanded should not be shared.
These things were to be kept sacred and passed down from one generation to another. So, in this year, they were given to Helaman before Shiblon died.
Also in this year, some dissenters went over to the Lamanites, and they were stirred up again to anger against the Nephites.

Also in that same year, they came down with a large army to fight against the people of Moronihah, or against Moronihah's army, but they were defeated and driven back to their own lands, suffering heavy losses.
That was the end of the thirty-ninth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.
This is the end of the account of Alma, his son Helaman, and also Shiblon, who was his son.
At the beginning of the fortieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, a serious difficulty began among the Nephites.
Pahoran had died and passed away like everyone else, so a serious disagreement began among his sons about who should have the judgment-seat.
Their names, who competed for the judgment-seat and caused the people to argue, were Pahoran, Paanchi, and Pacumeni.
These are not all the sons of Pahoran, because he had many, but these are the ones who competed for the judgment-seat. As a result, they caused three divisions among the people.
However, Pahoran was chosen by the voice of the people to be chief judge and governor over the people of Nephi.
When Pacumeni saw that he could not obtain the judgment-seat, he joined with the voice of the people.
Paanchi and the group of people who wanted him to be their governor were extremely angry; so he was about to persuade those people to rebel against their brothers.
As he was about to do this, he was captured, tried according to the voice of the people, and sentenced to death because he had started a rebellion and tried to destroy the people's freedom.

When the people who wanted him to be their governor saw that he was sentenced to death, they became angry and sent a man named Kishkumen to the judgment seat of Pahoran, and Kishkumen killed Pahoran as he sat on the judgment seat.
He was chased by the servants of Pahoran, but Kishkumen fled so quickly that no one could catch him.
He went to those who had sent him, and they all made a covenant, swearing by their everlasting Maker that they would not tell anyone that Kishkumen had murdered Pahoran.

So Kishkumen was not recognized among the people of Nephi, because he was in disguise when he killed Pahoran. Kishkumen and his group, who had made a secret agreement with him, mixed in with the people so well that they couldn't all be found; but everyone who was discovered was sentenced to death.

Pacumeni was appointed, according to the voice of the people, to be chief judge and governor over the people, to rule in place of his brother Pahoran, and it was his right. All this happened in the fortieth year of the reign of the judges, and it came to an end.

In the forty-first year of the reign of the judges, the Lamanites gathered an innumerable army of men and armed them with swords, scimitars, bows, arrows, headplates, breastplates, and all kinds of shields.
They came down again to fight against the Nephites. They were led by a man named Coriantumr, who was a descendant of Zarahemla and a dissenter from among the Nephites. He was a large and mighty man.

So the king of the Lamanites, named Tubaloth, who was the son of Ammoron, thought that Coriantumr, being a strong and wise man, could stand against the Nephites, and that by sending him out, he would gain power over the Nephites—
He stirred them up to anger, gathered his armies, appointed Coriantumr as their leader, and sent them to march down to the land of Zarahemla to fight against the Nephites.

Because there was so much contention and difficulty in the government, they hadn't kept enough guards in the land of Zarahemla, since they thought the Lamanites wouldn't dare come into the center of their lands to attack the great city of Zarahemla.
Coriantumr marched at the front of his large army and attacked the people in the city, moving so quickly that the Nephites had no time to gather their armies.
So Coriantumr killed the guards at the entrance of the city, then marched in with his entire army, and they killed everyone who tried to resist them, taking control of the whole city.
Pacumeni, who was the chief judge, fled from Coriantumr all the way to the city walls. Coriantumr struck him against the wall so hard that he died. That was the end of Pacumeni's days.

When Coriantumr saw that he had control of the city of Zarahemla, saw that the Nephites had fled from them, had been killed, captured, or thrown into prison, and that he had taken possession of the strongest fortress in the whole land, he gained confidence and was about to march against the entire land.

He didn't stay in the land of Zarahemla, but marched with a large army toward the city of Bountiful, because he was determined to fight his way through with the sword so he could take control of the northern parts of the land.
Assuming that their greatest strength was in the center of the land, he marched forward, giving them no time to gather except in small groups; in this way, they attacked them and cut them down.
Coriantumr's march through the center of the land gave Moronihah a great advantage over them, even though many Nephites had been killed.

Moronihah had assumed that the Lamanites wouldn't dare enter the center of the land, but would attack the cities around the borders as they had done before. So Moronihah made sure their strong armies defended those areas along the borders.

However, the Lamanites were not afraid as he wanted. They had entered the center of the land, captured the capital city of Zarahemla, and were moving through the most important parts of the land, killing many people—men, women, and children—and taking control of many cities and strongholds.
When Moronihah discovered this, he immediately sent Lehi with an army to intercept them before they could reach the land Bountiful.
He did just that; he confronted them before they reached the land of Bountiful and fought against them, causing them to start retreating back toward the land of Zarahemla.
Moronihah intercepted them as they retreated and fought against them, resulting in an extremely bloody battle. Many were killed, and among those who died was Coriantumr.
The Lamanites could not retreat in any direction—north, south, east, or west—because the Nephites had surrounded them on all sides.
In this way, Coriantumr led the Lamanites deep into the Nephite territory, so they ended up under the Nephites' control. Coriantumr was killed, and the Lamanites surrendered to the Nephites.
Moronihah took control of the city of Zarahemla again and made sure that the Lamanites who had been taken as prisoners left the land peacefully.
That is how the forty-first year of the reign of the judges ended.

In the forty-second year of the reign of the judges, after Moronihah had restored peace between the Nephites and the Lamanites, there was no one to fill the judgment-seat. Because of this, the people began to argue again about who should take that position.
Helaman, the son of Helaman, was chosen by the people to fill the judgment-seat.
Kishkumen, who had murdered Pahoran, waited in secret to kill Helaman as well; and he was supported by his group, who had made a covenant that no one would discover his wickedness.

There was a man named Gadianton who was very skilled with words and also in his craft, using them to carry out secret acts of murder and robbery. Because of this, he became the leader of Kishkumen's group.
He flattered them, including Kishkumen, promising that if they made him the judge, he would give power and authority to those in his group; so Kishkumen tried to kill Helaman.
As he went toward the judgment seat to kill Helaman, one of Helaman's servants, who had been out at night and had learned about the plans this group had made to kill Helaman by using a disguise,
He met Kishkumen and gave him a sign. Kishkumen then told him what he wanted, asking him to lead him to the judgment seat so he could kill Helaman.

When Helaman's servant understood everything Kishkumen intended in his heart—that his goal was to murder, and that everyone in his group wanted to murder, rob, and gain power as part of their secret plan—the servant said to Kishkumen, "Let's go to the judgment-seat."

This made Kishkumen very happy, because he thought he would succeed in his plan. But as they were on their way to the judgment seat, Helaman's servant stabbed Kishkumen in the heart, and he died instantly without making a sound. The servant then ran and told Helaman everything he had seen, heard, and done.
Helaman sent out orders to capture this group of robbers and secret murderers, so they could be executed according to the law.

When Gadianton realized that Kishkumen didn't return, he was afraid he would be destroyed. So he had his group follow him, and they escaped from the land by a secret route into the wilderness. When Helaman sent people to capture them, they couldn't be found anywhere.
More will be said about this Gadianton later. This is how the forty-second year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended.
At the end of this book, you will see that this Gadianton was responsible for the overthrow and almost the complete destruction of the people of Nephi.
I don't mean the end of the book of Helaman, but the end of the book of Nephi, from which I have taken all the account I have written.

In the forty-third year of the reign of the judges, there was no conflict among the people of Nephi except for a little pride within the church, which caused some minor disagreements among the people. These issues were resolved by the end of the forty-third year.
There was no contention among the people in the forty-fourth year, and there was not much contention in the forty-fifth year either.
In the forty-sixth year, there was a lot of contention and many disagreements; many people left the land of Zarahemla and traveled north to inherit the land.
They traveled a very long distance, until they reached large bodies of water and many rivers.
They spread out into all parts of the land, into any areas that hadn't been made desolate and without timber by the many people who had previously lived there.
Now no part of the land was uninhabited, except where there was no timber; but because so many of the people who had previously lived there had been destroyed, it was called desolate.
Since there was very little timber in the land, the people who moved there became very skilled at working with cement. So they built houses out of cement, and lived in them.

They multiplied and spread, moving from the land in the south to the land in the north, until they began to cover the entire land, from the southern sea to the northern sea, and from the western sea to the eastern sea.

The people in the land northward lived in tents and in houses made of cement, and they allowed any tree that grew on the land to keep growing so that, over time, they would have timber to build their houses, cities, temples, synagogues, sanctuaries, and all kinds of other buildings.
Because timber was very scarce in the land northward, they sent a lot of it there by ship.
In this way, they helped the people in the land northward so they could build many cities, made of both wood and cement.
Many of the people of Ammon, who were Lamanites by birth, also went into this land.
There are many records kept about what these people have done, written by many of them, and these records are detailed and extensive.

Not even a hundredth part of the history of this people—the account of the Lamanites and the Nephites, their wars, conflicts, divisions, preaching, prophecies, shipbuilding, construction of temples, synagogues, and sanctuaries, their righteousness and wickedness, murders, robberies, plundering, and all kinds of abominations and immoral acts—can be included in this record.
There are many books and many records of every kind, and they have been kept mainly by the Nephites.

These records have been passed down from one generation to another by the Nephites, until they fell into sin and were murdered, plundered, hunted, driven out, killed, and scattered across the earth, mixing with the Lamanites until they were no longer called Nephites, becoming wicked, wild, and fierce, even becoming Lamanites.
Now I return to my account; what I have spoken happened after there had been great arguments, disturbances, wars, and disagreements among the people of Nephi.
The forty-sixth year of the reign of the judges ended.
There was still great contention in the land during the forty-seventh year, and also in the forty-eighth year.

However, Helaman filled the judgment-seat with justice and fairness; he made sure to keep the statutes, judgments, and commandments of God, and he did what was right in God's sight at all times. He followed the ways of his father so that he prospered in the land.
He had two sons. He gave the oldest the name Nephi, and the youngest the name Lehi. They began to grow up in the ways of the Lord.
The wars and conflicts began to decrease somewhat among the Nephite people toward the end of the forty-eighth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.

In the forty-ninth year of the reign of the judges, there was continual peace in the land, except for the secret combinations that Gadianton the robber had set up in the more settled areas. At that time, those in charge of the government didn't know about them, so they weren't removed from the land.
During that same year, the church experienced tremendous prosperity, and thousands of people joined the church and were baptized in repentance.
The church prospered so much, and so many blessings were given to the people, that even the high priests and teachers were amazed.
The work of the Lord prospered, leading to the baptism and uniting of many souls—tens of thousands—into the church of God.
This shows that the Lord is merciful to everyone who sincerely calls on his holy name.
This shows that the gate of heaven is open to everyone, including all who believe in the name of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

We see that anyone who wants to can hold onto the word of God, which is living and powerful. It will cut through all the tricks, traps, and schemes of the devil, and guide the follower of Christ along a straight and narrow path across the endless gulf of misery prepared to swallow the wicked.
And bring their souls, their immortal souls, to the right hand of God in the kingdom of heaven, to sit with Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all our holy fathers, never to leave again.
During this year, there was continual rejoicing in the land of Zarahemla and in all the surrounding regions, throughout all the land possessed by the Nephites.
There was peace and extremely great joy during the rest of the forty-ninth year, and there was also continual peace and great joy in the fiftieth year of the reign of the judges.

In the fifty-first year of the reign of the judges, there was peace, except for the pride that began to enter the church—not into the church of God itself, but into the hearts of the people who claimed to belong to the church of God.

They became prideful, even to the point of persecuting many of their brothers and sisters. This was a great evil, which caused the more humble people to suffer intense persecution and go through much hardship.

However, they fasted and prayed often, and grew stronger and stronger in their humility, and firmer and firmer in their faith in Christ, filling their souls with joy and comfort, even to the purification and sanctification of their hearts, which sanctification comes because they yielded their hearts to God.

The fifty-second year also ended in peace, except for the extremely great pride that had entered the hearts of the people. This was because of their great riches and prosperity in the land, and their pride grew day by day.

In the fifty-third year of the reign of the judges, Helaman died, and his oldest son Nephi became the leader in his place. Nephi judged with justice and fairness; he kept God's commandments and followed the ways of his father.
In the fifty-fourth year, there were many disagreements in the church, and there was also conflict among the people, resulting in much bloodshed.
The rebellious group were killed or driven out of the land, and they went to the king of the Lamanites.
They tried to persuade the Lamanites to go to war against the Nephites, but the Lamanites were extremely afraid and refused to listen to the dissenters.

In the fifty-sixth year of the reign of the judges, some dissenters left the Nephites and joined the Lamanites. Together with others, they stirred up the Lamanites to anger against the Nephites, and they spent the entire year preparing for war.

In the fifty-seventh year, they came down against the Nephites to battle and began the work of death, so much that in the fifty-eighth year of the reign of the judges, they succeeded in taking possession of the land of Zarahemla and also all the lands, even up to the land near Bountiful.
The Nephites and Moronihah's armies were driven all the way into the land of Bountiful.

There they fortified themselves against the Lamanites, from the west sea all the way to the east. It was a day's journey for a Nephite along the line they had fortified, where they stationed their armies to defend their northern country.

So the Nephite dissenters, with the help of a large Lamanite army, took control of all the Nephite lands in the southern region. All of this happened during the fifty-eighth and fifty-ninth years of the reign of the judges.
In the sixtieth year of the reign of the judges, Moronihah and his armies succeeded in taking back many parts of the land; they regained many cities that had fallen into the hands of the Lamanites.
In the sixty-first year of the reign of the judges, they succeeded in regaining even half of all their possessions.

This great loss of the Nephites, and the terrible slaughter among them, would not have happened if it weren't for their wickedness and the abominations among them; and this was also true of those who claimed to belong to the church of God.

It was because of the pride in their hearts and their great wealth. They oppressed the poor, withheld food from the hungry, withheld clothing from the naked, struck their humble brothers on the cheek, mocked what was sacred, denied the spirit of prophecy and revelation, committed murder, plundering, lying, stealing, adultery, stirred up great contentions, and deserted to the land of Nephi among the Lamanites.

Because of their great wickedness and their boasting in their own strength, they were left to their own strength. As a result, they did not prosper, but were afflicted, beaten, and driven by the Lamanites until they had lost possession of almost all their lands.

Moronihah preached many things to the people because of their sin, and Nephi and Lehi, the sons of Helaman, also preached and prophesied to the people about their sins and what would happen to them if they did not repent.
They repented, and as they repented, they began to prosper.
When Moronihah saw that they had repented, he took the risk to lead them from place to place and from city to city, until they had regained half of their property and half of all their lands.
That was the end of the sixty-first year of the reign of the judges.
In the sixty-second year of the reign of the judges, Moronihah was unable to gain any more territory from the Lamanites.

So they gave up their plan to take back the rest of their lands, because there were so many Lamanites that it was impossible for the Nephites to gain more power over them. Moronihah used all his armies to hold on to the areas he had already taken.
Because there were so many Lamanites, the Nephites were very afraid that they would be overpowered, trampled, killed, and destroyed.
They began to remember the prophecies of Alma and the words of Mosiah, and they realized they had been a stubborn people and had ignored the commandments of God.

They had changed and disregarded the laws of Mosiah, or what the Lord commanded him to give to the people. They saw that their laws had become corrupted and that they had become a wicked people, just as wicked as the Lamanites.
Because of their sin, the church started to shrink, and people began to doubt the spirit of prophecy and the spirit of revelation. God's judgments were clearly before them.

They saw that they had become weak, like their brothers, the Lamanites, and that the Spirit of the Lord no longer preserved them; it had withdrawn from them because the Spirit of the Lord does not dwell in unholy temples—

So the Lord stopped preserving them by his miraculous and unmatched power, because they had fallen into unbelief and terrible wickedness; and they saw that the Lamanites were far more numerous than they were, and unless they held firmly to the Lord their God, they would surely be destroyed.
They saw that the strength of the Lamanites was equal to their own, matching them man for man. They had fallen into this great transgression and had become weak because of it, in just a few years.
In that same year, Nephi gave up the judgment-seat to a man named Cezoram.

Since their laws and governments were established by the voice of the people, and those who chose evil outnumbered those who chose good, they were becoming ready for destruction, because the laws had become corrupted.
And this was not all; they were a stubborn people, so much that they could not be governed by law or justice, except it led to their destruction.

Nephi became weary because of their wickedness, so he gave up the judgment seat and dedicated himself to preaching the word of God for the rest of his life, and his brother Lehi did the same for the rest of his life.
They remembered the words their father Helaman spoke to them. These are the words he said:

My sons, I want you to remember to keep the commandments of God, and I want you to share these words with the people. I have given you the names of our first parents who came out of the land of Jerusalem, and I did this so that when you remember your names, you will remember them; and when you remember them, you will remember their works; and when you remember their works, you will know that it is said and written that they were good.
So, my sons, I want you to do what is good, so that it can be said of you, and also written about you, just as it has been said and written about them.

And now, my sons, I have something more to ask of you. I want you to do these things not to boast, but to lay up for yourselves a treasure in heaven—one that is eternal and never fades away—so you may have that precious gift of eternal life, which we have reason to believe was given to our fathers.

Remember, my sons, the words King Benjamin spoke to his people. Remember that there is no other way or means for anyone to be saved except through the atoning blood of Jesus Christ, who will come. Remember that he is coming to redeem the world.

Also remember the words Amulek spoke to Zeezrom in the city of Ammonihah. He told him that the Lord would surely come to redeem his people, but not to redeem them in their sins—rather, to redeem them from their sins.

He has been given power from the Father to redeem them from their sins because of repentance. He has sent his angels to announce the message about the conditions of repentance, which lead to the power of the Redeemer and the salvation of their souls.

Now, my sons, remember that you must build your foundation on the rock of our Redeemer, who is Christ, the Son of God. Then, when the devil sends his powerful winds, his arrows in the whirlwind, and all his hail and mighty storm beat upon you, they will have no power to drag you down to misery and endless sorrow, because of the rock you are built on—a sure foundation, where if people build, they cannot fall.
These were the words Helaman taught to his sons; he taught them many things that aren't written, as well as many things that are written.
They remembered his words, so they went out, keeping God's commandments, to teach God's word to all the people of Nephi, starting in the city of Bountiful.
And from there to the city of Gid; and from the city of Gid to the city of Mulek;
They traveled from one city to another, until they had visited all the people of Nephi who were in the southern land, and then went into the land of Zarahemla, among the Lamanites.

They preached with great power, so much that they confused many of the dissenters who had left the Nephites. These people came forward, confessed their sins, were baptized in repentance, and immediately returned to the Nephites to try to make right the wrongs they had done.
Nephi and Lehi preached to the Lamanites with great power and authority, because power and authority had been given to them so they could speak, and they were also given the words they should say—

They spoke and greatly astonished the Lamanites, convincing them so much that eight thousand Lamanites in the land of Zarahemla and the surrounding area were baptized in repentance and realized the wickedness of their fathers' traditions.
Nephi and Lehi left from there to go to the land of Nephi.
They were captured by a Lamanite army and thrown into prison, the same prison where Ammon and his brothers had been put by Limhi's servants.
After they had been kept in prison for many days without food, the people went into the prison to take them so they could kill them.

Nephi and Lehi were surrounded as if by fire, so much so that the others were afraid to touch them, fearing they might be burned. However, Nephi and Lehi were not burned; they stood in the middle of the fire and were not harmed.
When they saw that they were surrounded by a pillar of fire and that it did not burn them, their hearts were filled with courage.
They saw that the Lamanites didn't dare touch them or even come near them, but just stood there as if they were struck dumb with amazement.
Nephi and Lehi stood up and began to speak to them, saying, "Do not be afraid, for it is God who has shown you this marvelous thing, which shows you that you cannot lay your hands on us to kill us."

When they said these words, the earth shook violently, and the walls of the prison shook as if they were about to collapse, but they did not fall. The people in the prison were Lamanites and Nephites who had become dissenters.
They were covered by a cloud of darkness, and a terrible, solemn fear came over them.
A voice came from above the cloud of darkness, saying: Repent, repent, and stop trying to destroy my servants whom I have sent to declare good news to you.
When they heard this voice, they saw that it was not a voice of thunder or a loud, chaotic noise, but a quiet voice of perfect gentleness, like a whisper, and it pierced to the very soul—

Even though the voice was gentle, the earth shook violently, and the walls of the prison trembled again, as if they were about to collapse; and the cloud of darkness that had covered them did not go away—
The voice came again, saying: Repent, repent, for the kingdom of heaven is near; and stop trying to destroy my servants. The earth shook again, and the walls trembled.
A third time the voice spoke to them, saying marvelous words that no human can express. The walls trembled again, and the earth shook as if it were about to split apart.
The Lamanites couldn't run away because the cloud of darkness was covering them, and they were also unable to move because they were so afraid.
One of them was a Nephite by birth who had once been a member of the church of God but had left it.

He turned around and saw, through the cloud of darkness, the faces of Nephi and Lehi; their faces were shining brightly, like the faces of angels. He saw that they lifted their eyes toward heaven, and they looked as if they were talking or lifting their voices to someone they could see.
The man cried out to the crowd, asking them to turn and look. Power was given to them so they turned and looked, and they saw the faces of Nephi and Lehi.
They said to the man, "What do all these things mean, and who are these men talking with?"
The man's name was Aminadab. Aminadab said to them, "They are talking with the angels of God."
The Lamanites said to him, "What should we do so that this cloud of darkness will be removed from overshadowing us?"

Aminadab said to them, "You need to repent and call out to the voice until you have faith in Christ, who was taught to you by Alma, Amulek, and Zeezrom. When you do this, the cloud of darkness will be removed from over you."
They all began to cry out to the voice of the one who had shaken the earth; they cried out until the cloud of darkness was dispersed.
When they looked around and saw that the cloud of darkness had disappeared from above them, they saw that they were surrounded—every person—by a pillar of fire.

Nephi and Lehi were in the middle of them, surrounded as if by a flaming fire, but it did not harm them or touch the walls of the prison. They were filled with joy that is indescribable and full of glory.
The Holy Spirit of God came down from heaven and entered into their hearts. They were filled as if with fire, and they were able to speak marvelous words.
A voice came to them—a pleasant voice, like a whisper—saying:
Peace be with you because of your faith in my Beloved Son, who existed from the foundation of the world.
When they heard this, they looked up as if to see where the voice was coming from, and they saw the heavens open. Angels came down from heaven and ministered to them.
About three hundred people saw and heard these things, and they were told to go out and not be amazed or doubt.

They went out and ministered to the people, telling everyone in the surrounding regions about everything they had heard and seen, so much so that most of the Lamanites were convinced because of the overwhelming evidence they had received.
All those who were convinced gave up their weapons of war, as well as their hatred and the traditions of their fathers.
They gave the lands they possessed to the Nephites.

When the sixty-second year of the reign of the judges ended, all these things had happened, and most of the Lamanites had become a righteous people, to the point that their righteousness was greater than that of the Nephites because of their firmness and steadiness in the faith.
Many of the Nephites had become hardened, unrepentant, and extremely wicked, so much that they rejected the word of God and all the preaching and prophesying that came among them.

However, the people of the church had great joy because of the conversion of the Lamanites, and because the church of God had been established among them. They spent time together, rejoiced together, and felt great happiness.
Many of the Lamanites went down to the land of Zarahemla and told the Nephite people how they were converted, encouraging them to have faith and repent.
Many preached with great power and authority, leading many people to become deeply humble and to follow God and the Lamb with humility.
Many of the Lamanites went into the land northward, and Nephi and Lehi also went into the land northward to preach to the people. That is how the sixty-third year ended.
There was peace throughout the land, so the Nephites could travel to any part of the land they wanted, whether among the Nephites or the Lamanites.
The Lamanites also traveled wherever they wanted, whether among the Lamanites or the Nephites, and they freely interacted with each other to buy, sell, and make profit as they wished.
They became extremely rich, both the Lamanites and the Nephites. They had an abundance of gold, silver, and all kinds of precious metals, both in the land south and in the land north.
The land to the south was called Lehi, and the land to the north was called Mulek, named after the son of Zedekiah. The Lord brought Mulek into the northern land and Lehi into the southern land.

There was every kind of gold in both these lands, as well as silver and all kinds of precious ore. There were also skilled craftsmen who worked with all kinds of ore and refined it, and in this way they became rich.

They raised plenty of grain in both the north and the south, and they prospered greatly in both regions. Their population grew, and they became very strong in the land. They also raised many flocks and herds, including many fattened animals.
Their women worked hard, spinning and making all kinds of cloth—fine-twined linen and every type of fabric—to clothe themselves. In this way, the sixty-fourth year passed in peace.
In the sixty-fifth year they also had great joy and peace, with much preaching and many prophecies about what was to come. That is how the sixty-fifth year ended.

In the sixty-sixth year of the reign of the judges, Cezoram was murdered by an unknown person as he sat on the judgment seat. In that same year, his son, who had been appointed by the people to take his place, was also murdered. That is how the sixty-sixth year ended.
At the beginning of the sixty-seventh year, the people started becoming extremely wicked again.

The Lord had blessed them for so long with worldly riches that they hadn't been stirred up to anger, wars, or bloodshed. Because of this, they started to set their hearts on their riches and began seeking wealth so they could be lifted above one another. They began to commit secret murders, and to rob and plunder, so they could gain more.

Those murderers and plunderers were a group formed by Kishkumen and Gadianton. There were many, even among the Nephites, who belonged to Gadianton's group. However, they were even more numerous among the more wicked part of the Lamanites. They were called Gadianton's robbers and murderers.
They were the ones who murdered the chief judge Cezoram and his son while they were in the judgment seat, and they were not found.
When the Lamanites discovered that there were robbers among them, they were extremely sorrowful, and they used every means in their power to destroy them from the face of the earth.

Satan stirred up the hearts of most of the Nephites, so they joined with those groups of robbers and entered into their covenants and oaths to protect and support each other in whatever difficult situations they faced, so they would not be punished for their murders, plundering, and stealing.

They had their signs, their secret signs, and their secret words so they could recognize a brother who had entered into the covenant. This way, no matter what wickedness his brother did, he would not be harmed by him or by anyone else who belonged to the group and had made this covenant.
In this way, they could murder, plunder, steal, commit sexual immorality, and do all kinds of wickedness, going against the laws of their country and the laws of their God.

Anyone who belonged to their group and revealed their wickedness and abominations to the world would be judged, not by the laws of their country, but by the laws of their wickedness, which had been given by Gadianton and Kishkumen.
These secret oaths and covenants are the ones that Alma commanded his son not to share with the world, because they could lead the people to destruction.

Those secret oaths and covenants didn't come to Gadianton from the records given to Helaman; instead, they were put into Gadianton's heart by the same being who tempted our first parents to eat the forbidden fruit—
That same being plotted with Cain, telling him that if he murdered his brother Abel, it would not be known to the world. He continued to plot with Cain and his followers from that time on.

It is that same being who inspired the people to build a tower tall enough to reach heaven. He also led the people who came from that tower into this land, spreading evil and abominations everywhere, until he brought the people to complete destruction and everlasting hell.
It is that same being who put it into Gadianton's heart to continue the work of darkness and secret murder; and he has brought it about from the beginning of man up to now.

He is the author of all sin. He continues his works of darkness and secret murder, passing down their plots, oaths, covenants, and plans of terrible wickedness from generation to generation, as much as he can influence the hearts of the children of men.

He had gained great influence over the hearts of the Nephites, so much that they became extremely wicked. Most of them turned away from righteousness, rejected God's commandments, followed their own desires, and made idols out of their gold and silver.
All these sins came upon them within just a few years, so that most of it had happened by the sixty-seventh year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.
They continued to increase in their wickedness during the sixty-eighth year as well.

The Nephites began to lose their faith and become more wicked and corrupt, while the Lamanites started to grow greatly in their knowledge of God. They began to keep his statutes and commandments, and to live in truth and righteousness before him.
We see that the Spirit of the Lord began to withdraw from the Nephites because of their wickedness and the hardness of their hearts.
We see that the Lord began to pour out his Spirit on the Lamanites because they were open and willing to believe his words.
The Lamanites hunted the band of Gadianton robbers, and they preached the word of God to the more wicked among them, so that this band of robbers was completely destroyed from among the Lamanites.

On the other hand, the Nephites built them up and supported them, starting with the more wicked among them, until they had spread throughout all the land of the Nephites and had persuaded most of the righteous to believe in their actions, share in their stolen goods, and join them in their secret murders and conspiracies.
So they took complete control of the government, and they oppressed, attacked, and rejected the poor, the meek, and the humble followers of God.
We can see that they were in a terrible condition and becoming ready for eternal destruction.
That is how the sixty-eighth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended.
In the sixty-ninth year of the reign of the judges over the Nephite people, Nephi, the son of Helaman, returned to the land of Zarahemla from the land to the north.
He had been among the people in the land northward, preaching the word of God to them and prophesying many things to them.
They rejected all his words so completely that he couldn't stay among them, and he returned to the land where he was born.

Seeing the people in such terrible wickedness, with the Gadianton robbers filling the judgment seats and taking control and authority over the land, they set aside God's commandments and were not right before him at all, doing no justice to the people.

They condemned the righteous because of their righteousness, let the guilty and wicked go unpunished because of their money, and held office at the head of government to rule and do whatever they wanted so they could gain wealth and worldly glory, and make it easier for themselves to commit adultery, steal, kill, and do whatever they pleased.
This great wickedness had come upon the Nephites in just a few years. When Nephi saw it, his heart was filled with sorrow, and he cried out in agony.

I wish I could have lived in the days when my father Nephi first left Jerusalem, so I could have rejoiced with him in the promised land. Back then, his people were willing to listen, committed to keeping God's commandments, slow to do wrong, and quick to obey the words of the Lord.
If I had lived in those days, my soul would have found joy in the righteousness of my brothers.
But I accept that these are my days, and my soul will be filled with sorrow because of the wickedness of my brothers.

Nephi was on a tower in his garden, which was by the highway that led to the main market in the city of Zarahemla. He had bowed himself on the tower in his garden, and the tower was also near the garden gate by the highway.

Some men were passing by and saw Nephi as he was pouring out his soul to God on the tower. They ran and told others what they had seen, and people gathered in large numbers to find out why there was such great mourning over the wickedness of the people.
Now, when Nephi stood up, he saw the crowds of people who had gathered together.
He opened his mouth and said to them, "Why have you gathered together? Is it so I can tell you about your sins?"
Because I have gone up on my tower to pour out my soul to God, because my heart is filled with sorrow over your sins!

Because of my mourning and lamentation, you have gathered together and are amazed; and you have good reason to be amazed. You should be amazed that you have allowed the devil to gain such a strong hold on your hearts.
How could you have given in to the temptations of the one who is trying to throw your souls into everlasting misery and endless sorrow?
Repent, repent! Why will you die? Turn to the Lord your God. Why has he forsaken you?
It is because you have hardened your hearts; you will not listen to the voice of the good shepherd; you have provoked him to anger against you.
Instead of gathering you, unless you repent, he will scatter you so that you become food for dogs and wild animals.
Oh, how could you have forgotten your God on the very day that he has delivered you?

It is to gain wealth, to be praised by others, and so you can get gold and silver. You have set your hearts on the riches and empty things of this world, and because of this you murder, plunder, steal, lie about your neighbor, and commit all kinds of wickedness.

Because of this, sorrow will come to you unless you repent. If you do not repent, this great city and all the other great cities around it, which are in our land, will be taken from you so that you will have no place in them. The Lord will not give you strength, as he has before, to stand against your enemies.

This is what the Lord says: I will not show my strength to the wicked, giving more to one than another, except to those who repent of their sins and listen to my words. So, my brothers, I want you to understand that it will be better for the Lamanites than for you unless you repent.

They are more righteous than you, because they have not sinned against the great knowledge you have received. Therefore, the Lord will be merciful to them; he will extend their days and increase their descendants, even when you will be completely destroyed unless you repent.
You will be cursed because of that great abomination that has come among you, and you have joined yourselves to it—to that secret group established by Gadianton!
You will face sorrow because of the pride you have allowed into your hearts, which has made you think you are better than you should because of your extremely great riches.
How terrible it will be for you because of your wickedness and abominations!
If you don't repent, you will be destroyed; even your lands will be taken from you, and you will be wiped off the face of the earth.
I'm not saying these things on my own, because I don't know them by myself; but I know they are true because the Lord God has revealed them to me, so I testify that they will happen.

When Nephi finished speaking, some of the judges—who were also members of the secret band of Gadianton—became angry and shouted against him, saying to the people, "Why don't you seize this man and bring him forward so he can be condemned for the crime he has committed?"
Why do you watch this man and listen to him speak against this people and against our law?
Nephi had spoken to them about the corruption of their law. Nephi said many things that cannot be written, and nothing he said was contrary to the commandments of God.

The judges were angry with him because he spoke plainly to them about their secret works of darkness; however, they didn't dare lay their own hands on him, because they were afraid the people would cry out against them.

So they called out to the people, saying, "Why do you let this man speak against us? He condemns all these people, even to destruction, and says that our great cities will be taken from us so we will have no place in them."
And now we know that this is impossible, because we are powerful and our cities are great, so our enemies cannot have any power over us.

They stirred up the people to anger against Nephi and caused arguments among them. Some people spoke out, saying, "Leave this man alone, for he is a good man, and the things he says will surely happen unless we repent."

All the judgments he has testified about will come upon us, because we know he has spoken the truth about our sins. Our sins are many, and he knows everything that will happen to us just as well as he knows about our sins.
If he had not been a prophet, he could not have testified about those things.

The people who wanted to destroy Nephi were forced, because they were afraid, not to touch him. So he began to speak to them again, seeing that he had gained favor with some of them, which made the rest of them afraid.

So he had to speak more to them, saying: My brothers, haven't you read that God gave power to one man, Moses, to strike the waters of the Red Sea, and they parted so that the Israelites, our ancestors, crossed on dry ground, and then the waters closed over the Egyptian armies and swallowed them up?
If God gave this man such power, then why do you argue among yourselves and say that He hasn't given me any power to know about the judgments that will come upon you unless you repent?
You not only deny my words, but you also deny all the words spoken by our fathers, and the words spoken by Moses, who was given such great power—the words he spoke about the coming of the Messiah.
Did he not testify that the Son of God would come? And just as he lifted up the bronze serpent in the wilderness, so will the one who is to come be lifted up.
Anyone who looked at that serpent would live; in the same way, anyone who looks to the Son of God with faith and a humble heart can live, even to eternal life.
Moses not only testified of these things, but so did all the holy prophets from his time back to the days of Abraham.
Abraham saw that he would come, and was filled with gladness and rejoiced.

Abraham not only knew about these things, but there were many people before Abraham who were called by the order of God, even after the order of his Son. This was done to show the people, thousands of years before his coming, that redemption would come to them.
I want you to know that ever since the days of Abraham, many prophets have testified of these things. The prophet Zenos testified boldly about them, and because of this, he was killed.

Zenock, Ezias, Isaiah, and Jeremiah—Jeremiah being the prophet who testified about the destruction of Jerusalem—and now we know that Jerusalem was destroyed just as Jeremiah said. So why couldn't the Son of God come, just as he prophesied?

Now, will you argue that Jerusalem was not destroyed? Will you say that the sons of Zedekiah were not killed, all except Mulek? And don't you see that the descendants of Zedekiah are with us, and they were driven out of the land of Jerusalem? But this isn't all—
