Our father Lehi was driven out of Jerusalem because he testified of these things. Nephi also testified of these things, and almost all of our fathers, even down to this time; they have testified of the coming of Christ, have looked forward to it, and have rejoiced in his day which is to come.
He is God, and he is with them, and he showed himself to them so they were redeemed by him; and they gave him glory because of what was to come.

Now, since you know these things and can't deny them unless you lie, you have sinned in this, because you have rejected all these things, even though you have received so much evidence. You have received everything—things in heaven and things on earth—as witnesses that they are true.

You have rejected the truth and rebelled against your holy God. Even now, instead of storing up treasures in heaven, where nothing is corrupted and nothing unclean can enter, you are piling up wrath for yourselves against the day of judgment.
Right now you are becoming ready for everlasting destruction because of your murders, your sexual immorality, and your wickedness; and unless you repent, it will come to you soon.

It is now right at your doors; go into the judgment-seat and look, and you will see that your judge has been murdered and is lying in his blood. He has been murdered by his brother, who wants to take his place on the judgment-seat.
They both belong to your secret group, whose founder is Gadianton and the evil one who seeks to destroy the souls of men.
When Nephi finished speaking, some of the men there ran to the judgment seat; five of them went, and as they went, they talked among themselves:

Now we will know for sure whether this man is a prophet and if God has commanded him to prophesy such marvelous things to us. We do not believe that he has; we do not believe that he is a prophet. However, if what he said about the chief judge is true—that he is dead—then we will believe that the other things he has spoken are true.
They ran with all their strength and entered the judgment seat, and saw that the chief judge had fallen to the ground and was lying in his own blood.
When they saw this, they were extremely astonished and fell to the ground, because they had not believed what Nephi had said about the chief judge.
When they saw, they believed, and fear came over them that all the judgments Nephi had spoken might come upon the people. They trembled and fell to the ground.
As soon as the judge was murdered—stabbed by his brother in secret—his brother fled, and the servants ran to tell the people, raising the alarm of murder among them.
The people gathered together at the place of the judgment seat, and to their astonishment, they saw the five men who had fallen to the ground.

The people didn't know anything about the crowd that had gathered at the garden of Nephi, so they said to each other, "These men are the ones who have murdered the judge, and God has struck them so they couldn't escape from us."
They seized them, tied them up, and threw them into prison. A proclamation was sent out that the judge had been killed, and that the murderers had been caught and put in prison.
The next day, the people gathered together to mourn and fast at the burial of the great chief judge who had been killed.
In the same way, the judges who were at the garden of Nephi and heard his words were also gathered together at the burial.

They asked the people, "Where are the five who were sent to find out if the chief judge was dead?" The people answered, "About these five you say you sent, we don't know; but there are five who are the murderers, and we have put them in prison."

The judges wanted them to be brought in, and they were brought in—it was the five who had been sent. The judges questioned them about the situation, and they told the judges everything they had done, saying:
We ran to the judgment seat, and when we saw everything just as Nephi had said, we were so astonished that we fell to the ground. When we recovered from our shock, they threw us into prison.
As for the murder of this man, we don't know who did it; all we know is that we ran and came just as you asked, and he was dead, just as Nephi said.

The judges explained the situation to the people and accused Nephi, saying, "We know that Nephi must have conspired with someone to kill the judge, so that he could reveal it to us, convert us to his beliefs, and make himself out to be a great man, chosen by God and a prophet."
Now we will catch this man, and he will admit his guilt and reveal to us who the real murderer of this judge is.
The five were released on the day of the burial. However, they rebuked the judges for what they had said against Nephi and argued with them one by one, until the judges were left confused.
However, they had Nephi taken, tied up, and brought before the crowd, and they started questioning him in different ways, trying to trap him so they could accuse him and have him put to death.

They said to him, "You're an accomplice; who is the man that committed this murder? Now tell us and admit your guilt. Here is money, and we'll also spare your life if you'll tell us and admit the agreement you made with him."
But Nephi said to them, "You fools, you who are stubborn in your hearts, blind, and stubborn people, do you know how long the Lord your God will allow you to continue in this sinful way?"
You should start to cry out and mourn because great destruction is waiting for you right now, unless you repent.

You say that I made an agreement with someone to murder Seezoram, our chief judge. But I tell you, the reason I have testified to you about this is so that you would know about it; it is a witness to you that I was aware of the wickedness and abominations among you.
And because I have done this, you say that I made an agreement with a man to do it; because I showed you this sign, you are angry with me and want to take my life.
Now I will show you another sign, and see if you will try to destroy me because of this.
I say to you: Go to the house of Seantum, who is the brother of Seezoram, and say to him—
Has Nephi, the so-called prophet who prophesies so much evil about this people, made an agreement with you, in which you have murdered Seezoram, who is your brother?
He will say to you, "No."
And you will say to him, "Have you murdered your brother?"
He will stand in fear and won't know what to say. He will deny it to you and pretend to be astonished; however, he will tell you that he is innocent.
You will examine him, and you will find blood on the edges of his cloak.
And when you see this, you will say, "Where did this blood come from? Don't we know that it's the blood of your brother?"
And then he will tremble and look pale, as if death has come upon him.
And then you will say, "Because of this fear and the paleness that has come over your face, we know that you are guilty."
Then he will become even more afraid, and he will admit to you that he committed this murder and will deny it no longer.
He will tell you that I, Nephi, know nothing about the matter except what was given to me by the power of God. Then you will know that I am an honest man and that I am sent to you from God.
They went and did exactly as Nephi had told them. The words he spoke were true; just as he said, the man denied it at first, and then, just as Nephi said, he confessed.
He was brought forward and proven to be the murderer, so the five men were released, as well as Nephi.
Some of the Nephites believed Nephi's words, and others believed because of the testimony of the five, since they had been converted while they were in prison.
Some of the people said that Nephi was a prophet.

Some people said, "He is a god, because unless he were a god, he couldn't know everything. He has told us the thoughts in our hearts and has revealed things to us. He has even shown us who really killed our chief judge."
A division arose among the people, and they separated and went their own ways, leaving Nephi alone as he stood among them.
Nephi went on his way toward his own house, thinking about the things the Lord had shown him.

As he was thinking about these things—feeling very discouraged because of the wickedness of the Nephite people, their secret works of darkness, their murders, their thefts, and all kinds of sin—as he was pondering in his heart, a voice came to him saying:

You are blessed, Nephi, for what you have done. I have seen how you have tirelessly declared the word I have given you to this people. You have not been afraid of them, and you have not sought your own life, but you have sought my will and to keep my commandments.

Because you have done this with such perseverance, I will bless you forever. I will make you powerful in word and in action, in faith and in works—even so that everything will be done for you according to your word, for you will not ask for anything that is against my will.

You are Nephi, and I am God. I declare to you in the presence of my angels that you will have power over this people, and you will strike the earth with famine, pestilence, and destruction according to the wickedness of this people.
I give you power that whatever you seal on earth will be sealed in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven. In this way, you will have power among this people.
So, if you say to this temple that it will be split in two, it will happen.
And if you say to this mountain, "Be cast down and become smooth, " it will be done.
If you say that God will strike this people, it will happen.
Now I command you to go and tell this people that the Lord God, who is the Almighty, says: Unless you repent, you will be struck down and destroyed.

When the Lord had spoken these words to Nephi, he stopped and did not go to his own house, but returned to the multitudes who were scattered across the land and began to declare to them the word of the Lord that had been spoken to him, warning them of their destruction if they did not repent.
Even though Nephi had performed a great miracle by telling them about the death of the chief judge, they hardened their hearts and did not listen to the words of the Lord.
So Nephi told them the word of the Lord, saying: Unless you repent, the Lord says you will be struck down and destroyed.
When Nephi had declared the word to them, they still hardened their hearts and would not listen to him. They spoke against him and tried to seize him so they could throw him into prison.
The power of God was with him, and they couldn't take him to throw him into prison, because he was taken by the Spirit and carried away from among them.
He went forward in the Spirit, moving from group to group, declaring the word of God until he had shared it with everyone or sent it out among all the people.
They would not listen to his words, and arguments began among them, so much that they turned against each other and started killing one another with swords.
And that is how the seventy-first year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended.
In the seventy-second year of the reign of the judges, the conflicts increased so much that there were wars throughout the entire land among all the people of Nephi.
This secret group of robbers was responsible for the destruction and wickedness. The war lasted throughout that year and continued into the seventy-third year.
That year, Nephi prayed to the Lord, saying:
Lord, please don't let these people be destroyed by war; but instead, let there be a famine in the land to remind them of you, their God, so that maybe they will repent and turn to you.

It happened just as Nephi said. There was a great famine throughout the land, affecting all the people of Nephi. In the seventy-fourth year, the famine continued, and the destruction stopped by the sword but became severe because of the famine.

This destruction continued in the seventy-fifth year. The earth was struck with drought and didn't produce grain during the harvest season. The whole land was affected, among both the Lamanites and the Nephites, and in the more wicked areas, thousands died.
The people saw that they were about to die from the famine, and they started to remember the Lord their God. They also began to remember the words of Nephi.

The people began to plead with their chief judges and leaders to ask Nephi, "We know you are a man of God, so please pray to the Lord our God to end this famine, so that everything you have said about our destruction won't come true."
The judges told Nephi what had been requested. When Nephi saw that the people had repented and humbled themselves in sackcloth, he prayed to the Lord again, saying:
O Lord, this people is repenting; they have removed the band of Gadianton from among them so completely that they have become extinct, and they have buried their secret plans in the earth.
Now, Lord, because of their humility, will you turn away your anger and let your anger be satisfied with the destruction of those wicked men whom you have already destroyed.
O Lord, will you turn away your anger, your fierce anger, and cause this famine to end in this land.
O Lord, will you listen to me and let it be done according to my words, and send rain upon the earth so that it can produce its fruit and its grain in the season of grain.
Lord, you listened to me when I asked for a famine so the destruction from war would stop; and I know you will listen to me now, because you said that if these people repent, you will spare them.
Lord, you see that they have repented because of the famine, the pestilence, and the destruction that has come upon them.
Now, Lord, will you turn away your anger and try again to see if they will serve you? And if so, Lord, you can bless them according to your words that you have spoken.
In the seventy-sixth year, the Lord turned away his anger from the people and caused rain to fall on the earth, so that it brought forth fruit in its season and grain in its season.

The people rejoiced and glorified God, and the whole land was filled with joy. They no longer tried to destroy Nephi, but regarded him as a great prophet and a man of God, with great power and authority given to him from God.
Lehi, his brother, was just as righteous as he was.

The people of Nephi began to prosper again in the land. They rebuilt their ruined areas and started to multiply and spread until they covered the whole land, both to the north and to the south, from the west sea to the east sea.

The seventy-sixth year ended in peace, and the seventy-seventh year began in peace. The church spread throughout the entire land, and most of the people, both Nephites and Lamanites, belonged to the church. They enjoyed very great peace in the land, and that is how the seventy-seventh year ended.
They also had peace in the seventy-eighth year, except for a few disagreements about the points of doctrine that had been taught by the prophets.

In the seventy-ninth year, there was a lot of conflict. Nephi, Lehi, and many of their brethren who understood the true points of doctrine received many revelations daily, so they preached to the people and were able to end the conflict that same year.

In the eightieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi, a group of dissenters who had left the people of Nephi years earlier and joined the Lamanites, taking on the name of Lamanites, along with some who were actual descendants of the Lamanites, were stirred up to anger by these dissenters. Because of this, they started a war with their brethren.

They committed murder and plunder, then retreated into the mountains, the wilderness, and secret places, hiding so they couldn't be found. Every day, more people joined them as dissenters went out to them.
In time, within just a few years, they became a very large group of robbers. They discovered all the secret plans of Gadianton, and so they became the robbers of Gadianton.
These robbers caused great havoc and destruction among the people of Nephi, and also among the people of the Lamanites.
It was necessary to put a stop to this destruction, so they sent an army of strong men into the wilderness and onto the mountains to search for this band of robbers and destroy them.
In that same year, they were driven back into their own lands. That is how the eightieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended.
At the beginning of the eighty-first year, they went out again against this band of robbers and destroyed many of them; but they also suffered much destruction.
They were once again forced to leave the wilderness and the mountains and return to their own lands because there were so many robbers occupying the mountains and the wilderness.

That is how the year ended. The robbers continued to grow and become stronger, to the point that they challenged the entire armies of both the Nephites and the Lamanites, and they caused great fear among all the people throughout the land.
They went to many parts of the land and caused great destruction; they killed many people and took others captive into the wilderness, especially women and children.
This great evil, which came upon the people because of their sin, reminded them once again of the Lord their God.
That was the end of the eighty-first year of the reign of the judges.
In the eighty-second year, they started to forget the Lord their God again. In the eighty-third year, they became stronger in wickedness. In the eighty-fourth year, they did not change their ways.
In the eighty-fifth year, they grew stronger and stronger in their pride and wickedness, and they were once again becoming ready for destruction.
That was the end of the eighty-fifth year.
We can see how false and unstable the hearts of people are, and we can see that the Lord, in his great infinite goodness, blesses and prospers those who put their trust in him.

We can see that when God prospers his people—when their fields, flocks, herds, gold, silver, and all kinds of valuable things increase; when he spares their lives, delivers them from their enemies, softens the hearts of their enemies so they don't go to war against them, and does everything for their welfare and happiness—that is when they harden their hearts, forget the Lord their God, and disrespect the Holy One. This happens because of their comfort and great prosperity.
We see that unless the Lord corrects his people with many hardships—unless he allows them to experience death, fear, famine, and all kinds of disease—they will not remember him.

Oh, how foolish, vain, evil, and devilish, and how quick to do wrong and slow to do good are the children of men. How quickly they listen to the words of the evil one and set their hearts on the worthless things of the world!

How quick people are to be lifted up in pride, to boast, and to do all kinds of wickedness; and how slow they are to remember the Lord their God and listen to his counsel, and how slow they are to walk in the paths of wisdom!

They do not want the Lord their God, who has created them, to rule and reign over them. Even with his great goodness and mercy toward them, they ignore his counsel and refuse to let him be their guide.
Oh, how great is the nothingness of the children of men; they are even less than the dust of the earth.
The dust of the earth moves here and there, separating as commanded by our great and everlasting God.
At his voice, the hills and the mountains tremble and shake.
By the power of his voice they are broken up and become smooth, even like a valley.
By the power of his voice, the whole earth shakes.
By the power of his voice, the foundations shake, even to the very center.
And if he says to the earth, "Move, " it is moved.
If he tells the earth to go back so that the day is extended for many hours, it happens.
And so, according to his word, the earth moves backward, and it appears to people that the sun stands still; this is true, because it is the earth that moves and not the sun.
And if he says to the waters of the great deep, "Be dried up, " it happens.
If he says to this mountain, "Be raised up, and go over and fall on that city so that it is buried, " it is done.
If a man hides a treasure in the earth, and the Lord says, "Let it be cursed because of the wickedness of the one who hid it, " then it will be cursed.
And if the Lord says, "Be cursed, so that no one will find you from now on and forever, " then no one will find it from that time on and forever.
If the Lord says to a man, "Because of your sins, you will be cursed forever, " it will happen.
If the Lord says, "Because of your sins you will be cut off from my presence, " he will make it happen.
And sorrow awaits anyone to whom he says this, for it applies to those who choose to do evil, and they cannot be saved. For this reason—that people might be saved—repentance has been declared.
So, those who repent and listen to the voice of the Lord their God are blessed, because they are the ones who will be saved.
May God, in His great fullness, allow people to be led to repentance and good works, so they can be restored to grace for grace according to their actions.
I want everyone to be saved. But we read that on the great and last day, some people will be cast out and separated from the presence of the Lord.

Anyone who is consigned to a state of endless misery fulfills the words that say: Those who have done good will have everlasting life, and those who have done evil will have everlasting damnation. That's how it is. Amen.
In the eighty-sixth year, the Nephites still remained in wickedness, in great wickedness, while the Lamanites strictly kept the commandments of God according to the law of Moses.

In that year, a man named Samuel, a Lamanite, came into the land of Zarahemla and began to preach to the people. He preached repentance to them for many days, but they cast him out, and he was about to return to his own land.
The voice of the Lord came to him, telling him to return and prophesy to the people whatever things would come into his heart.
They wouldn't allow him to enter the city, so he went and climbed up on the wall, stretched out his hand, and called out loudly, prophesying to the people whatever the Lord put into his heart.

He said to them: I, Samuel, a Lamanite, am speaking the words of the Lord, which He puts into my heart; and He has told me to say to this people that the sword of justice is hanging over them, and in less than four hundred years, the sword of justice will fall on this people.

Terrible destruction is coming to this people, and nothing can save them except repentance and faith in the Lord Jesus Christ, who will definitely come into the world, suffer many things, and be killed for his people.
An angel of the Lord has told me this, and he brought good news to my soul. I was sent to share it with you as well, so you could have this good news; but you would not accept me.

Therefore, the Lord says: Because the people of the Nephites have hard hearts, unless they repent I will take my word away from them, I will withdraw my Spirit from them, I will no longer support them, and I will turn the hearts of their brothers against them.
Four hundred years will not pass before I cause them to be struck; I will visit them with the sword, with famine, and with disease.

I will visit them in my fierce anger, and some of your enemies from the fourth generation will live to see your complete destruction. This will definitely happen unless you repent, says the Lord, and those of the fourth generation will bring about your destruction.
If you will repent and return to the Lord your God, I will turn away my anger, says the Lord. Blessed are those who repent and turn to me, but sorrow awaits those who do not repent.

Destruction is coming to this great city of Zarahemla; it is only saved because of the righteous people here. Destruction is coming to this great city, for I see, says the Lord, that many—actually, most—of the people in this city will harden their hearts against me, says the Lord.
But those who repent are blessed, and I will spare them. If it weren't for the righteous people in this great city, I would send fire down from heaven to destroy it.

It is spared for the sake of the righteous. The Lord says the time will come when you cast out the righteous from among you; then you will be ready for destruction. Woe to this great city because of the wickedness and abominations in it.
And sorrow will come to the city of Gideon because of the wickedness and abominations found there.
And sorrow will come to all the cities in the land around, which are possessed by the Nephites, because of the wickedness and abominations found in them.
A curse will come upon the land, says the Lord of Hosts, because of the people who live on it, because of their wickedness and their abominations.

The Lord of Hosts, our great and true God, says that anyone who hides treasures in the earth will not find them again because of the great curse on the land, unless he is a righteous person and hides them for the Lord.

I want them to store their treasures for me, says the Lord; and those who do not store their treasures for me are cursed. Only the righteous store their treasures for me. Anyone who does not store his treasures for me is cursed, along with his treasure, and no one will recover it because of the curse on the land.

The day will come when they will hide their treasures, because they have set their hearts on riches. Because they are focused on their riches, they will hide their treasures as they flee from their enemies. Since they do not dedicate their treasures to me, they and their treasures will be cursed, and on that day they will be struck down, says the Lord.

People of this great city, listen to my words; listen to what the Lord says. He says you are cursed because of your riches, and your riches are also cursed because you have set your hearts on them and have not listened to the words of the one who gave them to you.

You don't remember the Lord your God in the things he has blessed you with, but you always remember your riches, without thanking the Lord your God for them. Your hearts aren't drawn to the Lord, but instead they swell with great pride, boasting, envy, conflict, malice, persecution, murder, and all kinds of wickedness.
For this reason, the Lord God has brought a curse on the land and on your riches, and it's because of your sins.
Woe to this people because of this time that has come, that you cast out the prophets, mock them, stone them, kill them, and do all kinds of evil to them, just as people did in the past.
Now when you talk, you say, "If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have killed the prophets; we would not have stoned them or cast them out."

You are worse than they are; for as the Lord lives, if a prophet comes among you and declares the word of the Lord, testifying of your sins and wrongdoings, you get angry with him, cast him out, and look for every way to destroy him. You say he is a false prophet, a sinner, and of the devil, because he testifies that your actions are evil.

If someone comes among you and says, "Do this, and there is no sin; do that and you won't suffer; follow the pride of your own hearts; follow the pride of your eyes, and do whatever you want"—if someone says this, you accept him and say he is a prophet.

You will lift him up and give him your possessions; you will give him your gold and silver, and you will clothe him in expensive clothing. Because he speaks flattering words to you and says that all is well, you will not find fault with him.

You wicked and perverse generation, you hardened and stubborn people, how long do you think the Lord will allow you to continue? How long will you let yourselves be led by foolish and blind guides? How long will you choose darkness instead of light?
The anger of the Lord is already kindled against you; he has cursed the land because of your iniquity.
The time is coming when he will curse your riches, and they will become slippery so you can't hold onto them; and in your days of poverty, you won't be able to keep them.

In the days of your poverty, you will cry to the Lord, but your cries will be in vain, because your desolation has already come upon you and your destruction is certain. Then you will weep and howl in that day, says the Lord of Hosts. Then you will mourn and say:

If only I had repented and had not killed the prophets, or stoned them, or cast them out. In that day you will say, "If only we had remembered the Lord our God when he gave us our riches, then they wouldn't have become slippery so that we lost them; because now our riches are gone from us."
We lay a tool here, and the next day it's gone; and our swords are taken from us on the day we need them for battle.
We have hidden our treasures, but they have slipped away from us because of the curse on the land.
If only we had repented when the word of the Lord came to us; now the land is cursed, everything has become slippery, and we can't hold onto anything.

We are surrounded by demons; we are encircled by the angels of the one who has tried to destroy our souls. Our sins are great. O Lord, can you not turn your anger away from us? This will be your language in those days.

Your days of probation are over; you have put off the day of your salvation until it is forever too late, and your destruction is certain. You have spent your lives seeking things you could not obtain, and you have looked for happiness in doing evil, which is completely opposed to the righteousness found in our great and Eternal Head.
People of this land, I wish you would listen to my words. I pray that the Lord's anger will turn away from you, and that you will repent and be saved.
Samuel the Lamanite also prophesied many more things that cannot be written.
He said to them, "I give you a sign: in five more years, the Son of God will come to redeem all those who believe in his name."

I will give you this as a sign at the time of his coming: there will be great lights in the sky, so that on the night before he comes, there will be no darkness, and it will seem to people as if it is daytime.

There will be one day, a night, and another day that will seem like a single day with no night. This will be a sign for you. You will see the sun rise and set, so you will know for sure that there have been two days and a night, but the night will not be dark. This will happen the night before he is born.
A new star will appear, one you have never seen before; this will also be a sign for you.
This isn't all; there will be many signs and wonders in heaven.
You will all be amazed and filled with wonder, so much that you will fall to the ground.
Anyone who believes in the Son of God will have everlasting life.

The Lord has commanded me, through his angel, to come and tell you this. He has commanded me to prophesy these things to you. He has said to me: Call out to this people, repent and prepare the way of the Lord.

Now, because I am a Lamanite and have spoken to you the words the Lord has commanded me, and because they were hard for you to hear, you are angry with me and are trying to destroy me, and you have cast me out from among you.

You will hear my words, for this is why I have come up onto the walls of this city—so you can hear and know about the judgments of God that await you because of your sins, and also so you can understand the conditions of repentance.

And also so you can know about the coming of Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the Father of heaven and earth, the Creator of all things from the beginning; and so you can recognize the signs of his coming, so that you might believe in his name.
If you believe in his name, you will repent of all your sins, so that you can receive forgiveness through his merits.
I am giving you another sign, a sign of his death.
He must die so that salvation can come; it is necessary and essential for him to die to bring about the resurrection of the dead, so that people can be brought into the presence of the Lord.

This death brings about the resurrection and redeems all mankind from the first death—that spiritual death. Because all mankind, through the fall of Adam, are cut off from the presence of the Lord, they are considered dead, both in temporal and spiritual things.
The resurrection of Christ redeems all people and brings them back into the presence of the Lord.

It brings about the opportunity for repentance, so anyone who repents will not be cut down and thrown into the fire; but anyone who does not repent will be cut down and thrown into the fire. They will experience spiritual death again, a second death, because they are once more separated from things related to righteousness.
So repent, repent, or by knowing these things and not doing them, you will bring condemnation on yourselves and be brought down to this second death.

As I told you about another sign—a sign of his death—on the day he suffers death, the sun will be darkened and refuse to give you light, and the moon and the stars as well. There will be no light on the face of this land from the time he dies for three days, until he rises again from the dead.

At the time when he gives up his life, there will be thunder and lightning for many hours, and the earth will shake and tremble; the rocks on the face of this earth, both above and beneath the ground, which you know are now solid, or mostly one solid mass, will be broken apart.
They will be split in two, and from then on will be found in seams, cracks, and broken fragments across the whole earth, both above and beneath the ground.
There will be great storms, and many mountains will be brought down to the level of valleys, and many places that are now called valleys will become mountains, with great height.
Many highways will be destroyed, and many cities will become desolate.
Many graves will be opened and will give up many of their dead, and many saints will appear to many people.
This is what the angel told me; he said there would be thunder and lightning for many hours.
He told me that while the thunder, lightning, and storm continued, these things would happen, and darkness would cover the entire earth for three days.

The angel told me that many people will see even greater things than these, so that they might believe that these signs and wonders will happen throughout this land, and so that there will be no reason for anyone to doubt.

This is so that anyone who chooses to believe can be saved, and anyone who chooses not to believe will receive a righteous judgment; and if they are condemned, they bring that condemnation upon themselves.

Now remember, my brothers, that whoever dies, dies for themselves; and whoever does evil, does it to themselves. You are free and allowed to act for yourselves, because God has given you knowledge and has made you free.

He has given you the ability to know good from evil, and he has given you the ability to choose life or death. You can do good and be restored to what is good, or have what is good restored to you; or you can do evil and have what is evil restored to you.
Now, my beloved brothers, I tell you that unless you repent, your homes will be left to you desolate.

Unless you repent, your women will have great reason to mourn when they nurse their children; you will try to escape, but there will be nowhere to hide. And sorrow will come to those who are pregnant, because they will be burdened and unable to flee; so they will be trampled down and left to die.

Woe to the people called the people of Nephi unless they repent when they see all these signs and wonders shown to them. They have been a chosen people of the Lord; he has loved the people of Nephi, and he has also corrected them. In the days of their sins, he has disciplined them because he loves them.

My brothers, God has hated the Lamanites because their actions have been continually evil, and this is because of the sinful traditions of their fathers. But salvation has come to them through the preaching of the Nephites; and for this reason, the Lord has prolonged their days.
I want you to see that most of them are fulfilling their duties, living carefully before God, and keeping his commandments, statutes, and judgments according to the law of Moses.
I tell you, most of them are doing this, and they are working tirelessly to bring the rest of their brothers to the knowledge of the truth. As a result, many are added to their numbers every day.

You know for yourselves, because you have seen it, that everyone who is brought to know the truth and to recognize the wicked and abominable traditions of their fathers, and who is led to believe the holy scriptures and the prophecies of the holy prophets that are written—which lead them to have faith in the Lord and to repent—this faith and repentance bring a change of heart to them.
So, everyone who has reached this point, you know for yourselves, are firm and steadfast in the faith and in what has made them free.

You also know that they have buried their weapons of war, and they are afraid to take them up again because they might sin. You can see that they are afraid to sin—for they would rather allow themselves to be trampled and killed by their enemies than lift their swords against them, and this is because of their faith in Christ.

Now, because of their steadfastness when they believe in what they believe, and because of their firmness once they are enlightened, the Lord will bless them and prolong their days, despite their iniquity—

Even if they dwindle in unbelief, the Lord will prolong their days until the time comes that our fathers, the prophet Zenos, and many other prophets have spoken of, concerning the restoration of our brothers, the Lamanites, to the knowledge of the truth.

I tell you that in the last days the Lord's promises have been given to our brothers, the Lamanites. Even though they will suffer many hardships, be driven across the earth, hunted, attacked, and scattered with no place to find refuge, the Lord will still show them mercy.
This fulfills the prophecy that they will once again come to a true knowledge—the knowledge of their Redeemer and their great and true shepherd—and be counted among his sheep.
So I tell you, it will be better for them than for you unless you repent.

If the mighty works that have been shown to you had been shown to those who have dwindled in unbelief because of the traditions of their fathers, you can see for yourselves that they never would have dwindled in unbelief again.
Therefore, says the Lord: I will not completely destroy them, but I will make it so that in the day of my wisdom they will return to me, says the Lord.

The Lord says about the Nephite people: If they do not repent and keep my commandments, I will completely destroy them because of their unbelief, even though I have done many mighty works among them. These things will definitely happen, says the Lord.

Many people heard the words of Samuel, the Lamanite, as he spoke from the city walls. Those who believed his message went out to find Nephi; when they found him, they confessed their sins to him and did not deny them, wanting to be baptized to the Lord.

Everyone who didn't believe Samuel's words was angry with him; they threw stones at him on the wall, and many shot arrows at him as he stood on the wall. But the Spirit of the Lord was with him, so they couldn't hit him with their stones or their arrows.
When they saw they couldn't hit him, many more people believed his words, so they went to Nephi to be baptized.
Nephi was baptizing, prophesying, and preaching, calling the people to repent, showing signs and wonders, and performing miracles among them so they would know that Christ would come soon.

He told them about things that would soon happen, so they would know and remember, when those things came, that they had been warned ahead of time, so they might believe. So everyone who believed Samuel's words went to him to be baptized, because they came repenting and confessing their sins.

But most of them did not believe Samuel's words. When they saw they couldn't hit him with their stones and arrows, they called out to their captains, saying, "Take this man and tie him up, for he has a devil. Because of the power of the devil in him, we can't hit him with our stones and arrows. So take him, tie him up, and get rid of him."
As they went to lay their hands on him, he threw himself down from the wall and fled out of their lands, even to his own country, and began to preach and prophesy among his own people.
He was never heard of again among the Nephites, and that's how things stood with the people.
That was the end of the eighty-sixth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi.
So the eighty-seventh year of the reign of the judges ended, with most of the people still proud and wicked, while a smaller group lived more carefully before God.
These were also the conditions during the eighty-eighth year of the reign of the judges.

There was little change in the situation of the people, except that they began to become more hardened in sin and continued to do more and more things that went against the commandments of God in the eighty-ninth year of the reign of the judges.
In the ninetieth year of the reign of the judges, the people saw great signs and wonders, and the words of the prophets began to be fulfilled.
Angels appeared to people, to wise men, and told them good news of great joy; so in this year the scriptures started to be fulfilled.
However, the people began to harden their hearts, except for the most believing among them, both Nephites and Lamanites, and started to rely on their own strength and wisdom, saying:
They might have guessed some things correctly among so many, but we know that all these great and marvelous works that have been spoken of cannot happen.
They started to discuss and argue with each other, saying:

It doesn't make sense that someone like Christ would come; and if he is the Son of God, the Father of heaven and earth, as has been said, why doesn't he show himself to us just like he will to those in Jerusalem?
Why won't he show himself in this land just like he did in Jerusalem?

But we know that this is a wicked tradition passed down to us by our fathers, meant to make us believe in some great and marvelous thing that is supposed to happen—not here, but in a faraway land that we don't know. This way, they can keep us ignorant, because we can't see for ourselves whether it's true.

By the cunning and mysterious arts of the evil one, they will do something we can't understand, which will keep us under their control, making us servants to their words and to them, because we depend on them to teach us the word. If we give in to them, they will keep us ignorant for the rest of our lives.

The people imagined many more things in their hearts, which were foolish and useless, and they were very disturbed because Satan stirred them up to do wrong continually. He went around spreading rumors and contention throughout the land, trying to harden the hearts of the people against what was good and against what was to come.
Even with the signs and wonders performed among the people of the Lord, and the many miracles they did, Satan gained great influence over the hearts of people throughout the land.
This is how the ninetieth year of the reign of the judges over the people of Nephi ended.
This is the end of the book of Helaman, according to the record of Helaman and his sons.
The ninety-first year had passed, and it had been six hundred years since Lehi left Jerusalem; this was the year when Lachoneus was the chief judge and governor over the land.

Nephi, the son of Helaman, had left the land of Zarahemla and gave responsibility to his oldest son, Nephi, for the plates of brass, all the records that had been kept, and all the sacred things preserved since Lehi left Jerusalem.
He left the land, and no one knows where he went. His son Nephi took over keeping the records for him—the record of this people.
At the beginning of the ninety-second year, the prophecies of the prophets started to be fulfilled more completely, as there were greater signs and greater miracles performed among the people.
Some people began to say that the time had passed for Samuel the Lamanite's words to be fulfilled.
They started to rejoice over their brothers, saying, "The time has passed, and Samuel's words have not been fulfilled; so your joy and your faith about this have been in vain."
There was a great uproar throughout the land, and the people who believed became very sorrowful, worried that the things which had been spoken might not happen.
They watched carefully for that day, and that night, and that day which would be like one day as if there were no night, so they could know that their faith had not been in vain.
A day was set by the unbelievers for all those who believed in those traditions to be put to death, unless the sign given by Samuel the prophet happened.
When Nephi, the son of Nephi, saw the wickedness of his people, his heart was extremely sorrowful.
He went out and bowed down on the ground, and cried out with all his strength to God for his people—those who were about to be destroyed because of their faith in the tradition of their fathers.
He prayed earnestly to the Lord all that day, and then the voice of the Lord came to him, saying:

Lift up your head and be of good cheer; the time is near, and tonight the sign will be given. Tomorrow I will come into the world to show everyone that I will fulfill everything I have spoken through my holy prophets.

I am coming to my own to fulfill everything I have revealed to the children of men since the foundation of the world, and to do the will of both the Father and the Son—of the Father because of me, and of the Son because of my flesh. The time is near, and tonight the sign will be given.

The words that came to Nephi were fulfilled, just as they had been spoken; as the sun went down, there was no darkness, and the people began to be astonished because there was no darkness when night came.

Many people who hadn't believed the words of the prophets fell to the ground and seemed as if they were dead, because they realized that the plan of destruction they had made for those who believed the prophets had failed; the sign that had been given had already appeared.

They began to realize that the Son of God would soon appear. All the people across the entire earth, from west to east, both in the land north and in the land south, were so amazed that they fell to the ground.

They knew that the prophets had testified about these things for many years, and that the sign that had been given was already happening. They began to be afraid because of their sin and their unbelief.

There was no darkness that entire night; it was as bright as if it were midday. The sun rose again in the morning as usual, and they knew it was the day the Lord would be born because of the sign that had been given.
Everything happened exactly as the prophets had said.
A new star also appeared, just as was foretold.

From this time on, lies were spread among the people by Satan to harden their hearts so they wouldn't believe in the signs and wonders they had seen. Despite these lies and deceptions, most of the people still believed and were converted to the Lord.
Nephi went among the people, along with many others, baptizing them as they repented, which brought a great remission of sins. The people began once again to have peace in the land.

There were no arguments, except for a few people who started preaching and tried to prove with the scriptures that it was no longer necessary to follow the law of Moses. In this, they were mistaken because they didn't understand the scriptures.

They soon became converted and realized the mistake they were in, because it was made known to them that the law was not yet fulfilled and that it must be completely fulfilled. The word came to them that not even the smallest part would pass away until everything was fulfilled. So, in that same year, they recognized their error and confessed their faults.
So the ninety-second year passed, bringing good news to the people because the signs happened just as all the holy prophets had prophesied.

The ninety-third year also passed in peace, except for the Gadianton robbers who lived in the mountains and infested the land. Their strongholds and secret places were so secure that the people couldn't overpower them, so they committed many murders and caused much slaughter among the people.
In the ninety-fourth year, their numbers increased greatly because many Nephite dissenters fled to them, which caused much sorrow for the Nephites who stayed in the land.

There was also much sorrow among the Lamanites, because many of their children grew up and became independent, and were led away by some Zoramites, through their lies and flattering words, to join the Gadianton robbers.
In this way, the Lamanites also suffered and started to lose their faith and righteousness because of the wickedness of the rising generation.

The ninety-fifth year also passed, and the people began to forget the signs and wonders they had heard about, and they became less and less amazed by any sign or wonder from heaven, so much that their hearts became hard, their minds became blind, and they began to disbelieve everything they had heard and seen—

They imagined some vain thing in their hearts, thinking it was done by men and by the power of the devil to mislead and deceive the people; and in this way, Satan gained control of their hearts again, blinding them and leading them to believe that the doctrine of Christ was foolish and worthless.

The people started to grow stronger in wickedness and abominations, and they didn't believe there would be any more signs or wonders. Satan went around leading people's hearts astray, tempting them and causing them to commit great wickedness in the land.
And so the ninety-sixth year passed, then the ninety-seventh year, the ninety-eighth year, and the ninety-ninth year.
And one hundred years had passed since the days of Mosiah, who was king over the people of the Nephites.
And six hundred and nine years had passed since Lehi left Jerusalem.
Nine years had passed since the sign was given, which the prophets had spoken about, that Christ would come into the world.
The Nephites started counting their years from the time the sign was given, or from the coming of Christ, so nine years had passed.
Nephi, who was the father of Nephi and was responsible for the records, did not return to the land of Zarahemla and could not be found anywhere in the land.
The people continued to live in wickedness, despite all the preaching and prophesying sent among them. The tenth year ended this way, and the eleventh year also passed in iniquity.

In the thirteenth year, wars and conflicts began throughout all the land because the Gadianton robbers had become so numerous. They killed many people, destroyed many cities, and spread so much death and destruction that it became necessary for all the people, both Nephites and Lamanites, to take up arms against them.

All the Lamanites who had become converted to the Lord joined with their brothers, the Nephites, and were forced, for the safety of their lives, their women, and their children, to take up arms against the Gadianton robbers, and also to defend their rights, the privileges of their church and worship, and their freedom and liberty.
Before the thirteenth year ended, the Nephites were threatened with complete destruction because this war had become extremely severe.
The Lamanites who had joined with the Nephites were counted as Nephites.
Their curse was removed, and their skin became as white as the Nephites'.
Their young men and their daughters became extremely fair, and they were counted among the Nephites and were called Nephites. That is how the thirteenth year ended.

At the beginning of the fourteenth year, the war between the robbers and the people of Nephi continued and became extremely intense; however, the people of Nephi gained some advantage over the robbers, so much that they drove them out of their lands and into the mountains and their secret places.

The fourteenth year ended. In the fifteenth year, the Gadianton robbers came against the people of Nephi. Because of the wickedness, arguments, and divisions among the people of Nephi, the Gadianton robbers gained many advantages over them.
That was the end of the fifteenth year, and the people were experiencing many troubles. The threat of destruction hung over them, and they were about to be struck down because of their wickedness.
In the sixteenth year after Christ's coming, Lachoneus, the governor of the land, received a letter from the leader and governor of the band of robbers. These were the words written in the letter:

Lachoneus, most noble and chief governor of the land, I am writing this letter to you and give you very great praise because of your firmness, and also the firmness of your people, in maintaining what you believe to be your rights and liberty. You stand strong, as if you were supported by the hand of a god, in defending your liberty, your property, and your country, or what you call your country.

It seems a pity to me, most noble Lachoneus, that you would be so foolish and vain as to think you can stand against so many brave men under my command, who are now armed and waiting anxiously for the order to go down against the Nephites and destroy them.

I know they have an unconquerable spirit, since I've seen it in battle, and I know they have a lasting hatred toward you because of all the wrongs you've done to them. So if they come against you, they will completely destroy you.
I have written this letter and sealed it with my own hand, because I care about your well-being, respect your commitment to what you believe is right, and admire your noble spirit in battle.
So I am writing to you, asking that you give up your cities, your lands, and your possessions to my people, instead of having them attack you with the sword and bring destruction upon you.

In other words, surrender yourselves to us, join with us, learn about our secret works, and become our brothers so you can be like us—not our slaves, but our brothers and partners in all that we have.

I swear to you, if you do this, you will not be destroyed. But if you do not do this, I swear to you that next month I will command my armies to come against you, and they will not hold back or show mercy, but will kill you and use the sword against you until you are wiped out.
I am Giddianhi, the governor of the secret society of Gadianton. I know that this society and its works are good. They are ancient and have been handed down to us.

I am writing this letter to you, Lachoneus, and I hope you will surrender your lands and possessions without any bloodshed, so that my people can regain their rights and government. They left you because you wickedly kept their rights of government from them, and if you do not do this, I will avenge their wrongs. I am Giddianhi.

When Lachoneus received this letter, he was extremely astonished because of Giddianhi's boldness in demanding possession of the land of the Nephites, and also for threatening the people and seeking revenge for those who had not been wronged, except that they had wronged themselves by joining those wicked and evil robbers.

Lachoneus, the governor, was a just man and was not intimidated by the demands and threats of a robber. He did not listen to the letter from Giddianhi, the leader of the robbers, but instead had his people pray to the Lord for strength for when the robbers would come against them.
He sent a proclamation to all the people, telling them to gather their women, children, flocks, herds, and all their possessions, except for their land, into one place.

He ordered that strong fortifications be built around them, making them extremely secure. He also stationed armies made up of both Nephites and Lamanites—everyone counted among the Nephites—as guards all around, to watch over and protect them from the robbers day and night.
He said to them, "As the Lord lives, unless you repent of all your sins and pray to the Lord, you will not be delivered from the hands of those Gadianton robbers."
The words and prophecies of Lachoneus were so great and amazing that they caused fear among all the people, and everyone put in their best effort to follow what Lachoneus told them to do.
Lachoneus appointed chief captains over all the armies of the Nephites to lead them when the robbers came down out of the wilderness to attack them.
The highest-ranking leader and chief commander of the Nephite armies was appointed, and his name was Gidgiddoni.

The Nephites usually chose someone with the spirit of revelation and prophecy to be their chief captain, except during times of wickedness. So Gidgiddoni was a great prophet among them, as was the chief judge.
The people said to Gidgiddoni, "Pray to the Lord, and let's go up into the mountains and the wilderness so we can attack the robbers and destroy them in their own lands."

But Gidgiddoni said to them, "The Lord forbid it; if we go up against them, the Lord will deliver us into their hands. So we will prepare ourselves in the center of our lands, gather all our armies together, and we will not go against them. Instead, we will wait until they come against us. As surely as the Lord lives, if we do this, he will deliver them into our hands."

In the seventeenth year, at the end of the year, Lachoneus's proclamation had gone out across the entire land. The people took their horses, chariots, cattle, all their flocks and herds, their grain, and all their possessions, and marched in groups of thousands and tens of thousands until everyone had gathered at the appointed place to defend themselves against their enemies.
The land that was chosen was the land of Zarahemla, along with the land between Zarahemla and Bountiful, up to the line that separates Bountiful from Desolation.

There were many thousands of people called Nephites who gathered together in this land. Lachoneus made sure they gathered in the land to the south because there was a great curse on the land to the north.

They fortified themselves against their enemies and lived together in one land, united as one people. They were afraid because of the words Lachoneus had spoken, so they repented of all their sins and prayed to the Lord their God, asking Him to deliver them when their enemies came to fight against them.

They were extremely sorrowful because of their enemies. Gidgiddoni directed them to make all kinds of weapons of war, and to equip themselves with armor, shields, and bucklers, according to his instructions.

At the end of the eighteenth year, the armies of robbers prepared for battle and started coming down and moving out from the hills, mountains, wilderness, their strongholds, and secret places. They began to take possession of the lands in both the south and the north, as well as all the lands and cities that the Nephites had deserted and left desolate.
There were no wild animals or game in the lands abandoned by the Nephites, and the robbers could only find game in the wilderness.

The robbers could only survive in the wilderness because they lacked food; the Nephites had left their lands empty, gathered their flocks, herds, and all their possessions, and were living together in one group.

So the robbers had no way to steal or get food unless they fought the Nephites in open battle. The Nephites were all gathered together in one group, there were many of them, and they had stored up food, horses, cattle, and all kinds of flocks so they could survive for seven years. During that time, they hoped to destroy the robbers from the land. That is how the eighteenth year ended.
In the nineteenth year, Giddianhi realized it was necessary to go to battle against the Nephites, because there was no way his people could survive except by plundering, robbing, and murdering.

They didn't dare spread out across the land to plant grain, because they were afraid the Nephites would attack and kill them. So Giddianhi commanded his armies to go to battle against the Nephites that year.

They came up to battle in the sixth month, and it was a great and terrible day when they did. They were dressed like robbers, with a lambskin around their waists, dyed in blood. Their heads were shaved, and they wore headplates. The armies of Giddianhi looked great and terrible because of their armor and because they were dyed in blood.
When the Nephite armies saw the appearance of Giddianhi's army, they all fell to the ground and cried out to the Lord their God, asking Him to spare them and deliver them from their enemies.
When the armies of Giddianhi saw this, they began to shout loudly with joy, because they thought the Nephites had fallen in fear because of the terror of their armies.

But they were disappointed in this, because the Nephites did not fear them; instead, they feared their God and prayed to him for protection. So when Giddianhi's armies rushed at them, they were ready to face them. With the Lord's strength, they stood against them.

The battle began in the sixth month, and it was a great and terrible battle. The slaughter was so great and terrible that there had never been such a slaughter among all the people of Lehi since he left Jerusalem.
Despite the threats and oaths that Giddianhi had made, the Nephites defeated them so thoroughly that they retreated from before them.

Gidgiddoni commanded his armies to pursue them as far as the borders of the wilderness and not to spare anyone who fell into their hands along the way. So they pursued them and killed them to the borders of the wilderness, until they had fulfilled Gidgiddoni's command.
Giddianhi, who had stood and fought bravely, was chased as he tried to escape. Because he was exhausted from so much fighting, he was caught and killed. That was the end of Giddianhi the robber.
The armies of the Nephites returned to their place of security. The nineteenth year passed, and the robbers did not come again to battle, nor did they come again in the twentieth year.

In the twenty-first year, they didn't come to fight, but instead surrounded the people of Nephi on all sides to lay siege. They thought that if they cut the people of Nephi off from their lands and trapped them on every side, taking away all their outside resources, they could force them to surrender.
They had chosen another leader for themselves, named Zemnarihah. It was Zemnarihah who caused this siege to happen.
This was an advantage for the Nephites, because it was impossible for the robbers to lay siege long enough to have any effect on them, due to the large amount of provisions the Nephites had stored.
Because the robbers had very little food—for they had nothing except the meat they got in the wilderness for their survival—
The wild game became scarce in the wilderness, so much that the robbers were about to die from hunger.
The Nephites kept marching out day and night, attacking their armies and defeating them by the thousands and tens of thousands.
So the people of Zemnarihah wanted to abandon their plan because of the great destruction that came upon them both night and day.
Zemnarihah commanded his people to withdraw from the siege and march into the farthest parts of the land to the north.

Gidgiddoni, aware of their plan and knowing their weakness from lack of food and the heavy losses they had suffered, sent out his armies at night, blocked their escape route, and positioned his forces to cut off their retreat.
They did this during the night and marched past the robbers, so that the next day, when the robbers started their march, they were met by the Nephite armies both in front of them and behind them.
The robbers who were in the south were also defeated in their hiding places. All these things happened because Gidgiddoni commanded it.
Many thousands surrendered themselves as prisoners to the Nephites, and the rest were killed.
Their leader, Zemnarihah, was captured and hanged on a tree, even at the top of it, until he died. After he was dead, they cut the tree down to the ground and shouted with a loud voice, saying:
May the Lord keep his people righteous and pure in heart, so they can bring down anyone who tries to kill them for power and secret plots, just as this man has been brought down.

They rejoiced and shouted together with one voice, saying, "May the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob protect this people in righteousness as long as they call on the name of their God for protection."
They all broke out together in singing and praising their God for the great thing he had done for them by saving them from falling into the hands of their enemies.
They cried out, "Hosanna to the Most High God." They shouted, "Blessed is the name of the Lord God Almighty, the Most High God."

Their hearts were filled with so much joy that they wept many tears because of God's great goodness in saving them from their enemies; and they knew it was because of their repentance and humility that they had been saved from everlasting destruction.
At that time, there was not a single person among all the Nephites who doubted the words of all the holy prophets who had spoken, because they knew that those words had to be fulfilled.

They knew it was necessary that Christ had come because of the many signs that had been given, just as the prophets had said. Because of the things that had already happened, they knew that everything would happen just as it had been spoken.
So they gave up all their sins, their abominations, and their immoral behaviors, and served God with complete diligence day and night.

When they had captured all the robbers, so that none escaped except those who were killed, they put their prisoners in prison and had the word of God preached to them. Anyone who repented of their sins and made a covenant not to murder anymore was set free.
But everyone who didn't make a covenant and still kept those secret murders in their hearts, and anyone found threatening their brothers, was judged and punished according to the law.
In this way, they ended all those wicked, secret, and abominable groups, in which there had been so much evil and so many murders committed.
In this way, the twenty-second year passed, then the twenty-third, the twenty-fourth, and the twenty-fifth; so twenty-five years had passed.

Many things happened that, to some people, would seem great and marvelous; however, not all of them can be written in this book. In fact, this book can't even contain a hundredth part of what took place among so many people over twenty-five years.
There are records that contain all the events of this people, and Nephi gave a shorter but accurate account.
So I have made my record of these things based on the record of Nephi, which was engraved on the plates called the plates of Nephi.
I am making this record on plates that I have made with my own hands.
My name is Mormon, named after the land of Mormon, where Alma established the church among the people—the first church created among them after their transgression.
I am a disciple of Jesus Christ, the Son of God. I have been called by him to share his word with his people, so they can have everlasting life.

And it has become necessary for me, according to the will of God, that the prayers of those who have passed on, who were the holy ones, should be fulfilled according to their faith, to make a record of these things which have been done—
A small record of what has happened from the time Lehi left Jerusalem up to the present time.
So I am making my record from the accounts given by those who came before me, up until the beginning of my time.
And now I am making a record of the things I have seen with my own eyes.
I know the record I am making is accurate and true; however, there are many things that, because of our language, we are not able to write.
I will now finish what I have to say about myself and continue by giving my account of the things that have happened before me.

I am Mormon, a pure descendant of Lehi. I have reason to bless my God and my Savior Jesus Christ, because he brought our ancestors out of the land of Jerusalem (and no one knew it except him and those he brought out of that land), and because he has given me and my people so much knowledge for the salvation of our souls.
Surely he has blessed the house of Jacob and has been merciful to the descendants of Joseph.
As long as the children of Lehi have kept his commandments, he has blessed them and helped them prosper according to his word.
He will surely bring a remnant of the descendants of Joseph to know the Lord their God again.
As surely as the Lord lives, he will gather from the four corners of the earth all the remnant of the descendants of Jacob, who are scattered across the entire earth.

And just as he has made a covenant with all the house of Jacob, that covenant will be fulfilled in his own due time, restoring the entire house of Jacob to the knowledge of the covenant he made with them.

Then they will know their Redeemer, who is Jesus Christ, the Son of God; and they will be gathered in from the four corners of the earth to their own lands, from where they have been dispersed. As the Lord lives, so it will be. Amen.
The Nephite people all returned to their own lands in the twenty-sixth year, each person with his family, his flocks and herds, his horses and cattle, and everything that belonged to them.

They had not used up all their provisions, so they took with them everything they hadn't consumed—all their grain of every kind, their gold, their silver, and all their precious things—and returned to their own lands and possessions, both in the north and in the south, in the land northward and the land southward.

They gave land to those robbers who had promised to keep the peace and wanted to stay Lamanites, giving them enough according to their numbers so they could support themselves by their own work. In this way, they established peace throughout the land.
They began to prosper and grow strong again. The twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh years passed, and there was great order in the land. They had established their laws based on fairness and justice.
There was nothing anywhere in the land to stop the people from continually prospering, unless they fell into sin.
Gidgiddoni, the judge Lachoneus, and the appointed leaders established this great peace in the land.
Many new cities were built, and many old cities were repaired.
Many highways were built, and many roads were made, connecting city to city, land to land, and place to place.
The twenty-eighth year ended, and the people had continual peace.
In the twenty-ninth year, some disagreements began among the people, and some became proud and boastful because of their extremely great riches, even leading to severe persecutions.
There were many merchants in the land, as well as many lawyers and many officers.

The people started to separate into classes based on their wealth and their opportunities for education. Some were uneducated because they were poor, while others received a great education because they were rich.

Some became prideful, while others were extremely humble. Some responded to insults with more insults, while others endured insults, persecution, and all kinds of afflictions without retaliating, but remained humble and repentant before God.

This created a great inequality throughout the land, so much that the church began to break apart. In the thirtieth year, the church was broken up everywhere except among a few of the Lamanites who had converted to the true faith. They refused to leave it, remaining firm, steadfast, and immovable, and were willing with all diligence to keep the commandments of the Lord.

The reason for the people's wickedness was that Satan had great power, stirring them up to do all kinds of evil and filling them with pride, tempting them to seek power, authority, riches, and the vain things of the world.
In this way, Satan led the hearts of the people to commit all kinds of wickedness, so they had only enjoyed peace for a few years.

At the beginning of the thirtieth year, the people had been under the influence of the devil for a long time, led by his temptations wherever he wanted and doing whatever evil he wanted them to do. At the start of this thirtieth year, they were in a state of terrible wickedness.
They did not sin out of ignorance, because they knew God's will for them, since it had been taught to them. So they deliberately rebelled against God.
At that time, Lachoneus, the son of Lachoneus, was leading the people, because he took his father's place and governed them that year.

Men inspired by heaven were sent out and stood among the people throughout the land, preaching and boldly testifying about the sins and wrongdoings of the people. They testified to them about the redemption the Lord would bring to his people—that is, the resurrection of Christ—and they boldly testified of his death and sufferings.

Many of the people were extremely angry at those who testified of these things, and those who were angry were mainly the chief judges, former high priests, and lawyers. In fact, all the lawyers were angry with those who testified of these things.
No lawyer, judge, or high priest had the authority to sentence anyone to death unless the governor of the land signed the condemnation.

Many people testified boldly about things concerning Christ, and the judges secretly put them to death, so that the governor of the land didn't learn about their deaths until after they had already been killed.
This was against the laws of the land, because no one could be put to death unless they had authority from the governor.
A complaint was brought to the governor of the land in Zarahemla against the judges who had sentenced the prophets of the Lord to death, not according to the law.
They were taken and brought before the judge to be judged for the crime they had committed, according to the law given by the people.
Those judges had many friends and relatives, and nearly all the lawyers and high priests gathered together and united with the families of the judges who were to be tried according to the law.
They entered into a covenant with each other, the same covenant that was made by people in the past, which was given and carried out by the devil, to unite against all righteousness.
So they joined together against the people of the Lord, making a covenant to destroy them and to rescue those guilty of murder from justice, which was about to be carried out according to the law.

They openly defied the law and the rights of their country, and they made a pact with each other to kill the governor and set up a king over the land, so that the land would no longer be free but would be ruled by kings.
I will show you that they did not establish a king over the land; but in this same year, the thirtieth year, they destroyed the judgment seat and murdered the chief judge of the land.
The people turned against each other and separated into tribes, each person joining with their family, relatives, and friends. In this way, they destroyed the government of the land.
Each tribe appointed a chief or leader, and in this way they became tribes with their own leaders.
There was no one among them who didn't have a large family, many relatives, and friends; so their tribes grew very large.
All of this happened, and there were no wars yet among them; all this wickedness came upon the people because they gave themselves over to the power of Satan.
The laws of the government were destroyed because of the secret alliance among the friends and relatives of those who killed the prophets.
They caused a great conflict in the land, so much so that almost all of the more righteous people had become wicked; there were only a few righteous people left among them.
So less than six years had passed since most of the people had turned away from their righteousness, like a dog returning to its vomit or a pig going back to wallow in the mud.
This secret combination, which had brought such great wickedness upon the people, gathered themselves together and chose a man named Jacob as their leader.
They called him their king, so he became the king over this wicked group. He was one of the main leaders who had spoken out against the prophets who testified of Jesus.

They weren't as numerous as the tribes of the people, who were united together except that their leaders set up their own laws, each according to his tribe. Even though they were enemies and not a righteous people, they were united in their hatred of those who had made a covenant to destroy the government.

Jacob saw that their enemies outnumbered them, and since he was the leader of the group, he told his people to flee to the northernmost part of the land and build a kingdom there. He convinced them that many others would join them, and that they would become strong enough to fight against the other tribes. They did as he commanded.
Their march was so quick that no one could stop them until they were out of reach of the people. That is how the thirtieth year ended, and that is how things stood for the people of Nephi.

In the thirty-first year, they divided into tribes, each person joining with their family, relatives, and friends. They agreed not to go to war with each other, but they weren't united in their laws or their governments, since each group followed the decisions of their own leaders and chiefs. They did set up very strict laws to prevent one tribe from wronging another, so there was some peace in the land. However, their hearts had turned away from the Lord their God, and they stoned the prophets and cast them out from among them.

Nephi had been visited by angels and also heard the voice of the Lord. He had seen angels and was an eyewitness. He had been given power to understand the ministry of Christ, and he was also an eyewitness to how quickly the people returned from righteousness to wickedness and abominations.

Grieved by the hardness of their hearts and the blindness of their minds, he went among them that same year and began to boldly testify about repentance and forgiveness of sins through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ.

He taught them many things, but not everything he said can be written, and only part of it wouldn't be enough, so those things aren't included in this book. Nephi taught with power and great authority.

They were angry with him because he had greater power than they did. It was not possible for them to disbelieve his words, because his faith in the Lord Jesus Christ was so great that angels ministered to him every day.
In the name of Jesus, he cast out devils and unclean spirits, and he even raised his brother from the dead after his brother had been stoned and killed by the people.
The people saw it and witnessed it, and they were angry with him because of his power. He also performed many more miracles in front of the people in the name of Jesus.

The thirty-first year passed, and only a few people were converted to the Lord. But those who were converted clearly showed to others that they had been visited by the power and Spirit of God, which is in Jesus Christ, whom they believed in.

All those who had devils cast out of them and were healed of their sicknesses and infirmities clearly showed the people that they had been changed by the Spirit of God and had been healed; they also showed signs and performed some miracles among the people.
