Anyone who repents and is baptized in my name will be filled; and if he endures to the end, I will hold him guiltless before my Father on the day when I stand to judge the world.
Anyone who does not endure to the end will be cut down and cast into the fire, from which they can never return, because of the justice of the Father.
This is the word he has given to the children of men. For this reason, he keeps the promises he has made, and he does not lie, but fulfills all his words.

No unclean thing can enter his kingdom; nothing can enter his rest except those who have washed their garments in my blood because of their faith, their repentance of all their sins, and their faithfulness to the end.

This is the commandment: Repent, all you ends of the earth, and come to me and be baptized in my name, so you can be sanctified by receiving the Holy Ghost, so you can stand spotless before me at the last day.
Truly, I tell you, this is my gospel; and you know what you must do in my church, because the works you have seen me do, you should also do; you should do exactly what you have seen me do.
So if you do these things, you are blessed, because you will be lifted up at the last day.
Write the things you have seen and heard, except for those which are forbidden.
Write the works of this people that will happen, just as has been written about what has already happened.
From the books that have been written, and those that will be written, this people will be judged, because through them their works will be made known to others.
All things are written by the Father; so the world will be judged out of the books that are written.
You will be judges of this people, according to the judgment I give you, which will be just. So, what kind of people should you be? Truly, I tell you, you should be even as I am.
Now I am going to the Father. I tell you the truth, whatever you ask the Father in my name will be given to you.
So ask, and you will receive; knock, and it will be opened to you. Whoever asks, receives; and to the one who knocks, it will be opened.
My joy is full because of you and also this generation. Even the Father rejoices, and all the holy angels, because of you and this generation, for none of them are lost.
I want you to understand that I'm talking about those who are alive in this generation; none of them are lost, and in them I have a fulness of joy.

I am saddened because of the fourth generation from this one, for they will be led away captive by him just like the son of perdition was. They will sell me for silver and gold, and for things that moths destroy and thieves can break in and steal. On that day, I will visit them by turning their own actions back on themselves.

When Jesus finished speaking, he said to his disciples: Enter through the narrow gate, because the gate is narrow and the way is difficult that leads to life, and few people find it. But the gate is wide and the way is broad that leads to death, and many people travel that path, until night comes, when no one can work.
After Jesus finished speaking, he spoke to his disciples one by one and asked them, "What do you want from me after I return to the Father?"

They all spoke, except for three, saying: We want that after we have lived out our lives, our ministry, to which you have called us, may come to an end, so that we can quickly come to you in your kingdom.
He said to them, "You are blessed because you have asked me for this. After you are seventy-two years old, you will come to me in my kingdom, and you will find rest with me."
After he spoke to them, he turned to the three and said to them, "What do you want me to do for you when I go to the Father?"
They were sad in their hearts because they didn't dare to tell him what they wanted.
He said to them, "I know your thoughts, and you have desired the same thing that John, my beloved, who was with me in my ministry before I was lifted up by the Jews, desired from me."

You are even more blessed, because you will never experience death; instead, you will live to witness everything the Father does for the children of men, until all things are fulfilled according to the Father's will, when I come in my glory with the powers of heaven.
You will never experience the pains of death; when I come in my glory, you will be changed in an instant from mortality to immortality, and then you will be blessed in the kingdom of my Father.

You will not experience pain while you live in the flesh, nor sorrow except for the sins of the world. I will do all this because of what you have asked of me, for you have desired to bring the souls of people to me as long as the world exists.

Because of this, you will have a fullness of joy, and you will sit down in my Father's kingdom. Your joy will be complete, just as the Father has given me a fullness of joy. You will be even as I am, and I am even as the Father; and the Father and I are one.
The Holy Ghost testifies of the Father and me, and the Father gives the Holy Ghost to the children of men because of me.
When Jesus finished speaking, he touched each of them with his finger except for the three who were to remain, and then he left.
The heavens were opened, and they were taken up into heaven, where they saw and heard things that cannot be described.
They were forbidden to speak, and they were not given the power to tell the things they saw and heard.

They couldn't tell whether they were in their bodies or out of them, because it felt to them like a transformation, as if they had been changed from their physical bodies into an immortal state so they could see the things of God.
They again ministered on the earth; however, they did not share the things they had heard and seen, because of the commandment given to them in heaven.
And now, from the day they were changed, I don't know whether they were mortal or immortal;

But this much I know, according to the record that has been given—they went out across the land and ministered to all the people, bringing as many as would believe in their preaching into the church; baptizing them, and everyone who was baptized received the Holy Ghost.
They were thrown into prison by people who weren't part of the church, but the prisons couldn't hold them because they were torn apart.

They were thrown down into the earth, but they struck the earth with the word of God, and by His power they were delivered from the depths of the earth. Because of this, no one could dig pits deep enough to hold them.
They were thrown into a furnace three times and were not harmed.
They were thrown into a den of wild beasts twice, and they played with the animals like a child with a young lamb, and were not harmed.

They went among all the people of Nephi and preached the gospel of Christ to everyone in the land. The people were converted to the Lord and joined the church of Christ, and the people of that generation were blessed, just as Jesus had promised.
Now I, Mormon, will stop talking about these things for now.
I was about to write the names of those who would never die, but the Lord forbade me; so I am not writing them, because they are hidden from the world.
I have seen them, and they have served me.
They will be among the Gentiles, and the Gentiles will not know them.
They will also be among the Jews, and the Jews will not recognize them.

When the Lord, in his wisdom, decides that they should minister to all the scattered tribes of Israel, and to all nations, families, languages, and people, and bring many souls to Jesus from among them, their desire will be fulfilled because of the convincing power of God that is in them.
They are like the angels of God, and if they pray to the Father in the name of Jesus, they can show themselves to anyone they choose.
So, great and marvelous works will be done by them before the important day when everyone must stand before the judgment seat of Christ.
Even among the Gentiles, they will do a great and marvelous work before the day of judgment.
If you had all the scriptures that tell about all the marvelous works of Christ, you would know, according to the words of Christ, that these things must definitely happen.

Woe to anyone who will not listen to the words of Jesus, or to those he has chosen and sent among them. Whoever does not accept the words of Jesus and the words of those he has sent does not accept him, and therefore he will not receive them at the last day.
It would be better for them if they had never been born. Do you think you can escape the justice of an offended God, who has been trampled under the feet of men so that salvation could come?
Now, as I was speaking about those whom the Lord has chosen, the three who were taken up into heaven, I did not know whether they were changed from mortality to immortality—
Since I wrote, I have asked the Lord, and he has shown me that there must be a change made to their bodies, or else they would have to experience death.
So, in order for them not to experience death, their bodies were changed so they wouldn't feel pain or sorrow except for the sins of the world.

This change was not the same as the one that will happen at the last day, but there was a change made in them so that Satan had no power over them and could not tempt them. They were made holy in the flesh, so they were sanctified and the powers of the earth could not hold them.

They were to remain in this state until the judgment day of Christ; and on that day they would receive a greater change and be received into the kingdom of the Father, never to leave again, but to live forever in the heavens.

Now I tell you, when the Lord, in his wisdom, decides that these words will go to the Gentiles as he promised, then you will know that the covenant the Father made with the children of Israel about restoring them to their lands of inheritance is already starting to be fulfilled.
You can know that the words of the Lord, spoken by the holy prophets, will all be fulfilled; and you should not say that the Lord is delaying his coming to the children of Israel.
You don't need to think in your hearts that the words that have been spoken are useless, because the Lord will remember his covenant that he has made with his people of the house of Israel.

When you see these words coming among you, you don't need to reject the works of the Lord anymore, for the sword of his justice is in his right hand; and on that day, if you reject his works, he will make sure it quickly comes upon you.
Woe to anyone who mocks the works of the Lord; woe to anyone who denies Christ and his works!
Woe to anyone who denies the revelations of the Lord and says that the Lord no longer works by revelation, prophecy, gifts, tongues, healings, or by the power of the Holy Ghost!

And sorrow awaits anyone who, for personal gain, claims in that day that Jesus Christ cannot perform miracles; because anyone who does this will become like the son of perdition, for whom there was no mercy, according to the word of Christ.
You don't need to hiss, reject, or mock the Jews or any of the remnant of the house of Israel anymore, because the Lord remembers his covenant with them and he will do for them what he has promised.
So you shouldn't think that you can change the Lord's will, or prevent Him from carrying out judgment to fulfill the covenant He has made with the house of Israel.
Listen, you Gentiles, and hear the words of Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God, which he has commanded me to speak about you, for he commands me to write, saying:

Turn, all you Gentiles, from your wicked ways; repent of your evil actions, your lies and deceptions, your sexual immorality, your secret abominations, your idolatries, your murders, your priestcrafts, your envy, your conflicts, and from all your wickedness and abominations. Come to me and be baptized in my name, so you can receive forgiveness of your sins and be filled with the Holy Ghost, so you may be counted among my people who are of the house of Israel.

The thirty-fourth year passed, and then the thirty-fifth. The disciples of Jesus established the church of Christ throughout all the surrounding lands. Everyone who came to them, truly repented of their sins, and was baptized in the name of Jesus also received the Holy Ghost.

In the thirty-sixth year, all the people throughout the land, both Nephites and Lamanites, were converted to the Lord. There were no arguments or disputes among them, and everyone treated each other fairly.
They shared everything in common, so there were no rich or poor, no slaves or free people; everyone was free and shared in the heavenly gift.
The thirty-seventh year also passed, and there was still peace in the land.

The disciples of Jesus performed great and amazing works—they healed the sick, raised the dead, made the lame walk, gave sight to the blind, and helped the deaf hear. They did all kinds of miracles among the people, and they did nothing miraculous except in the name of Jesus.

The thirty-eighth year passed, as did the thirty-ninth, the forty-first, and the forty-second, until forty-nine years had passed, and then the fifty-first and fifty-second years, until fifty-nine years had passed.
The Lord blessed them greatly in the land, so much that they rebuilt cities where cities had been burned.
They even rebuilt the great city of Zarahemla.
Many cities had sunk, and water had come up in their place, so these cities could not be restored.
The people of Nephi grew strong and multiplied very quickly, becoming an exceptionally beautiful and happy people.
They got married and gave their children in marriage, and they were blessed according to the many promises the Lord had made to them.

They no longer followed the rituals and ordinances of the law of Moses; instead, they lived according to the commandments they had received from their Lord and their God, continuing in fasting and prayer, and meeting together often to pray and to hear the word of the Lord.
There was no contention among all the people throughout the land, and powerful miracles were performed by the disciples of Jesus.

The seventy-first year passed, then the seventy-second, and so on until the seventy-ninth year had passed. A hundred years had gone by, and all the disciples of Jesus whom he had chosen had gone to the paradise of God, except for the three who were to remain. Other disciples were ordained in their place, and many people of that generation had also passed away.
There was no contention in the land because the love of God lived in the hearts of the people.

There was no envy, no conflict, no chaos, no sexual immorality, no lying, no murder, or any kind of wickedness; and there could not have been a happier people among all those created by the hand of God.
There were no robbers or murderers, and there were no Lamanites or any other -ites; instead, they were united as the children of Christ and heirs to the kingdom of God.

They were truly blessed, for the Lord blessed everything they did. They were blessed and prospered until one hundred and ten years had passed, and the first generation since Christ had passed away, and there was no contention anywhere in the land.
Nephi, who kept this last record on the plates of Nephi, died, and his son Amos took over and kept the record on the plates of Nephi as well.

He kept it for eighty-four years, and there was still peace in the land, except for a small group of people who had left the church and taken on the name of Lamanites. So, there began to be Lamanites again in the land.

Amos died as well, in the one hundred and ninety-fourth year after Christ's coming, and his son Amos took over keeping the record. He also kept it on the plates of Nephi, and it was written in the book of Nephi, which is this book.
Two hundred years went by, and the second generation had all passed away except for a few.
Now I, Mormon, want you to know that the people had multiplied so much that they were spread across the entire land, and they had become extremely rich because of their prosperity in Christ.
Now, in the two hundred and first year, some people among them began to be prideful, wearing expensive clothing, all kinds of fine pearls, and the luxurious things of the world.
From that time on, they no longer shared their goods and possessions in common.
They started dividing into classes, building churches for themselves to make money, and began to deny the true church of Christ.

When two hundred and ten years had passed, there were many churches in the land. Many churches claimed to know Christ, but they denied much of his gospel, allowing all kinds of wickedness and giving sacred things to those who had been forbidden to receive them because of unworthiness.
This church grew rapidly because of wickedness and because Satan gained control over their hearts.

There was another church that denied Christ, and they persecuted the true church of Christ because of their humility and their belief in Christ. They also looked down on them because of the many miracles that happened among them.

So they used their power and authority against the disciples of Jesus who stayed with them, and they threw them into prison; but by the power of God's word within them, the prisons were split in two, and the disciples went out performing great miracles among the people.
Despite all these miracles, the people hardened their hearts and tried to kill them, just as the Jews in Jerusalem tried to kill Jesus, as he had said.
They threw them into furnaces of fire, and they came out unharmed.
They also threw them into dens of wild beasts, and they played with the wild beasts just like a child would with a lamb; and they came out from among them without being harmed.

However, the people hardened their hearts, because many priests and false prophets led them to establish many churches and commit all kinds of sin. They attacked the followers of Jesus, but the followers of Jesus did not fight back. Over the years, they declined in faith and became more wicked, until two hundred and thirty years had passed.
In the two hundred and thirty-first year, there was a great division among the people.
In that year, a group of people called the Nephites arose, and they were true believers in Christ. Among them were those whom the Lamanites called Jacobites, Josephites, and Zoramites.
So the true believers in Christ, and the true worshipers of Christ—including the three disciples of Jesus who were to remain—were called Nephites, Jacobites, Josephites, and Zoramites.

Those who rejected the gospel were called Lamanites, Lemuelites, and Ishmaelites. They did not dwindle in unbelief, but instead willfully rebelled against the gospel of Christ. They taught their children not to believe, just as their ancestors had dwindled from the beginning.

It was because of the wickedness and abominations of their fathers, just like it was in the beginning. They were taught to hate the children of God, just as the Lamanites were taught to hate the children of Nephi from the start.
Two hundred and forty-four years passed, and this was the state of the people. The more wicked part of the people grew stronger and became much more numerous than the people of God.
They continued to build churches for themselves and decorated them with all kinds of precious things. In this way, two hundred and fifty years passed, and then two hundred and sixty years.
The wicked part of the people began once more to establish the secret oaths and combinations of Gadianton.
The people who were called the people of Nephi also began to be proud in their hearts because of their great riches, and became vain like their brothers, the Lamanites.
From this time, the disciples began to feel sorrow for the sins of the world.
After three hundred years had passed, both the Nephites and the Lamanites had become extremely wicked, just like each other.
The Gadianton robbers spread across the entire land, and no one was righteous except for the disciples of Jesus. They stored up gold and silver in abundance and traded in all kinds of goods.
After three hundred and five years had passed, and the people were still living in wickedness, Amos died, and his brother Ammaron took over keeping the record.

When three hundred and twenty years had passed, Ammaron, being directed by the Holy Ghost, hid the sacred records—all the sacred records that had been handed down from generation to generation—until the three hundred and twentieth year from the coming of Christ.
He hid them for the Lord so they could come again to the remnant of the house of Jacob, according to the prophecies and promises of the Lord. This is the end of the record of Ammaron.
I, Mormon, am writing down the things I have seen and heard, and I call it the Book of Mormon.

Around the time that Ammaron hid the records for the Lord, he came to me—I was about ten years old and had started to learn in the way of my people—and Ammaron said to me, "I see that you are a serious child and quick to notice things."

When you are about twenty-four years old, I want you to remember the things you have observed about this people. When you reach that age, go to the land of Antum, to a hill called Shim. There I have placed before the Lord all the sacred engravings about this people.
You will take the plates of Nephi for yourself, and you will leave the rest where they are. You will engrave on the plates of Nephi everything you have observed about this people.
I, Mormon, a descendant of Nephi, and my father's name was Mormon, remembered the things Ammaron commanded me.
When I was eleven years old, my father took me to the land southward, to the land of Zarahemla.
The entire land was covered with buildings, and the people were almost as numerous as the sand of the sea.
In this year, a war began between the Nephites—which included the Nephites, Jacobites, Josephites, and Zoramites—and the Lamanites, Lemuelites, and Ishmaelites.
The Lamanites, the Lemuelites, and the Ishmaelites were all called Lamanites, so there were two groups: the Nephites and the Lamanites.
The war started among them near the borders of Zarahemla, by the waters of Sidon.
The Nephites gathered together a great number of men, exceeding thirty thousand. That same year, they had several battles in which the Nephites defeated the Lamanites and killed many of them.
The Lamanites abandoned their plans, and peace settled in the land; peace lasted for about four years, and there was no bloodshed.
Wickedness spread throughout the entire land, so the Lord took away his beloved disciples, and miracles and healings stopped because of the people's sin.
There were no gifts from the Lord, and the Holy Ghost did not come upon anyone because of their wickedness and unbelief.
When I was fifteen years old and somewhat serious-minded, the Lord visited me, and I experienced and understood the goodness of Jesus.

I tried to preach to the people, but my mouth was shut and I was forbidden to preach to them, because they had willfully rebelled against God. The beloved disciples were taken out of the land because of the people's sin.
I stayed among them, but I was not allowed to preach to them because their hearts were so hard. Because of the hardness of their hearts, the land was cursed for their sake.

The Gadianton robbers, who were among the Lamanites, spread throughout the land so much that the people started hiding their treasures in the ground. But their treasures became slippery, because the Lord had cursed the land, so they couldn't keep them or get them back again.
There were sorceries, witchcraft, and magic, and the power of the evil one was at work throughout the land, fulfilling all the words of Abinadi and also Samuel the Lamanite.

In that same year, a war started again between the Nephites and the Lamanites. Even though I was young, I was large in stature, so the people of Nephi chose me to be their leader, the leader of their armies.
When I was sixteen years old, I led an army of the Nephites against the Lamanites; by this time, three hundred twenty-six years had passed.

In the three hundred and twenty-seventh year, the Lamanites attacked us with such great power that they frightened my armies. Because of this, my armies would not fight and began to retreat toward the northern regions.

We went to the city of Angola, took possession of it, and prepared to defend ourselves against the Lamanites. We fortified the city with all our strength, but even with all our defenses, the Lamanites attacked us and drove us out of the city.
They also forced us out of the land of David.
We marched forward and came to the land of Joshua, which was on the western borders by the seashore.
We gathered our people as quickly as possible so we could bring them together in one group.

The land was filled with robbers and Lamanites, and even though my people faced great destruction, they didn't repent of their evil actions. Because of this, there was bloodshed and carnage everywhere, caused by both the Nephites and the Lamanites, and the whole land was in complete turmoil.

The Lamanites had a king named Aaron, and he came against us with an army of forty-four thousand. I resisted him with forty-two thousand. I defeated him with my army, and he fled from me. All this happened after three hundred and thirty years had passed.

The Nephites started to repent of their sins and began to cry out, just as Samuel the prophet had prophesied, because no one could keep what belonged to them due to the thieves, robbers, murderers, magic arts, and witchcraft in the land.
So there was mourning and lamentation throughout the land because of these things, especially among the people of Nephi.

When I, Mormon, saw their lamentation, mourning, and sorrow before the Lord, my heart began to rejoice within me because I knew the Lord's mercy and patience. I supposed that he would be merciful to them and that they would become a righteous people again.

But my joy was empty, because their sorrow didn't lead them to repent or recognize God's goodness. Instead, it was the sorrow of the damned, because the Lord would not always allow them to find happiness in sin.
They didn't come to Jesus with broken hearts and humble spirits. Instead, they cursed God and wished for death, but still fought for their lives with the sword.

My sorrow returned to me again, and I saw that their day of grace had passed, both physically and spiritually; I saw thousands of them killed in open rebellion against their God and their bodies piled up like dung on the land. Three hundred and forty-four years had passed.
In the three hundred and forty-fifth year, the Nephites began to flee from the Lamanites, and they were chased until they reached the land of Jashon, before they were able to stop their retreat.

The city of Jashon was near the land where Ammaron had placed the records for the Lord so they wouldn't be destroyed. I followed Ammaron's instructions, took the plates of Nephi, and made a record as Ammaron had directed.

On the plates of Nephi, I made a complete record of all the wickedness and abominations, but on these plates I chose not to give a full account of their wickedness and abominations, because I have constantly witnessed wickedness and abominations ever since I was old enough to understand the ways of people.
I am sorrowful because of their wickedness; my heart has been filled with sorrow because of their wickedness all my life. Still, I know that I will be lifted up at the last day.
That year, the people of Nephi were once again hunted and driven out. We were forced to flee until we reached the land called Shem in the north.
We fortified the city of Shem and gathered our people as much as possible, hoping we might save them from destruction.
In the three hundred and forty-sixth year, they began to attack us again.
I spoke to my people and urged them with great energy to stand boldly against the Lamanites and fight for their wives, their children, their houses, and their homes.
My words motivated them somewhat, so they didn't run away from the Lamanites, but stood boldly against them.
We fought with an army of thirty thousand against an army of fifty thousand. We stood so firmly against them that they fled from us.

When they fled, we pursued them with our armies, met them again, and defeated them. However, the strength of the Lord was not with us; we were left on our own, and the Spirit of the Lord was not with us. Because of this, we had become as weak as our brothers.

My heart was filled with sorrow because of the great calamity that had come upon my people, because of their wickedness and their abominations. But we went out against the Lamanites and the Gadianton robbers until we had taken back possession of the lands of our inheritance.
The three hundred and forty-ninth year passed. In the three hundred and fiftieth year, we made a treaty with the Lamanites and the Gadianton robbers, in which our lands of inheritance were divided.
The Lamanites gave us the land to the north, even up to the narrow passage that leads into the southern land. We gave the Lamanites all the land to the south.
The Lamanites didn't come to battle again until ten more years had passed. During that time, I had my people, the Nephites, prepare their lands and their weapons for when the next battle would come.
The Lord said to me, "Call out to this people—Repent, come to me, be baptized, and rebuild my church, and you will be spared."
I pleaded with the people, but it was in vain; they didn't realize that the Lord had spared them and given them a chance to repent. They hardened their hearts against the Lord their God.

After the tenth year ended, making a total of three hundred sixty years since the coming of Christ, the king of the Lamanites sent me a letter letting me know that they were preparing to come again to battle against us.
I had my people gather together at the land of Desolation, to a city on the borders by the narrow pass that led into the land southward.
We stationed our armies there to stop the Lamanite armies from taking any of our lands, so we fortified ourselves against them with all our strength.
In the three hundred sixty-first year, the Lamanites came down to the city of Desolation to fight against us, and that year we defeated them so completely that they returned to their own lands again.
In the three hundred sixty-second year, they came down again to battle. We defeated them again, killed many of them, and their dead were thrown into the sea.

Because of this great thing my people, the Nephites, had done, they started to boast about their own strength and swore before heaven that they would take revenge for the blood of their brothers who had been killed by their enemies.
They swore by the heavens and by the throne of God that they would go to battle against their enemies and destroy them from the land.
From this time on, I, Mormon, completely refused to be a commander and leader of this people because of their wickedness and abominations.

I had led them, and even though they were wicked, I had led them many times into battle and loved them with all my heart, with the love of God that was in me. I had poured out my soul in prayer to God for them all day long; but it was without faith because their hearts were so hard.
I have delivered them from their enemies three times, and they still have not repented of their sins.

After they swore by everything our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ had forbidden, that they would go fight their enemies and take revenge for the blood of their brothers, the voice of the Lord came to me, saying:
Vengeance is mine, and I will repay; and because these people did not repent after I delivered them, they will be cut off from the face of the earth.

I completely refused to go up against my enemies, and I did just as the Lord commanded me. I stood as a passive witness to show the world the things I saw and heard, according to the revelations of the Spirit that testified of things to come.
So I am writing to you, Gentiles, and also to you, house of Israel, when the work begins, that you will be about to prepare to return to the land of your inheritance.
I am writing to everyone across the earth, to you, the twelve tribes of Israel, who will be judged according to your works by the twelve whom Jesus chose to be his disciples in the land of Jerusalem.
I am also writing to the remnant of this people, who will be judged by the twelve whom Jesus chose in this land; and they will be judged by the other twelve whom Jesus chose in the land of Jerusalem.

The Spirit shows me these things, so I am writing to all of you. I am writing so you will know that everyone must stand before the judgment seat of Christ—every person from the entire human family of Adam—and you will be judged for your actions, whether they are good or evil.

I am writing so that you may believe the gospel of Jesus Christ, which you will have among you, and so that the Jews, the covenant people of the Lord, will have another witness besides the one they saw and heard, that Jesus, whom they killed, was truly the Christ and truly God.
I wish I could persuade everyone throughout the world to repent and get ready to stand before the judgment seat of Christ.
In the three hundred sixty-third year, the Nephites took their armies out of the land of Desolation to fight against the Lamanites.

The armies of the Nephites were driven back again to the land of Desolation. While they were still weary, a fresh army of the Lamanites attacked them, and there was a fierce battle. The Lamanites took possession of the city Desolation, killed many of the Nephites, and took many prisoners.
The rest fled and joined the people living in the city of Teancum. The city of Teancum was located on the border by the seashore, and it was also near the city of Desolation.
The Nephite armies began to be defeated because they went up against the Lamanites; if they hadn't done that, the Lamanites would not have had any power over them.
The judgments of God will overtake the wicked, and the wicked are punished by other wicked people, because it is the wicked who stir up people's hearts to violence.
The Lamanites prepared to attack the city of Teancum.
In the three hundred sixty-fourth year, the Lamanites came against the city of Teancum to take possession of it as well.

They were pushed back and driven away by the Nephites. When the Nephites saw that they had driven out the Lamanites, they started boasting about their own strength again. They went forward with their own power and took back the city of Desolation.
All these things had happened, and thousands had been killed on both sides, both among the Nephites and the Lamanites.
After the three hundred and sixty-sixth year had passed, the Lamanites attacked the Nephites again; but the Nephites still did not repent of the evil they had done, and continued in their wickedness.

It is impossible to fully describe or write a perfect account of the horrible bloodshed and carnage among the people, both Nephites and Lamanites. Every heart was hardened, and they took pleasure in shedding blood continually.
There had never been such great wickedness among all the children of Lehi, or even among all the house of Israel, according to the words of the Lord, as there was among this people.
The Lamanites took control of the city Desolation because they outnumbered the Nephites.
They also marched against the city Teancum, drove the inhabitants out, took many prisoners—both women and children—and offered them as sacrifices to their idol gods.

In the three hundred sixty-seventh year, the Nephites, angry because the Lamanites had sacrificed their women and children, went against the Lamanites with extremely great anger and defeated them again, driving them out of their lands.
The Lamanites did not attack the Nephites again until the three hundred seventy-fifth year.
That year, they came down against the Nephites with all their strength, and their numbers were so great that they couldn't be counted.
From this time on, the Nephites had no power over the Lamanites and began to be destroyed by them, like dew before the sun.
The Lamanites came down against the city of Desolation, and there was an extremely fierce battle fought in the land of Desolation, in which they defeated the Nephites.
They fled from them again and went to the city of Boaz. There they stood against the Lamanites with great courage, so the Lamanites did not defeat them until they attacked a second time.
When they came the second time, the Nephites were driven back and killed in an extremely great slaughter; their women and children were once again sacrificed to idols.
The Nephites fled from them again, taking all the inhabitants with them from both towns and villages.
Now I, Mormon, saw that the Lamanites were about to conquer the land, so I went to the hill Shim and took all the records that Ammaron had hidden for the Lord.

I went among the Nephites and regretted the oath I had made that I would no longer help them. They gave me command of their armies again, because they believed I could deliver them from their troubles.
I had no hope, because I knew the judgments of the Lord that would come upon them. They didn't repent of their sins, but fought for their lives without calling on the Being who created them.
The Lamanites came against us as we fled to the city of Jordan, but they were driven back and did not take the city at that time.

They attacked us again, and we defended the city. There were also other cities held by the Nephites, and these strongholds blocked them from entering the land ahead of us to destroy the people living there.

Any lands we had passed by, whose inhabitants had not been gathered in, were destroyed by the Lamanites, and their towns, villages, and cities were burned with fire; and in this way, three hundred seventy-nine years went by.

In the three hundred and eightieth year, the Lamanites came against us again to battle, and we stood against them boldly; but it was all in vain, because their numbers were so great that they trampled the people of the Nephites under their feet.
We fled again, and those who ran faster than the Lamanites escaped, but those who couldn't outrun the Lamanites were overtaken and destroyed.

Now, I, Mormon, do not want to trouble people's souls by describing such a terrible scene of blood and carnage as I saw; but I know these things must be made known, and that everything hidden must be revealed openly—

A knowledge of these things must come to the remnant of this people, and also to the Gentiles, whom the Lord has said will scatter this people, and this people will be considered as nothing among them. For this reason, I am writing a brief summary, not daring to give a full account of what I have seen because of the commandment I have received, and also so you will not have too much sorrow because of the wickedness of this people.
I say this to their descendants, and also to the Gentiles who care about the house of Israel, so they can recognize and understand where their blessings come from.

I know that they will mourn for the tragedy of the house of Israel; they will grieve over the destruction of this people; they will be saddened that this people did not repent so they could have been embraced in the arms of Jesus.

These things are written to the remnant of the house of Jacob, and they are written this way because God knows that wickedness will not bring them to the people; they are to be kept for the Lord so they can come forth in his own due time.
This is the commandment I have received: they will come forth according to the Lord's commandment, when he sees fit, in his wisdom.

They will go to the unbelieving Jews for this purpose: to persuade them that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God, so that the Father can accomplish, through his most Beloved, his great and eternal purpose of restoring the Jews, or all the house of Israel, to the land of their inheritance, which the Lord their God has given them, fulfilling his covenant.

And also so that the descendants of this people may more fully believe his gospel, which will be brought to them by the Gentiles; for this people will be scattered and will become a dark, filthy, and loathsome people, beyond anything we have ever seen, even more than what has been among the Lamanites, and this will happen because of their unbelief and idolatry.
The Spirit of the Lord has already stopped striving with their fathers; they are without Christ and God in the world, and they are driven about like chaff before the wind.
They were once a delightful people, and Christ was their shepherd; they were even led by God the Father.
But now they are led by Satan, like chaff blown by the wind, or like a ship tossed on the waves without a sail, anchor, or anything to steer it; and just as the ship is, so are they.
The Lord has saved the blessings that they could have received in the land for the Gentiles who will possess the land.

They will be driven and scattered by the Gentiles; and after they have been driven and scattered by the Gentiles, then the Lord will remember the covenant he made with Abraham and with all the house of Israel.
The Lord will also remember the prayers of the righteous that have been offered to Him for them.
So then, Gentiles, how can you stand before the power of God unless you repent and turn from your evil ways?
Don't you know that you are in the hands of God? Don't you know that he has all power, and at his great command the earth will be rolled together like a scroll?

So repent and humble yourselves before Him, or He will come against you in justice—if not, a remnant of the descendants of Jacob will go among you like a lion and tear you to pieces, and no one will be able to save you.
Now I finish my record about the destruction of my people, the Nephites. We marched out to face the Lamanites.
I, Mormon, wrote a letter to the king of the Lamanites, asking him to allow us to gather our people in the land of Cumorah, by a hill called Cumorah, so we could face them in battle there.
The king of the Lamanites granted me what I asked for.
We marched to the land of Cumorah and set up our tents around the hill Cumorah. It was a land with many waters, rivers, and springs, and here we hoped to gain an advantage over the Lamanites.
After three hundred eighty-four years had passed, we gathered all the rest of our people to the land of Cumorah.

When we had gathered all our people together in the land of Cumorah, I, Mormon, began to grow old. Knowing this would be the final struggle of my people, and having been commanded by the Lord not to let the sacred records handed down by our fathers fall into the hands of the Lamanites—because the Lamanites would destroy them—I made this record from the plates of Nephi and hid all the records entrusted to me by the Lord in the hill Cumorah, except for these few plates which I gave to my son Moroni.

My people, with their wives and children, now saw the armies of the Lamanites marching toward them; filled with that terrible fear of death which fills the hearts of all the wicked, they waited to face them.
They came to fight against us, and everyone was filled with terror because of how many there were.
They attacked my people with the sword, the bow, the arrow, the ax, and all kinds of weapons of war.
My men were cut down, including my ten thousand who were with me, and I was wounded in the middle of it; but they passed by me and did not kill me.

After they had gone through and killed all my people except for twenty-four of us—including my son Moroni—and we had survived the death of our people, we saw the next day, when the Lamanites had returned to their camps, from the top of the hill Cumorah, the ten thousand of my people who had been killed, with me leading them at the front.
We also saw the ten thousand of my people who were led by my son Moroni.
The ten thousand of Gidgiddonah had fallen, and he was among them.

Lamah had fallen with his ten thousand; Gilgal had fallen with his ten thousand; Limhah had fallen with his ten thousand; Jeneum had fallen with his ten thousand; and Cumenihah, Moronihah, Antionum, Shiblom, Shem, and Josh had each fallen with their ten thousand.

There were ten more who were killed by the sword, each with their ten thousand; all my people had fallen, except for the twenty-four who were with me, a few who escaped to the southern lands, and a few who deserted to the Lamanites. Their flesh, bones, and blood lay on the ground, left by those who killed them to decay and return to the earth.
My soul was torn with anguish because of the death of my people, and I cried out:
You beautiful people, how could you have turned away from the ways of the Lord? You beautiful people, how could you have rejected Jesus, who stood with open arms to receive you?
If you had not done this, you would not have fallen. But you have fallen, and I mourn your loss.
Oh, you beautiful sons and daughters, fathers and mothers, husbands and wives, you fair ones—how could you have fallen!
But you are gone, and my sorrows cannot bring you back.

The day will soon come when your mortal body must become immortal, and these bodies that are now decaying will soon become incorruptible. Then you must stand before the judgment seat of Christ to be judged according to your works, and if you are righteous, you will be blessed with your ancestors who have gone before you.

I wish you had repented before this great destruction came upon you. But you are gone, and the Father, the Eternal Father of heaven, knows your situation; and he acts with you according to his justice and mercy.

Now I want to say something to the remnant of this people who have been spared, hoping that God will allow them to receive my words so they can learn about the things of their ancestors. I am speaking to you, the remnant of the house of Israel, and these are the words I say:
Know that you are part of the house of Israel.
You need to understand that you must repent, or you cannot be saved.
You need to lay down your weapons of war, stop taking pleasure in shedding blood, and never take them up again unless God commands you.

You need to come to understand the faith of your ancestors, repent of all your sins and wrongdoings, and believe in Jesus Christ—that he is the Son of God, that he was killed by the Jews, and that by the power of the Father he has risen again, gaining victory over the grave; and in him the sting of death is overcome.
He brings about the resurrection of the dead, so that everyone must be raised to stand before his judgment seat.

And he has accomplished the redemption of the world, so that anyone found guiltless before him on the judgment day is allowed to live in the presence of God in his kingdom, to sing endless praises with the heavenly choirs to the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, who are one God, in a state of happiness that never ends.

So repent and be baptized in the name of Jesus, and embrace the gospel of Christ, which will be given to you not only in this record but also in the record that will come to the Gentiles from the Jews, and then from the Gentiles to you.

This is written so that you may believe it; and if you believe it, you will also believe this; and if you believe this, you will know about your ancestors and the marvelous works that were accomplished by the power of God among them.

You will also know that you are a remnant of the descendants of Jacob; so you are counted among the people of the first covenant. If you believe in Christ and are baptized—first with water, then with fire and with the Holy Ghost—following the example of our Savior as he has commanded us, it will be well with you on the day of judgment. Amen.
I, Moroni, am finishing the record of my father, Mormon. I have only a few things to write, which my father commanded me to include.
After the great and tremendous battle at Cumorah, the Nephites who had escaped into the country southward were hunted by the Lamanites until they were all destroyed.

My father was also killed by them, and I am left alone to write the sad story of my people's destruction. They are gone, and I am fulfilling my father's commandment. I don't know whether they will kill me.
So I will write and hide the records in the earth, and it doesn't matter where I go.

My father has made this record, and he has written its purpose. I would write it too if I had room on the plates, but I don't; and I have no ore, for I am alone. My father has been killed in battle, along with all my relatives, and I have no friends or anywhere to go; and I don't know how long the Lord will allow me to live.
Four hundred years have passed since the coming of our Lord and Savior.

The Lamanites have hunted my people, the Nephites, from city to city and from place to place, until they are gone. Their fall has been great, and the destruction of my people, the Nephites, is truly great and remarkable.
It is the hand of the Lord that has done this. The Lamanites are at war with each other, and the entire land is caught in constant murder and bloodshed. No one knows when the war will end.
I won't say anything more about them, because only the Lamanites and robbers still exist on the land.

No one knows the true God except the disciples of Jesus, who stayed in the land until the people's wickedness became so great that the Lord would not allow them to remain with the people; and no one knows whether they are still on the earth.
My father and I have seen them, and they have ministered to us.

Anyone who receives this record and does not reject it because of its imperfections will come to know greater things than these. I am Moroni, and if it were possible, I would make everything known to you.
I will stop talking about this people now. I am the son of Mormon, and my father was a descendant of Nephi.

I am the one who is hiding this record for the Lord. The plates themselves are worthless because of the Lord's commandment. He has truly said that no one will have them to get gain. But the record is of great value, and whoever brings it to light will be blessed by the Lord.

No one can have the power to bring it to light unless God gives it to them; because God wants it to be done with a focus on his glory, or for the welfare of the ancient and long-dispersed covenant people of the Lord.

Blessed is the one who brings this record to light, for it will be brought out of darkness into light, according to the word of God. It will come out of the earth and shine out of darkness, coming to the knowledge of the people, and it will be done by the power of God.
If there are faults, they are the faults of a man. But we know of no fault; however, God knows all things. So whoever condemns, let him be careful, or he may be in danger of hell fire.
Anyone who says, "Show me, or you will be punished, " should be careful not to demand something the Lord has forbidden.
The one who judges rashly will be judged rashly in return; each person will be rewarded according to their actions. So, anyone who strikes others will be struck in return by the Lord.
The scripture says that man should not strike or judge, because judgment belongs to the Lord, and vengeance is also His, and He will repay.

Anyone who speaks out in anger and contention against the work of the Lord and against the covenant people of the Lord, who are the house of Israel, and says, "We will destroy the work of the Lord, and the Lord will not remember his covenant which he has made with the house of Israel"—that person is in danger of being cut down and cast into the fire.
The eternal purposes of the Lord will continue until all his promises are fulfilled.

Search the prophecies of Isaiah. I cannot write them. I tell you, those saints who have gone before me and have possessed this land will cry to the Lord, even from the dust; and as the Lord lives, he will remember the covenant he has made with them.

He knows their prayers, which were for their brothers and sisters. He knows their faith, for in his name they could move mountains; in his name they could make the earth shake; and by the power of his word they caused prisons to fall to the ground. Even the fiery furnace could not harm them, nor could wild beasts or poisonous serpents, because of the power of his word.
Their prayers were also for him, that the Lord would allow these things to come forth.

No one should say they will not come, because they definitely will, for the Lord has spoken it. They will come out of the earth by the hand of the Lord, and no one can stop it. This will happen in a time when people say that miracles have ended, and it will happen as if someone is speaking from the dead.
It will happen in a time when the blood of the saints cries out to the Lord because of secret combinations and evil deeds.

It will come in a day when people deny the power of God, and churches become corrupted and filled with pride; even in a time when church leaders and teachers become proud, to the point that they envy those who belong to their churches.
It will come in a time when people will hear about fires, storms, and clouds of smoke in other countries.
There will also be reports of wars, rumors of wars, and earthquakes in various places.

It will come in a time when there are great pollutions on the earth; there will be murders, robbery, lying, deception, sexual immorality, and all kinds of evil. Many will say, "Do this or do that, it doesn't matter, for the Lord will support such people at the last day." But sorrow will come to them, for they are in the bitterness of sin and bound by wickedness.
It will come in a day when churches will be established that say, "Come to me, and for your money you will be forgiven of your sins."

You wicked, perverse, and stubborn people, why have you built churches for yourselves just to get gain? Why have you changed the holy word of God to bring condemnation on your souls? Look to the revelations of God, because the time will come when all these things must happen.
The Lord has shown me great and marvelous things about what will soon happen, at the time when these things will come to you.
I am speaking to you as if you were here, even though you are not. Jesus Christ has shown you to me, and I know what you are doing.

I know that you walk in the pride of your hearts, and there are only a few who do not lift themselves up in pride—wearing very fine clothes, envying, arguing, holding malice, persecuting others, and committing all kinds of sins. Your churches—even every one of them—have become corrupted because of the pride in your hearts.
You love money, your possessions, your fine clothing, and the decoration of your churches more than you love the poor and needy, the sick and the afflicted.

You corrupt people, you hypocrites, you teachers who sell yourselves for things that will decay, why have you polluted the holy church of God? Why are you ashamed to take on the name of Christ? Why don't you realize that endless happiness is worth more than never-ending misery just for the praise of the world?
Why do you decorate yourselves with things that have no life, yet let the hungry, the needy, the naked, the sick, and the afflicted pass by you without noticing them?

Why do you build up your secret abominations to get gain, and cause widows to mourn before the Lord, and orphans to mourn before the Lord, and the blood of their fathers and their husbands to cry to the Lord from the ground for vengeance on your heads?
The sword of vengeance hangs over you, and the time is coming soon when he will avenge the blood of the saints on you, for he will not allow their cries any longer.
Now I'm going to talk about those who do not believe in Christ.

Will you believe in the day of your visitation—when the Lord comes, on that great day when the earth is rolled together like a scroll and the elements melt with intense heat, on that great day when you are brought to stand before the Lamb of God—will you then say that there is no God?

Will you still deny Christ, or can you look upon the Lamb of God? Do you think you could live with him while being aware of your guilt? Do you think you could be happy living with that holy Being when your souls are tormented by the knowledge that you have broken his laws?
I tell you that you would be more miserable living with a holy and just God, fully aware of your own filthiness before him, than you would be living with the damned souls in hell.
When you are brought to see your nakedness before God, along with the glory of God and the holiness of Jesus Christ, it will ignite an unquenchable fire within you.

So, you who do not believe, turn to the Lord; pray earnestly to the Father in the name of Jesus, so that you may be found spotless, pure, clean, and white, having been cleansed by the blood of the Lamb on that great and last day.

I am speaking to those of you who deny the revelations of God and claim that they have ended—that there are no revelations, no prophecies, no gifts, no healings, no speaking in tongues, and no interpretation of tongues.
I tell you, anyone who denies these things does not know the gospel of Christ; he has not read the scriptures, or if he has, he does not understand them.
Don't we read that God is the same yesterday, today, and forever, and that there is no change or even a hint of change in him?
If you have imagined a god who changes and in whom there is any shadow of changing, then you have imagined a god who is not a God of miracles.
I will show you a God of miracles, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. He is the same God who created the heavens and the earth, and everything in them.
He created Adam, and through Adam came the fall of man. Because of the fall of man, Jesus Christ came, who is both the Father and the Son; and because of Jesus Christ, the redemption of man came.

Because of the redemption of mankind, which came through Jesus Christ, people are brought back into the presence of the Lord. This is how all people are redeemed, because the death of Christ brings about the resurrection, which provides redemption from an endless sleep. From this sleep, everyone will be awakened by the power of God when the trumpet sounds. They will come forward, both small and great, and everyone will stand before his judgment, having been redeemed and freed from this eternal bond of death, which is a physical death.

Then the judgment of the Holy One will come upon them. At that time, those who are filthy will remain filthy; those who are righteous will remain righteous; those who are happy will remain happy; and those who are unhappy will remain unhappy.

Now, all of you who have imagined a god who can't do miracles, I want to ask you: Have all these things I've talked about already happened? Has the end come yet? I tell you, no; and God has not stopped being a God of miracles.
Aren't the things that God has done amazing in our eyes? And who can understand the marvelous works of God?

Who can say it wasn't a miracle that by his word the heaven and the earth were made, and by the power of his word man was created from the dust of the earth, and by the power of his word miracles have been performed?
Who can say that Jesus Christ didn't perform many mighty miracles? Many powerful miracles were also done by the hands of the apostles.

If miracles happened then, why would God stop being a God of miracles and still be unchanging? I tell you, he does not change; if he did, he would stop being God. But he does not stop being God, and he is a God of miracles.
The reason He stops performing miracles among people is because they fall into unbelief, turn away from the right path, and do not know the God they should trust.
I tell you that whoever believes in Christ without doubting, whatever they ask the Father in the name of Christ will be given to them; and this promise is for everyone, even to the ends of the earth.
Jesus Christ, the Son of God, said to his disciples who would remain, and also to all his disciples, in front of the crowd: Go into all the world and preach the gospel to everyone.
Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned.

These signs will follow those who believe: in my name they will cast out demons; they will speak in new languages; they will pick up serpents; and if they drink anything deadly, it will not harm them; they will lay hands on the sick, and they will recover.
Anyone who believes in my name without doubting will have all my words confirmed to them, even to the ends of the earth.

Now, who can stand against the works of the Lord? Who can deny his words? Who will rise up against the almighty power of the Lord? Who will despise the works of the Lord? Who will despise the children of Christ? All of you who despise the works of the Lord will be amazed and perish.

So don't look down on these things or be surprised, but listen to the words of the Lord, and ask the Father in the name of Jesus for whatever you need. Don't doubt, but have faith, and start as people did in the past—come to the Lord with all your heart, and work out your own salvation with reverence and humility before Him.

Be wise during your time of testing; rid yourselves of all impurity; don't ask for things just to satisfy your own desires, but ask with unwavering determination that you won't give in to temptation, and that you will serve the true and living God.

Make sure you are not baptized unworthily; make sure you do not partake of the sacrament of Christ unworthily; but make sure you do all things worthily, and do them in the name of Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God. If you do this and endure to the end, you will not be cast out.
I am speaking to you as if I were speaking from the dead, because I know you will have my words.

Do not condemn me because of my imperfections, or my father because of his imperfections, or those who wrote before him. Instead, give thanks to God that he has shown you our imperfections, so you can learn to be wiser than we have been.
Now we have written this record to the best of our knowledge, in the characters we call reformed Egyptian, which have been handed down and changed by us according to our way of speaking.

If our plates had been large enough, we would have written in Hebrew; but we have also changed the Hebrew language. If we could have written in Hebrew, you would have had no imperfections in our record.
But the Lord knows the things we have written, and also that no other people know our language. Because no other people know our language, he has prepared a way for it to be interpreted.
These things are written so that we can be free from the guilt of our brothers, who have fallen into unbelief.
These things we have hoped for our brothers—their return to the knowledge of Christ—are in line with the prayers of all the saints who have lived in this land.

May the Lord Jesus Christ grant that their prayers are answered according to their faith, and may God the Father remember the covenant he has made with the house of Israel. May he bless them forever through faith in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen.
I, Moroni, am now going to give an account of the ancient inhabitants who were destroyed by the hand of the Lord in this northern land.
I am taking my account from the twenty-four plates that were found by the people of Limhi, which is called the Book of Ether.

I assume that the first part of this record, which talks about the creation of the world, Adam, and events from that time up to the great tower, and everything that happened among the children of men until then, is available among the Jews—
So I am not writing about what happened from the days of Adam up to that time, but those events are recorded on the plates; and whoever finds them will have the ability to get the full account.
I am not giving the full account, but only a part of it, from the tower until they were destroyed.
This is how I give the account: The person who wrote this record was Ether, and he was a descendant of Coriantor.
Coriantor was the son of Moron.
Moron was Ethem's son.
Ethem was the son of Ahah.
Ahah was Seth's son.
Seth was the son of Shiblon.
Shiblon was the son of Com.
Com was the son of Coriantum.
Coriantum was the son of Amnigaddah.
Amnigaddah was Aaron's son.
Aaron was a descendant of Heth, who was the son of Hearthom.
Hearthom was the son of Lib.
Lib was the son of Kish.
Kish was the son of Corom.
Corom was Levi's son.
Levi was Kim's son.
Kim was the son of Morianton.
And Morianton was a descendant of Riplakish.
Riplakish was the son of Shez.
Shez was the son of Heth.
Heth was the son of Com.
Com was the son of Coriantum.
And Coriantum was the son of Emer.
Emer was the son of Omer.
Omer was the son of Shule.
Shule was the son of Kib.
Kib was the son of Orihah, who was the son of Jared.

Jared left with his brother, their families, and some others with their families from the great tower when the Lord confused the language of the people and, in his anger, swore that they would be scattered across the whole earth. As the Lord said, the people were scattered.

The brother of Jared was a large and mighty man, highly favored by the Lord. Jared, his brother, said to him, "Pray to the Lord that he will not confuse our language so we can still understand each other."
The brother of Jared prayed to the Lord, and the Lord had compassion on Jared. He did not confuse Jared's language, so Jared and his brother were not confused.
Then Jared said to his brother, "Pray again to the Lord, and maybe he will turn away his anger from our friends so that he won't confuse their language."
The brother of Jared prayed to the Lord, and the Lord had compassion on their friends and families as well, so they were not confused.

Jared spoke again to his brother, saying, "Go and ask the Lord if he will drive us out of the land, and if he does, pray to him to know where we should go. Who knows, maybe the Lord will lead us to a land that is better than any other on earth. If that happens, let's be faithful to the Lord so we can receive it as our inheritance."
The brother of Jared prayed to the Lord just as Jared had told him to.
The Lord heard the brother of Jared, had compassion on him, and said to him:

Gather your flocks, both male and female, of every kind; also gather seeds of every kind; bring your families, Jared your brother and his family, your friends and their families, and the friends of Jared and their families.
When you have done this, you will lead them down into the valley to the north. I will meet you there, and I will go before you into a land that is better than any other on earth.

There I will bless you and your descendants, and I will raise up from your descendants, and from the descendants of your brother, and those who go with you, a great nation. There will be no nation greater than the one I will raise up from your descendants on the face of the earth. I will do this for you because you have prayed to me for such a long time.

Jared and his brother, along with their families and the families of their friends, traveled north into the valley called Nimrod, named after the mighty hunter, bringing with them all the flocks they had gathered, both male and female of every kind.
They also set traps and caught birds, and they prepared a container to carry fish from the waters with them.
They also brought with them deseret, which means honey bee; they carried swarms of bees and all kinds of things from the land, including seeds of every kind.
When they arrived in the valley of Nimrod, the Lord came down and spoke with the brother of Jared. He was in a cloud, and the brother of Jared did not see him.

The Lord commanded them to go into the wilderness, into a region where no one had ever been. The Lord went before them and spoke with them while standing in a cloud, giving them directions on where they should travel.
They traveled through the wilderness and built barges, which they used to cross many bodies of water, being continually guided by the hand of the Lord.

The Lord did not allow them to stay in the wilderness beyond the sea, but wanted them to continue on to the promised land, which was better than all other lands and which the Lord God had preserved for a righteous people.

He had sworn in his anger to the brother of Jared that anyone who possessed this promised land, from that time on and forever, must serve him, the true and only God, or they would be destroyed when his full wrath came upon them.

We see God's decrees about this land: it is a land of promise. Any nation that possesses it must serve God, or they will be swept away when his full wrath comes upon them. His full wrath comes when they are fully grown in wickedness.

This is a land that is more special than any other; whoever possesses it must serve God or will be removed, because that is God's everlasting decree. The people are not removed until the wickedness among the inhabitants is complete.

This is given to you, O Gentiles, so that you may know the commandments of God—that you may repent and not continue in your sins until the end comes, so you will not bring the full wrath of God upon yourselves as the previous inhabitants of the land have done.

This is a choice land, and any nation that possesses it will be free from bondage, captivity, and from all other nations under heaven, if they will serve the God of the land, who is Jesus Christ, who has been revealed by the things we have written.

I continue with my record. The Lord brought Jared and his brothers to the great sea that divides the lands. When they reached the sea, they set up their tents and named the place Moriancumer. They lived in tents by the seashore for four years.

After four years, the Lord came again to the brother of Jared, stood in a cloud, and spoke with him. The Lord talked with the brother of Jared for three hours and corrected him because he had forgotten to pray to the Lord.

The brother of Jared repented of the wrong he had done and prayed to the Lord for his brothers who were with him. The Lord said to him, "I will forgive you and your brothers of your sins, but you must not sin anymore, because you should remember that my Spirit will not always strive with people. If you continue to sin until you are completely wicked, you will be cut off from my presence. These are my thoughts about the land I will give you as your inheritance, for it will be a land chosen above all other lands."

The Lord said, "Go to work and build barges the same way you have built them before." So the brother of Jared and his brothers went to work and built barges as they had before, following the Lord's instructions. The barges were small and light on the water, as light as a bird on the water.

They were built in a way that made them extremely watertight, able to hold water like a dish. The bottom was tight like a dish, the sides were tight like a dish, and the ends were pointed. The top was tight like a dish, the length was about the length of a tree, and the door, when closed, was tight like a dish.
The brother of Jared prayed to the Lord, saying, "O Lord, I have done the work you commanded me, and I have built the barges just as you directed."
Lord, there is no light in them; how will we steer? We will also die, because we can't breathe inside them except for the air that's already in them; so we will die.

The Lord said to the brother of Jared, "You must make a hole in the top and also in the bottom; and when you need air, you should open the hole to get air. If water comes in, you should close the hole so you won't perish in the flood."
The brother of Jared did as the Lord had commanded.

He prayed again to the Lord, saying, "O Lord, I have done as you commanded me, and I have prepared the vessels for my people, but there is no light in them. O Lord, will you allow us to cross this great water in darkness?"

The Lord said to the brother of Jared, "What do you want me to do so you can have light in your vessels? You can't have windows, because they would be broken; and you can't take fire with you, because you won't travel by the light of fire."

You will be like a whale in the middle of the sea, as the mountain waves crash over you. But I will bring you up again from the depths of the sea, because I have sent the winds from my mouth, and I have also sent the rains and the floods.

I am preparing you for these challenges, because you cannot cross this great ocean unless I help you face the waves, the winds, and the floods that will come. So, what do you want me to do so you can have light when you are surrounded by the depths of the sea?

The brother of Jared (there were eight vessels prepared) went to the mountain they called Shelem because it was very tall. He melted out of a rock sixteen small stones that were white and clear, like transparent glass. He carried them in his hands to the top of the mountain and called out to the Lord, saying:

Lord, you have said that we must be surrounded by the floods. Please, Lord, don't be angry with your servant because of his weakness before you; we know that you are holy and live in the heavens, and that we are unworthy before you. Because of the fall, our natures have become continually evil. Even so, Lord, you have given us a commandment to call upon you, so that we may receive from you according to our desires.

O Lord, you have struck us because of our sins and have driven us out, and for many years we have been in the wilderness. Still, you have been merciful to us. Lord, please look on me with pity and turn your anger away from your people. Don't let them cross this raging sea in darkness; instead, look at these things I have made from the rock.

I know, Lord, that you have all power and can do whatever you want for the benefit of people. So please touch these stones with your finger and make them shine in the darkness. They will give us light in the vessels we have prepared, so we can have light as we cross the sea.
O Lord, you can do this. We know that you are able to show great power, which seems small to human understanding.

When the brother of Jared finished speaking, the Lord reached out and touched the stones one by one with his finger. The veil was removed from the brother of Jared's eyes, and he saw the finger of the Lord—it looked like a human finger, made of flesh and blood. The brother of Jared fell down before the Lord, overcome with fear.
The Lord saw that the brother of Jared had fallen to the ground, and He said to him, "Get up; why have you fallen?"
He said to the Lord, "I saw your finger, and I was afraid you might strike me, because I didn't know that you had flesh and blood."

The Lord said to him, "Because of your faith, you have seen that I will take on flesh and blood. No one has ever come before me with faith as great as yours; if it weren't so, you couldn't have seen my finger. Did you see anything more than this?"
He answered, "No; Lord, show yourself to me."
And the Lord said to him, "Do you believe the words I will speak?"
He answered, "Yes, Lord, I know that you speak the truth, for you are a God of truth and cannot lie."

And when he had said these words, the Lord showed himself to him and said, Because you know these things, you are redeemed from the fall; so you are brought back into my presence, and I show myself to you.

I am the one who was prepared from the foundation of the world to redeem my people. I am Jesus Christ. I am the Father and the Son. All mankind will have life in me, and that life will be eternal, for those who believe in my name; and they will become my sons and my daughters.

I have never shown myself to any person I have created, because no one has believed in me as you have. Do you see that you are created in my own image? In fact, all people were created in the beginning in my own image.
This body you now see is the body of my spirit; I created humans after the body of my spirit; and just as I appear to you in the spirit, I will appear to my people in the flesh.

As I, Moroni, said, I can't give a complete account of these things that are written, so I'll just say that Jesus showed himself to this man in spirit, in the same way and in the same form as the body he showed to the Nephites.
He ministered to him just as he ministered to the Nephites; all of this was so this man would know that he was God, because of the many great works the Lord had shown him.

Because of this man's knowledge, he could not be kept from seeing within the veil; and he saw the finger of Jesus. When he saw it, he fell in fear, for he knew it was the finger of the Lord. He no longer had faith, because he knew without any doubt.
Because he had this perfect knowledge of God, he could not be kept from within the veil; so he saw Jesus, and Jesus ministered to him.

The Lord said to the brother of Jared, "You must not let the things you have seen and heard be made known to the world until the time comes when I will glorify my name in the flesh. You should keep what you have seen and heard to yourself and show it to no one."
When you come to me, you will write them and seal them up so that no one can interpret them, because you will write them in a language that cannot be read.
I will give you these two stones, and you must seal them up along with the things you write.
The language you will write has been confounded, so at the right time, I will make these stones reveal to people the things you write.

After the Lord said these words, he showed the brother of Jared all the people who had lived on the earth and all who would live; he did not hide anything from his sight, even to the ends of the earth.

God had told him before that if he believed in Him, He could show him all things—it would be shown to him. So the Lord could not hold anything back from him, because he knew that the Lord could show him everything.
The Lord said to him, "Write these things and seal them up, and I will reveal them to the children of men at the right time."
The Lord commanded him to seal up the two stones he had received and not show them until the Lord revealed them to the children of men.

The Lord commanded the brother of Jared to leave the mountain, away from the presence of the Lord, and write down what he had seen. These things were not to be given to the children of men until after Christ would be lifted up on the cross. For this reason, King Mosiah kept them hidden, so they would not come to the world until after Christ had shown himself to his people.
After Christ had truly shown himself to his people, he commanded that these things should be made known.
Now, after all of them have dwindled in unbelief, there is no one left except the Lamanites, and they have rejected the gospel of Christ. So I am commanded to hide them again in the earth.
I have written on these plates the very things that the brother of Jared saw, and there have never been greater things revealed than those that were shown to the brother of Jared.

The Lord has commanded me to write these things, so I have written them. He also commanded me to seal them up, and to seal up their interpretation. So I have sealed up the interpreters, as the Lord commanded.
The Lord told me that these things will not be given to the Gentiles until the day they repent of their sins and become clean before Him.

When they have faith in me, says the Lord, just as the brother of Jared did, so they can become sanctified in me, then I will show them the things the brother of Jared saw, revealing to them all my revelations, says Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the Father of the heavens and the earth, and everything in them.
