Anyone who argues against the word of the Lord will be cursed; and anyone who denies these things will be cursed. I will not show greater things to them, says Jesus Christ, for I am the one who speaks.
At my command, the heavens open and close; at my word, the earth will shake; and at my command, its inhabitants will pass away, just as if by fire.
Anyone who does not believe my words does not believe my disciples; and if I do not speak, you judge; because you will know that it is I who speaks, at the last day.

Anyone who believes the things I have spoken, I will visit with the manifestations of my Spirit, and they will know and testify. Because of my Spirit, they will know that these things are true, for it persuades people to do good.

Anything that persuades people to do good comes from me, because good comes from no one except me. I am the one who leads people to all good; whoever does not believe my words does not believe me—that I exist; and whoever does not believe me does not believe the Father who sent me. I am the Father, the light, the life, and the truth of the world.
Come to me, you Gentiles, and I will show you greater things—the knowledge that is hidden because of unbelief.
Come to me, house of Israel, and you will see the great things the Father has prepared for you since the foundation of the world; but you have not received them because of unbelief.

When you tear down that veil of unbelief that keeps you in your terrible state of wickedness, hardness of heart, and blindness of mind, then the great and marvelous things that have been hidden from you since the foundation of the world will be revealed. When you call upon the Father in my name with a broken heart and a contrite spirit, you will know that the Father has remembered the covenant he made with your fathers, O house of Israel.
Then my revelations, which I had my servant John write, will be revealed to everyone. When you see these things, you will know that the time is near for them to truly come to pass.
So when you receive this record, you can know that the work of the Father has begun throughout the whole land.

So repent, everyone throughout the earth, and come to me. Believe in my gospel and be baptized in my name, because whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned. Signs will follow those who believe in my name.

Blessed is the one who is found faithful to my name at the last day, for he will be lifted up to live in the kingdom prepared for him since the foundation of the world. I am the one who has spoken this. Amen.

I, Moroni, have written the words I was commanded to, according to my memory. I have told you about the things I have sealed up, so do not touch them to try to translate them, because you are not allowed to do that unless, at some point, God sees fit for it to happen.
You may be allowed to show the plates to those who will help bring forth this work.
They will be shown to three people by the power of God, and those three will know for sure that these things are true.

These things will be established by the testimony of three witnesses; and through the testimony of these three, and this work, the power of God and his word will be shown, which the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost testify of—and all of this will stand as a testimony against the world at the last day.
If they repent and come to the Father in the name of Jesus, they will be received into the kingdom of God.
If I have no authority for these things, judge for yourselves; because you will know that I have authority when you see me, and we will stand before God at the last day. Amen.
Now I, Moroni, will continue by giving the record of Jared and his brother.

After the Lord had prepared the stones that the brother of Jared had brought up to the mountain, the brother of Jared came down from the mountain and placed the stones into the vessels that had been prepared, one at each end. The stones gave light to the vessels.
The Lord made the stones shine in the darkness to give light to the men, women, and children, so they wouldn't have to cross the great waters in the dark.

When they had prepared all kinds of food so they could survive on the water, and also food for their flocks, herds, and any other animals or birds they brought with them, they boarded their vessels or barges and set out to sea, trusting themselves to the Lord their God.
The Lord God caused a strong wind to blow over the waters toward the promised land, and they were carried across the waves of the sea by the wind.
They were buried many times in the depths of the sea because of the mountain waves that broke over them, and also because of the great and terrible storms caused by the fierce winds.

When they were buried deep in the water, no water could harm them because their vessels were as watertight as a dish, and also as secure as Noah's ark. When they were surrounded by many waters, they prayed to the Lord, and he brought them back up to the surface.
The wind never stopped blowing toward the promised land while they were on the water, so they were carried forward by the wind.
They sang praises to the Lord; the brother of Jared also sang praises to the Lord, and he thanked and praised the Lord all day long. When night came, they continued to praise the Lord.
They were carried along, and no sea monster could break them, nor could any whale harm them; and they always had light, whether they were above the water or under it.
They traveled on the water for three hundred and forty-four days.

They landed on the shore of the promised land. When they set foot on the land, they bowed down and humbled themselves before the Lord, shedding tears of joy because of the many tender mercies He had shown them.
They went out onto the land and began to farm the earth.
Jared had four sons named Jacom, Gilgah, Mahah, and Orihah.
The brother of Jared also had sons and daughters.
Jared and his brother's friends numbered about twenty-two people. They also had sons and daughters before they reached the promised land, so their group began to grow.
They were taught to walk humbly before the Lord, and they were also taught by inspiration from above.
They began to spread across the land, multiplying and farming the earth, and they grew strong in the land.
The brother of Jared started to get old and realized he would soon die. So he said to Jared, "Let's gather our people so we can count them and find out what they want from us before we die."
The people gathered together. The brother of Jared had twenty-two sons and daughters, and Jared had twelve sons and daughters, since he had four sons.
They counted their people, and after they had finished, they asked them what they wanted done before they died.
The people asked them to anoint one of their sons to be a king over them.
This was upsetting to them, and the brother of Jared said to them, "Surely this will lead to captivity."
But Jared said to his brother, "Let them have a king." So he said to them, "Choose a king from among our sons, anyone you want."

They chose the firstborn son of the brother of Jared, whose name was Pagag. But Pagag refused and would not be their king. The people wanted his father to force him, but his father refused and commanded them not to force anyone to be their king.
They chose all the brothers of Pagag, but they refused.
None of the sons of Jared were willing to be king, except for one; and Orihah was anointed to be king over the people.
He began to reign, and the people started to prosper; they became extremely rich.
Jared died, and his brother died also.
Orihah walked humbly before the Lord and remembered the great things the Lord had done for his father. He also taught his people about the great things the Lord had done for their fathers.
Orihah ruled the land with righteous judgment throughout his life, and he lived for many years.
He had sons and daughters; he had thirty-one children, including twenty-three sons.
He also had a son named Kib in his old age. Kib became king after him, and Kib had a son named Corihor.

When Corihor was thirty-two years old, he rebelled against his father and went to live in the land of Nehor. He had sons and daughters, and they became very attractive, so Corihor led many people to follow him.
After he gathered an army, he went to the land of Moron where the king lived and took him captive, fulfilling the prophecy of the brother of Jared that they would be brought into captivity.
The land of Moron, where the king lived, was near the land that the Nephites called Desolation.
Kib lived in captivity, and his people were under the control of his son Corihor, until he became very old. However, while he was still in captivity and in his old age, Kib had a son named Shule.
Shule became angry with his brother, and he grew strong and became mighty in physical strength; he was also mighty in judgment.

He went to the hill Ephraim, melted ore from the hill, and made steel swords for those who had joined him. After arming them with swords, he returned to the city Nehor and fought his brother Corihor. In this way, he gained the kingdom and restored it to his father Kib.
Because of what Shule had done, his father gave him the kingdom, and Shule began to reign in his father's place.
He executed judgment righteously and expanded his kingdom across the entire land, because the people had become extremely numerous.
Shule also had many sons and daughters.
Corihor repented of the many evils he had done, so Shule gave him authority in his kingdom.
Corihor had many sons and daughters. Among his sons was one named Noah.
Noah rebelled against Shule, the king, and also against his father Corihor. He persuaded his brother Cohor, all his other brothers, and many of the people to join him.
He fought against Shule the king and won back the land of their first inheritance, becoming king over that part of the land.
He attacked Shule, the king, again, captured him, and took him as a prisoner to Moron.

As he was about to put him to death, the sons of Shule snuck into the house of Noah at night and killed him. They broke down the door of the prison, brought out their father, and placed him on his throne in his own kingdom.
So, the son of Noah built up his kingdom in his place; however, they never gained power over Shule the king again, and the people under Shule's reign prospered greatly and became strong.
The country was divided into two kingdoms: the kingdom of Shule and the kingdom of Cohor, the son of Noah.
Cohor, the son of Noah, led his people to fight against Shule, but Shule defeated them and killed Cohor.
Cohor had a son named Nimrod. Nimrod gave the kingdom of Cohor to Shule, and he gained Shule's favor. Shule showed him great kindness, and Nimrod was able to do what he wanted in Shule's kingdom.

During Shule's reign, prophets came among the people, sent by the Lord. They warned that the people's wickedness and idolatry were bringing a curse on the land, and that they would be destroyed if they did not repent.
The people insulted and mocked the prophets. King Shule judged and punished everyone who spoke against the prophets.
He established a law throughout the entire land that gave the prophets the authority to go wherever they wanted, and because of this, the people were brought to repentance.
Because the people repented of their sins and idolatries, the Lord spared them, and they began to prosper again in the land. Shule had sons and daughters in his old age.

There were no more wars during Shule's lifetime, and he remembered the great things the Lord had done for his ancestors in bringing them across the great ocean to the promised land. He judged righteously all his days.
He had a son named Omer, who became king after him. Omer had a son named Jared, and Jared had sons and daughters.
Jared rebelled against his father and went to live in the land of Heth. He used his clever words to flatter many people until he had gained half of the kingdom.
When he had gained half of the kingdom, he fought against his father, took him captive, and made him serve in captivity.
During the reign of Omer, he was in captivity for half of his life. He had sons and daughters, including Esrom and Coriantumr.
They were extremely angry because of what their brother Jared had done, so they raised an army and fought against him. They attacked him at night.
When they had killed Jared's army, they were about to kill him too. He pleaded with them not to kill him and promised to give the kingdom back to his father. They agreed to spare his life.
Jared was extremely sorrowful because he lost the kingdom, since he had set his heart on the kingdom and the glory of the world.
Jared's daughter was very clever, and when she saw how sad her father was, she began to think of a way to help him get the kingdom back.

Jared's daughter was extremely beautiful. She spoke with her father and asked, "Why are you so sad? Haven't you read the record our ancestors brought across the ocean? Isn't there an account about people long ago who gained kingdoms and great glory through their secret plans?"

So now, let my father send for Akish, the son of Kimnor. I am beautiful, and I will dance before him and please him so that he will want to marry me. If he asks you to let him marry me, tell him, "I will give her to you if you bring me the head of my father, the king."
Omer was a friend to Akish, so when Jared sent for Akish, Jared's daughter danced before him and pleased him so much that he wanted to marry her. He said to Jared, "Give her to me as my wife."
Jared said to him, "I will give her to you if you bring me the head of my father, the king."
Akish gathered all his relatives into Jared's house and said to them, "Will you swear to be loyal to me in what I will ask of you?"

They all swore to him, by the God of heaven, by the heavens, by the earth, and by their own heads, that anyone who failed to help Akish as he wanted would be killed, and anyone who revealed anything Akish told them would also be put to death.
So they agreed with Akish, and Akish gave them the oaths that had been passed down from those in the past who also sought power—oaths that had come from Cain, who was a murderer from the beginning.

They were supported by the power of the devil to give these oaths to the people, to keep them in darkness, to help those who wanted power to gain it, and to murder, steal, lie, and commit all kinds of wickedness and sexual immorality.

Jared's daughter inspired him to look into these ancient things, and Jared encouraged Akish to do the same. So Akish introduced it to his family and friends, persuading them with attractive promises to do whatever he wanted.
They formed a secret combination, just like those in ancient times; this combination is extremely abominable and wicked in the sight of God.
The Lord does not work in secret combinations, nor does He want people to shed blood; in all things He has forbidden it from the beginning of mankind.
I, Moroni, am not writing the details of their oaths and secret combinations, because it has been made known to me that they exist among all people, including the Lamanites.
They have caused the destruction of the people I am now talking about, and also the destruction of the people of Nephi.

Any nation that supports these secret groups to gain power and wealth, allowing them to spread throughout the nation, will be destroyed. The Lord will not allow the blood of his saints, shed by these groups, to continually cry out to him from the ground for vengeance without him avenging them.

O Gentiles, God in His wisdom has shown you these things so that you can repent of your sins and not allow these murderous groups, which are created to gain power and wealth, to have control over you. If you let this happen, the work of destruction will come upon you, and the sword of the justice of the Eternal God will fall on you, leading to your downfall and destruction.

The Lord commands you that when you see these things happening among you, you should wake up to how terrible your situation is because of this secret combination among you. Otherwise, there will be sorrow for it because of the blood of those who have been killed, for they cry from the dust for vengeance on it and on those who supported it.

Anyone who builds it up seeks to overthrow the freedom of all lands, nations, and countries; and it leads to the destruction of all people, because it is built up by the devil, the father of all lies—the same liar who deceived our first parents, the same liar who has caused people to commit murder from the beginning, who has hardened the hearts of men so they have murdered the prophets, stoned them, and cast them out from the beginning.

I, Moroni, am commanded to write these things so that evil can be removed, and so the time may come when Satan has no power over the hearts of the children of men, but instead, they are persuaded to do good continually, come to the fountain of all righteousness, and be saved.
Now I, Moroni, continue with my record. Because of the secret combinations of Akish and his friends, they overthrew the kingdom of Omer.
However, the Lord was merciful to Omer, as well as to his sons and daughters who did not try to destroy him.

The Lord warned Omer in a dream to leave the land, so Omer left with his family and traveled for many days. They passed by the hill of Shim and the place where the Nephites were destroyed, then continued east until they reached a place called Ablom by the seashore. There, he set up his tent along with his sons, daughters, and all his household, except for Jared and his family.
Jared was anointed king over the people through wicked actions, and he gave his daughter to Akish as a wife.

Akish wanted to kill his father-in-law, so he went to those he had sworn to by the ancient oath, and they killed his father-in-law by cutting off his head while he was sitting on his throne, speaking to his people.
The influence of this wicked and secret society had spread so much that it corrupted the hearts of all the people. As a result, Jared was murdered on his throne, and Akish became king in his place.
Akish became jealous of his son, so he put him in prison and gave him little or no food until he died.
Nimrah, the brother of the one who was killed, was angry with his father because of what his father had done to his brother.
Nimrah gathered a small group of men, left the land, and went to live with Omer.
Akish had other sons, and they won the hearts of the people, even though they had sworn to him to do all kinds of evil according to whatever he wanted.
The people of Akish wanted wealth, just as Akish wanted power. So the sons of Akish offered them money, and in this way they convinced most of the people to follow them.

A war broke out between Akish and his sons, lasting for many years and leading to the destruction of nearly everyone in the kingdom—everyone except for thirty people and those who escaped with the house of Omer.
Omer was restored again to the land of his inheritance.
Omer grew old; but in his old age he had a son named Emer, and he anointed Emer to be king to rule in his place.

After he anointed Emer to be king, he saw peace in the land for two years, and then he died after living many days filled with sorrow. Emer became king in his place and followed in his father's footsteps.
The Lord began once again to remove the curse from the land, and the house of Emer prospered greatly during Emer's reign. In sixty-two years, they became very strong and extremely rich.
They had all kinds of fruit, grain, silks, fine linen, gold, silver, and valuable items.
They also had all kinds of cattle—oxen, cows, sheep, pigs, goats—and many other kinds of animals that were useful for human food.
They also had horses and donkeys, and there were elephants, cureloms, and cumoms. All of these were useful to people, especially the elephants, cureloms, and cumoms.

The Lord poured out his blessings on this land, which was the most choice of all lands. He commanded that whoever possessed the land should do so for the Lord, or they would be destroyed when they became fully wicked. For the Lord says, "I will pour out the fullness of my wrath on such people."
Emer judged righteously throughout his life and had many sons and daughters. He had a son named Coriantum, and he anointed Coriantum to reign in his place.

After he anointed Coriantum to reign in his place, he lived for four more years and saw peace in the land. He even saw the Son of Righteousness and rejoiced and gloried in his day, and he died in peace.
Coriantum followed in his father's footsteps and built many great cities, doing good for his people throughout his life. He had no children until he was very old.
His wife died at the age of one hundred and two. In his old age, Coriantum married a young woman and had sons and daughters. He lived until he was one hundred and forty-two years old.
He had a son named Com, who became king after him. Com reigned for forty-nine years and had a son named Heth, as well as other sons and daughters.
The people spread out again across the land, and once more, there was a great amount of wickedness throughout the land. Heth started to follow the old secret plans again to destroy his father.
He dethroned his father by killing him with his own sword, and then he ruled in his place.

Prophets came into the land again, calling the people to repent and prepare the way of the Lord, or a curse would come upon the land—a great famine in which they would be destroyed if they did not repent.
But the people did not believe the words of the prophets and threw them out; some they threw into pits and left them to die. They did all these things because King Heth commanded them to.
A great famine began in the land, and the people started to die very quickly because of it, since there was no rain on the earth.
Poisonous serpents also came onto the land and poisoned many people. Their flocks started to flee from the poisonous serpents toward the land to the south, which the Nephites called Zarahemla.
Many of them died along the way; however, some escaped into the land to the south.
The Lord made it so the serpents no longer chased them, but instead blocked the way so the people couldn't get through, and anyone who tried to pass might be killed by the poisonous serpents.

The people followed the paths of the animals and ate the bodies of those that died along the way, until they had eaten them all. When the people realized they were about to die, they began to repent of their sins and pray to the Lord.

When they had humbled themselves enough before the Lord, he sent rain on the land. The people began to recover, and fruit started to grow in the northern regions and in all the surrounding areas. The Lord showed his power by preserving them from famine.
Shez, who was a descendant of Heth—for Heth had died in the famine, and his entire household except Shez had perished—began to rebuild a broken people.

Shez remembered the destruction of his ancestors and built a righteous kingdom, because he remembered how the Lord brought Jared and his brother across the ocean. He lived according to the Lord's ways and had sons and daughters.
His oldest son, Shez, rebelled against him; however, Shez was killed by a robber because of his great wealth, which brought peace back to his father.

His father built many cities throughout the land, and the people began to spread across the whole land again. Shez lived to a very old age and had a son named Riplakish. After Shez died, Riplakish became king in his place.

Riplakish did not do what was right in the sight of the Lord, for he had many wives and concubines, and he placed burdens on the people that were hard to bear. He taxed them heavily, and with those taxes he built many large buildings.

He built himself an extremely beautiful throne and constructed many prisons. Anyone who refused to pay taxes was thrown into prison, and anyone who couldn't pay taxes was also imprisoned. He made the prisoners work continually for their own support, and anyone who refused to work was put to death.

He obtained all his fine work, including his fine gold, which he had refined in prison, and he had all kinds of fine workmanship made in prison. He afflicted the people with his whoredoms and abominations.
After he had reigned for forty-two years, the people rebelled against him, and war broke out again in the land. Riplakish was killed, and his descendants were driven out of the land.

After many years, Morianton, who was a descendant of Riplakish, gathered an army of outcasts and went out to fight against the people. He gained control over many cities, and the war was extremely fierce and lasted for many years. Eventually, he gained power over all the land and established himself as king over it.
After he became king, he eased the people's burdens, which made him popular with them, and they anointed him as their king.
He acted justly toward the people, but not toward himself because of his many sexual sins; so he was cut off from the presence of the Lord.
Morianton built many cities, and the people became extremely rich during his reign—in buildings, gold and silver, raising grain, flocks, herds, and other things that had been restored to them.

Morianton lived to a very old age and then had a son named Kim. Kim became king after his father and ruled for eight years, and then his father died. Kim did not rule righteously, so he was not favored by the Lord.

His brother rebelled against him and took him captive; he stayed in captivity for the rest of his life. While in captivity, he had sons and daughters, and in his old age he had a son named Levi. Then he died.
After his father died, Levi served in captivity for forty-two years. He made war against the king of the land and gained the kingdom for himself.

After he became king, he did what was right in the sight of the Lord, and the people prospered in the land. He lived to a good old age and had sons and daughters. He also had a son named Corom, whom he anointed as king to take his place.
Corom did what was good in the sight of the Lord all his days. He had many sons and daughters, and after living many years, he died like everyone else. Kish became king after him.
Kish died, and Lib became king in his place.

Lib also did what was good in the sight of the Lord. During Lib's days, the poisonous serpents were destroyed. So they went into the land southward to hunt food for the people, because the land was filled with animals of the forest. Lib himself also became a great hunter.
They built a large city near the narrow neck of land, at the place where the sea divides the land.
They kept the land to the south as wilderness for hunting, and the entire land to the north was filled with people.
They were extremely hardworking, and they bought, sold, and traded with each other to make a profit.

They worked with all kinds of ore and made gold, silver, iron, brass, and all types of metals. They dug these out of the earth, piling up great heaps of dirt to get ore of gold, silver, iron, and copper. They also did all kinds of fine work.
They had silks and fine-twined linen, and they made all kinds of cloth so they could clothe themselves.
They made all kinds of tools to work the land—tools for plowing, planting, harvesting, hoeing, and threshing.
They made all kinds of tools to work with their animals.
They made all kinds of weapons of war and produced all sorts of work with extremely intricate craftsmanship.
There was never a people more blessed or more prospered by the hand of the Lord. They lived in a land that was better than any other, because the Lord had declared it.
Lib lived for many years and had sons and daughters; he also had a son named Hearthom.
Hearthom became king in place of his father. After Hearthom had reigned for twenty-four years, the kingdom was taken from him. He spent many years in captivity, for the rest of his life.

He had a son named Heth, and Heth lived in captivity all his life. Heth had a son named Aaron, and Aaron also lived in captivity all his life. Aaron had a son named Amnigaddah, who also lived in captivity all his life. Amnigaddah had a son named Coriantum, and Coriantum lived in captivity all his life. Coriantum had a son named Com.

Com took control of half of the kingdom and ruled it for forty-two years. He went to war against King Amgid, and they fought for many years. During that time, Com gained power over Amgid and eventually took control of the rest of the kingdom.
During the days of Com, robbers started to appear in the land. They used the old plans, made oaths like the people of ancient times, and tried again to destroy the kingdom.
Com fought hard against them, but he could not defeat them.
During the days of Com, many prophets came and warned that this great people would be destroyed unless they repented, turned to the Lord, and stopped their murders and wickedness.
The prophets were rejected by the people, so they fled to Com for protection because the people wanted to destroy them.
They prophesied many things to Com, and he was blessed for the rest of his days.
He lived to a good old age and had a son named Shiblom, who became king after him. Shiblom's brother rebelled against him, and a very great war began throughout the land.
The brother of Shiblom ordered that all the prophets who spoke about the destruction of the people be put to death.

There was great calamity throughout the land, because they had warned that a great curse would come upon the land and the people, and that there would be a destruction among them like never before on the earth, and their bones would become like piles of dirt on the land unless they repented of their wickedness.

They did not listen to the voice of the Lord because of their wicked combinations. As a result, wars and conflicts broke out throughout the land, along with many famines and diseases, causing such great destruction as had never been known on the earth. All of this happened during the days of Shiblom.
The people began to repent of their sins, and as they did, the Lord had mercy on them.
Shiblom was killed, and Seth was taken captive and lived in captivity for the rest of his life.
Ahah, his son, took over the kingdom and ruled the people for the rest of his life. During his reign, he committed all kinds of wickedness, causing much bloodshed, and his days were few.
Ethem, who was a descendant of Ahah, took control of the kingdom, and he also did evil during his lifetime.
During the days of Ethem, many prophets came and prophesied to the people, warning that the Lord would completely destroy them from the face of the earth unless they repented of their sins.
The people hardened their hearts and refused to listen to their words, and the prophets mourned and withdrew from among the people.
Ethem ruled wickedly all his days and had a son named Moron. Afterward, Moron became king in his place, and Moron did what was evil in the sight of the Lord.

A rebellion started among the people because of the secret combination that was formed to gain power and wealth. A powerful and wicked man rose up and fought against Moron, overthrowing half of the kingdom. He held onto that half of the kingdom for many years.
Moron overthrew him and regained the kingdom.
Another mighty man arose, and he was a descendant of the brother of Jared.
He overthrew Moron and took control of the kingdom. Moron lived in captivity for the rest of his life, and he had a son named Coriantor.
Coriantor lived in captivity for the rest of his life.

During the days of Coriantor, many prophets came and spoke of great and marvelous things. They called the people to repent, warning that if they did not repent, the Lord God would judge them and completely destroy them.
And that the Lord God would send or bring another people to possess the land by his power, in the same way he brought their ancestors.
They rejected all the words of the prophets because of their secret society and wicked abominations.
Coriantor had a son named Ether, and then he died, having lived in captivity all his life.
During Ether's lifetime, Coriantumr was king over all the land.
Ether was a prophet of the Lord. Ether came forward during the days of Coriantumr and began to prophesy to the people, because he could not be restrained due to the Spirit of the Lord within him.
He cried out from morning until sunset, urging the people to believe in God and repent so they wouldn't be destroyed, telling them that all things are accomplished through faith.

Anyone who believes in God can confidently hope for a better world, even a place at the right hand of God. This hope comes from faith and becomes an anchor for people's souls, making them steady and unwavering, always doing good works and being led to glorify God.
Ether prophesied great and marvelous things to the people, but they did not believe him because they did not see them.

Now I, Moroni, want to talk a little about these things. I want to show the world that faith is hoping for things you can't see. So don't argue just because you can't see; you don't receive a witness until after your faith is tested.

It was through faith that Christ appeared to our ancestors after he rose from the dead. He didn't show himself to them until they had faith in him. So, some had to have faith in him, because he didn't show himself to the world.

Because of people's faith, he has shown himself to the world, glorified the name of the Father, and prepared a way for others to receive the heavenly gift, so they can hope for things they have not seen.
You can also have hope and share in the gift if you will have faith.
It was by faith that people in ancient times were called after the holy order of God.
By faith the law of Moses was given. But through the gift of his Son, God has prepared a better way; and it is by faith that it has been fulfilled.
If there is no faith among the children of men, God cannot do miracles among them; so he did not show himself until after they had faith.
It was the faith of Alma and Amulek that caused the prison to fall to the ground.
It was the faith of Nephi and Lehi that brought about the change in the Lamanites, so that they were baptized with fire and with the Holy Ghost.
It was the faith of Ammon and his brothers that brought about such a great miracle among the Lamanites.
All those who performed miracles did so by faith, both those who lived before Christ and those who lived after.
By faith, the three disciples received a promise that they would not experience death; and they did not receive the promise until after they showed their faith.
No one has ever performed miracles until after they had faith; they first believed in the Son of God.

There were many whose faith was so extremely strong, even before Christ came, that they could not be kept from within the veil. They actually saw with their eyes the things they had previously seen with an eye of faith, and they were glad.

We have seen in this record that one of these was the brother of Jared. His faith in God was so great that when God put forth his finger, he could not hide it from the brother of Jared, because of the word he had spoken to him, which he had received by faith.

After the brother of Jared saw the finger of the Lord, because of the promise he had received through faith, the Lord could not hide anything from him; so He showed him everything, because he could no longer be kept from seeing beyond the veil.
It is by faith that my ancestors have received the promise that these things would come to their brothers through the Gentiles; so the Lord has commanded me, even Jesus Christ.

And I said to him, Lord, the Gentiles will mock these things because of our weakness in writing. Lord, you have made us strong in speaking by faith, but you have not made us strong in writing. You have made all these people able to speak much because of the Holy Ghost you have given them.

You have made us so we can write only a little because our hands are awkward. You have not made us strong in writing like the brother of Jared, for you made him so that the things he wrote were powerful, even as you are, so much that people were overwhelmed when they read them.

You have also made our words powerful and great, so much that we can't write them. When we write, we see our weakness and struggle with how we arrange our words, and I'm afraid the Gentiles will make fun of what we write.
And when I said this, the Lord spoke to me, saying: Fools mock, but they will mourn; and my grace is enough for the meek, so they will not take advantage of your weakness.

If people come to me, I will show them their weaknesses. I give people weakness so they can be humble, and my grace is enough for everyone who humbles themselves before me. If they humble themselves before me and have faith in me, I will make weak things become strong for them.
I will show the Gentiles their weakness, and I will show them that faith, hope, and charity lead to me—the source of all righteousness.
I, Moroni, heard these words and felt comforted. I said, "O Lord, let your righteous will be done, for I know that you work among the children of men according to their faith."
The brother of Jared said to the mountain Zerin, "Move, " and it was moved. If he hadn't had faith, it wouldn't have moved; you work after people have faith.
This is how you revealed yourself to your disciples; after they had faith and spoke in your name, you showed yourself to them with great power.

I also remember that you have said you have prepared a house for people, even among the mansions of your Father, where people can have a greater hope. So, people must have hope, or they cannot receive an inheritance in the place you have prepared.
I also remember that you have said you loved the world so much that you gave your life for it, so you could take it up again to prepare a place for the children of men.
Now I know that the love you have had for the children of men is charity. Unless people have charity, they cannot inherit the place you have prepared in the mansions of your Father.

I know from what you have said that if the Gentiles don't have charity because of our weakness, you will test them and take away their talent, even what they have received, and give it to those who will have more abundantly.
I prayed to the Lord, asking Him to give the Gentiles grace so they could have charity.

The Lord said to me: If they don't have charity, it doesn't matter to you; you have been faithful, so your garments will be made clean. And because you have recognized your weakness, you will be made strong, even to the point of sitting down in the place I have prepared in the mansions of my Father.

Now I, Moroni, say goodbye to the Gentiles and also to my beloved brothers, until we meet before the judgment seat of Christ, where everyone will know that my garments are not stained with your blood.

Then you will know that I have seen Jesus, and that he has talked with me face to face, and that he told me with plain humility, just as one person speaks to another in my own language, about these things.
I've only written a few things because I'm not strong in writing.

I encourage you to seek Jesus, the one the prophets and apostles have written about, so that the grace of God the Father, the Lord Jesus Christ, and the Holy Ghost, who testifies of them, may be with you and remain in you forever. Amen.
Now I, Moroni, am going to finish my record about the destruction of the people I have been writing about.

They rejected all of Ether's words, even though he truly told them everything from the beginning of man. After the waters had receded from this land, it became a choice land above all others, chosen by the Lord. The Lord wants everyone who lives here to serve Him.
It was the place of the New Jerusalem, which will come down from heaven, and the holy sanctuary of the Lord.
Ether saw the days of Christ and spoke about a New Jerusalem on this land.

He also spoke about the house of Israel and the Jerusalem from where Lehi would come. After it is destroyed, it will be rebuilt as a holy city to the Lord. It cannot be called a new Jerusalem because it existed in ancient times, but it will be rebuilt and become a holy city of the Lord, built for the house of Israel.
A New Jerusalem will be built on this land for the descendants of Joseph, and these things have been foreshadowed.

Just as Joseph brought his father down to the land of Egypt and died there, the Lord brought a remnant of Joseph's descendants out of Jerusalem so he could show mercy to them and keep them from being destroyed, just as he was merciful to Joseph's father and kept him from perishing.

The remnant of the house of Joseph will be established on this land, and it will be their inheritance. They will build a holy city to the Lord, like the Jerusalem of old, and they will no longer be confused or scattered until the end comes, when the earth passes away.
There will be a new heaven and a new earth, and they will be like the old ones except that the old have passed away, and everything has become new.

Then the New Jerusalem will come, and blessed are those who live there, for their garments are white through the blood of the Lamb. They are counted among the remnant of the descendants of Joseph, who was of the house of Israel.

Then the old Jerusalem will also come; and its inhabitants are blessed, for they have been washed in the blood of the Lamb. They are the ones who were scattered and gathered from the four corners of the earth and from the northern countries, and they take part in the fulfillment of the covenant God made with their father, Abraham.
And when these things happen, it fulfills the scripture that says, those who were first will be last, and those who were last will be first.

I was about to write more, but I am forbidden. The prophecies of Ether were great and marvelous, but the people considered him as nothing and cast him out. He hid himself in the cavity of a rock during the day, and at night he went out to observe the things that would happen to the people.
While he lived in the cave, he finished the rest of his record, watching the destruction that happened to the people at night.

In the same year that he was cast out from among the people, a great war began among them. Many mighty men rose up and tried to destroy Coriantumr with their secret plans of wickedness, which have already been mentioned.
Coriantumr, having studied all the arts of war and all the cunning of the world, gave battle to those who sought to destroy him.

But he did not repent, nor did his handsome sons or daughters; nor did the handsome sons and daughters of Cohor; nor the handsome sons and daughters of Corihor; in fact, none of the handsome sons and daughters on the whole earth repented of their sins.
In the first year that Ether lived in the cave, many people were killed by the swords of those secret groups as they fought against Coriantumr to try to take the kingdom.
The sons of Coriantumr fought hard and were badly wounded.

In the second year, the word of the Lord came to Ether, telling him to go and prophesy to Coriantumr that if he and his entire household would repent, the Lord would give him his kingdom and spare the people.

Otherwise, they would be destroyed, and all his household except for himself. He would live only to see the fulfillment of the prophecies that had been spoken about another people receiving the land as their inheritance. Coriantumr would be buried by them, and every soul would be destroyed except for Coriantumr.
Coriantumr did not repent, nor did his household or the people. The wars did not stop, and they tried to kill Ether, but he escaped from them and hid again in the cave in the rock.
Shared rose up and fought against Coriantumr, and he defeated him so thoroughly that in the third year he took him captive.
In the fourth year, Coriantumr's sons defeated Shared and restored the kingdom to their father.
A war started across the whole land, with each man and his group fighting for what they wanted.
There were robbers, and all kinds of wickedness covered the entire land.
Coriantumr was extremely angry with Shared, so he went against him with his armies to battle. They met each other in great anger in the valley of Gilgal, and the battle became very intense.
Shared fought against him for three days. Coriantumr defeated him and pursued him until he came to the plains of Heshlon.
Shared attacked him again on the plains and defeated Coriantumr, driving him back to the valley of Gilgal.
Coriantumr fought Shared again in the valley of Gilgal, where he defeated and killed him.
Shared wounded Coriantumr in his thigh, so he couldn't go to battle again for two years. During that time, everyone in the land was shedding blood, and no one stopped them.

A great curse came upon the land because of the people's wickedness. If someone set down his tool or sword on a shelf or wherever he usually kept it, the next day he wouldn't be able to find it—the curse on the land was that severe.

So every man held tightly to what belonged to him and refused to borrow or lend; each person kept the handle of his sword in his right hand to defend his property, his life, and his wives and children.
After two years had passed and after Shared died, Shared's brother rose up and fought against Coriantumr. Coriantumr defeated him and chased him into the wilderness of Akish.
The brother of Shared fought against him in the wilderness of Akish. The battle was extremely intense, and many thousands were killed by the sword.
Coriantumr laid siege to the wilderness, and the brother of Shared marched out of the wilderness at night and killed part of Coriantumr's army while they were drunk.
He went to the land of Moron and took Coriantumr's throne.
Coriantumr stayed with his army in the wilderness for two years, during which his army became much stronger.
The brother of Shared, named Gilead, also gained great strength for his army because of secret combinations.
His high priest murdered him as he sat on his throne.
One of the secret combinations murdered him in a secret pass and took the kingdom for himself. His name was Lib, and he was a man of great stature, taller than anyone else among all the people.
In the first year of Lib, Coriantumr went to the land of Moron and fought against Lib.
He fought with Lib, and Lib struck his arm and wounded him; however, Coriantumr's army pushed forward against Lib, so he fled to the borders by the seashore.
Coriantumr chased him, and Lib fought against him on the seashore.
Lib struck Coriantumr's army, causing them to flee again to the wilderness of Akish.
Lib chased him until he reached the plains of Agosh. Coriantumr took all the people with him as he fled from Lib in that part of the land where he was escaping.

When he reached the plains of Agosh, he fought against Lib and struck him until he died. However, Lib's brother came against Coriantumr instead, and the battle became extremely fierce, causing Coriantumr to flee again from the army of Lib's brother.
The brother of Lib was named Shiz. Shiz chased after Coriantumr, destroyed many cities, killed both women and children, and burned the cities.
Fear of Shiz spread throughout the entire land, and people cried out everywhere, "Who can stand against the army of Shiz? He sweeps everything before him!"
The people began to gather together in armies across the entire land.
They split up, with some fleeing to Shiz's army and others fleeing to Coriantumr's army.
The war had been so intense and lasted so long, with so much bloodshed and destruction, that the entire land was covered with the bodies of the dead.

The war was so fast and intense that no one was left to bury the dead. They went from one battle to the next, leaving the bodies of men, women, and children scattered across the land, where they became food for worms.
The smell spread across the entire land, and the people were troubled day and night because of it.

However, Shiz continued to pursue Coriantumr because he had sworn to take revenge on Coriantumr for the death of his brother, who had been killed, and because of the word of the Lord given to Ether that Coriantumr would not die by the sword.
We see that the Lord visited them in the fullness of his wrath, and their wickedness and abominations prepared the way for their everlasting destruction.
Shiz chased Coriantumr eastward to the borders by the seashore, and there Coriantumr fought against Shiz for three days.

The destruction among Shiz's armies was so terrible that the people became frightened and started to flee from Coriantumr's armies. They fled to the land of Corihor and drove out the inhabitants ahead of them—anyone who wouldn't join them.

They set up their tents in the valley of Corihor, and Coriantumr set up his tents in the valley of Shurr. The valley of Shurr was near the hill Comnor, so Coriantumr gathered his armies on the hill Comnor and sounded a trumpet to invite the armies of Shiz to come out to battle.
They came out but were driven back; they came a second time and were driven back again. They came a third time, and the battle became extremely fierce.
Shiz struck Coriantumr and gave him many deep wounds. Coriantumr lost so much blood that he fainted and was carried away as if he were dead.
The loss of men, women, and children on both sides was so great that Shiz ordered his people not to pursue Coriantumr's armies, so they returned to their camp.
When Coriantumr had recovered from his wounds, he began to remember the words that Ether had spoken to him.
He saw that nearly two million of his people had already been killed by the sword, and he began to sorrow in his heart. Two million mighty men had been killed, along with their wives and children.

He started to repent of the wrong he had done; he began to remember the words spoken by all the prophets, and he saw that they had been fulfilled completely; and his soul mourned and refused to be comforted.
He wrote a letter to Shiz, asking him to spare the people, and promised to give up the kingdom to save their lives.
When Shiz received his letter, he wrote back to Coriantumr, saying that if Coriantumr would surrender so Shiz could kill him with his own sword, then Shiz would spare the lives of the people.

The people did not repent of their sins. The people of Coriantumr became angry with the people of Shiz, and the people of Shiz became angry with the people of Coriantumr. So the people of Shiz went to battle against the people of Coriantumr.
When Coriantumr realized he was about to be defeated, he ran away from Shiz's people again.

He came to the waters of Ripliancum, which means large, or to exceed all. When they arrived at these waters, they set up their tents, and Shiz also set up his tents nearby. The next day, they went to battle.
They fought an extremely intense battle, during which Coriantumr was wounded again and fainted from the loss of blood.
The armies of Coriantumr attacked the armies of Shiz and defeated them, forcing them to flee. They fled south and set up their tents in a place called Ogath.
Coriantumr's army set up their tents by the hill Ramah, which was the same hill where my father Mormon hid the sacred records for the Lord.
They gathered together all the people across the entire land who had not been killed, except for Ether.
Ether saw everything the people did; he saw that those who supported Coriantumr joined his army, and those who supported Shiz joined the army of Shiz.
They spent four years gathering the people so they could bring together everyone in the land and gain all the strength they possibly could.

When they were all gathered together, each joining the army he chose, with their wives and children—men, women, and children all armed with weapons of war, having shields, breastplates, and helmets, and dressed for battle—they marched out against each other to fight. They fought all day, but neither side won.

When night came, they were tired and went back to their camps. After they returned to their camps, they began to howl and mourn for the loss of their people who had been killed. Their cries, howling, and mourning were so intense that they filled the air.

The next day they went to battle again, and that day was great and terrible; but neither side won. When night came, they filled the air with their cries, howlings, and mourning for the loss of their people who had been killed.
Coriantumr wrote another letter to Shiz, asking him not to return to battle, but instead to take the kingdom and spare the lives of the people.

The Spirit of the Lord had stopped striving with them, and Satan had full power over the hearts of the people, because they were given up to the hardness of their hearts and the blindness of their minds so they might be destroyed. So they went again to battle.
They fought all day, and when night came, they slept with their swords.
The next day they fought until nightfall.
When night came, they were consumed with anger, just like a man who is drunk with wine, and they slept again with their swords.
The next day they fought again, and by nightfall only fifty-two of Coriantumr's people and sixty-nine of Shiz's people were left alive.
That night, they slept with their swords, and the next day they fought again, struggling with all their strength using their swords and shields throughout the entire day.
When night came, there were thirty-two of Shiz's people and twenty-seven of Coriantumr's people.
They ate and slept, and prepared to die the next day. They were large and mighty men, strong in the strength of men.
They fought for three hours, and they collapsed from the loss of blood.

When the men of Coriantumr had regained enough strength to walk, they were about to run for their lives. But Shiz and his men got up, and in his anger, Shiz swore that he would kill Coriantumr or die by the sword himself.
He chased after them and caught up to them the next day, and they fought again with swords. When everyone had been killed by the sword except Coriantumr and Shiz, Shiz fainted from the loss of blood.
When Coriantumr leaned on his sword and rested for a moment, he cut off Shiz's head.
After he cut off Shiz's head, Shiz raised himself up on his hands and then fell. After struggling to breathe, he died.
Coriantumr fell to the ground and became as if he had no life.

The Lord spoke to Ether and told him to go out. He went out and saw that everything the Lord had said had come true. He finished his record (I have not written a hundredth part of it) and hid it in a way that the people of Limhi later found it.

The last words written by Ether are these: Whether the Lord wants me to be taken up or to remain and experience His will in the flesh, it doesn't matter, as long as I am saved in the kingdom of God. Amen.
I, Moroni, after finishing the record of the people of Jared, thought I wouldn't write anything more, but I am still alive; and I don't reveal myself to the Lamanites because they would kill me.
Their wars among themselves are extremely fierce, and because of their hatred, they kill every Nephite who will not deny Christ.
And I, Moroni, will not deny Christ, so I go wherever I can to protect my own life.

I'm writing a few more things, even though I hadn't planned to write anything else. I do this in case they might be valuable to my brothers, the Lamanites, at some future time, according to the Lord's will.
These are the words of Christ, which he spoke to his disciples, the twelve he had chosen, as he laid his hands on them—

He called them by name and said, "You will pray to the Father in my name with great faith. After you do this, you will have power to give the Holy Ghost to those on whom you lay your hands. You will give it in my name, because this is how my apostles do it."
Christ spoke these words to them when he first appeared; the crowd did not hear it, but the disciples did. Everyone on whom they laid their hands received the Holy Ghost.
This is how the disciples, who were called the elders of the church, ordained priests and teachers—
After they prayed to the Father in the name of Christ, they laid their hands on them and said:

In the name of Jesus Christ, I ordain you to be a priest, or if you are to be a teacher, I ordain you to be a teacher, to preach repentance and forgiveness of sins through Jesus Christ, by faithfully enduring in his name to the end. Amen.
This is how they ordained priests and teachers, according to the gifts and callings God gives to people; and they ordained them by the power of the Holy Ghost, which was in them.

This is how their elders and priests gave the flesh and blood of Christ to the church. They did it according to Christ's commandments, so we know this way is correct. The elder or priest would administer it—
They knelt down with the church and prayed to the Father in the name of Christ, saying:

God, the Eternal Father, we ask you in the name of your Son, Jesus Christ, to bless and make this bread holy for the souls of all those who eat it; that they may eat in remembrance of the body of your Son, and show you, God, the Eternal Father, that they are willing to take upon themselves the name of your Son, always remember him, and keep his commandments which he has given them, so they may always have his Spirit to be with them. Amen.
This is how they gave the wine: They took the cup and said:

O God, the Eternal Father, we ask you, in the name of your Son, Jesus Christ, to bless and make this wine holy for the souls of all those who drink it, so they may do it in remembrance of the blood of your Son, which was shed for them; so they can show you, O God, the Eternal Father, that they always remember him, and that they may have his Spirit to be with them. Amen.
Now I'll talk about baptism. Elders, priests, and teachers were baptized, but they were only baptized if they showed evidence that they were worthy of it.
They only baptized those who came with a broken heart and a contrite spirit, and who testified to the church that they had truly repented of all their sins.
No one was baptized unless they took upon themselves the name of Christ and were determined to serve him to the end.

After they were baptized and changed and cleansed by the power of the Holy Ghost, they were counted as members of the church of Christ. Their names were recorded so they could be remembered and strengthened by the word of God, to help them stay on the right path, remain diligent in prayer, and rely only on the merits of Christ, who is the author and finisher of their faith.
The church met together often to fast, pray, and talk with each other about the well-being of their souls.
They met together often to partake of bread and wine in remembrance of the Lord Jesus.

They were careful to make sure there was no wrongdoing among them. Anyone found guilty of sin, with three church members as witnesses condemning them before the elders, and who did not repent or confess, had their names removed and were no longer counted among the people of Christ.
As often as they repented and sincerely asked for forgiveness, they were forgiven.

Their meetings were led by the church according to the guidance of the Spirit and by the power of the Holy Ghost. As the Holy Ghost directed them—whether to preach, encourage, pray, plead, or sing—that is what they did.

Now I, Moroni, am writing some of the words of my father Mormon, which he spoke about faith, hope, and charity. He spoke to the people in this way as he taught them in the synagogue they had built as a place of worship.

Now I, Mormon, am speaking to you, my beloved brothers. By the grace of God the Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ, and by his holy will, because of the gift of his calling to me, I am allowed to speak to you at this time.

I want to speak to you who are members of the church, who are peaceful followers of Christ, and who have gained enough hope to enter into the rest of the Lord, from now on until you rest with him in heaven.
Now, my brothers, I can tell these things about you because you live peacefully with other people.
I remember the word of God, which says that you will know people by their works; if their works are good, then they are good as well.
God has said that an evil person cannot do good; if he offers a gift or prays to God without real intent, it does him no good.
It is not considered righteousness for him.
If an evil person gives a gift, he does it grudgingly; so it is considered as if he had kept the gift, and he is counted as evil before God.
In the same way, it is considered wrong if someone prays without real intent of heart; it does him no good, because God does not accept such prayers.
So, a person who is evil cannot do what is good, and he will not give a good gift.

A bitter fountain cannot produce good water, and a good fountain cannot produce bitter water. In the same way, a person who serves the devil cannot follow Christ, and if he follows Christ, he cannot be a servant of the devil.
All good things come from God, and anything evil comes from the devil. The devil is an enemy of God and constantly fights against Him, inviting and tempting people to sin and do evil.
Anything that comes from God encourages and motivates us to do good continually. So, everything that encourages and motivates us to do good, to love God, and to serve Him is inspired by God.
So be careful, my beloved brothers, not to judge something evil as being from God, or to judge something good and from God as being from the devil.

My brothers, you have been given the ability to judge so you can know good from evil; and the way to judge is clear, so you can know with complete certainty, just as you can tell daylight from the dark night.

The Spirit of Christ is given to everyone so they can know good from evil. I am showing you how to judge; anything that invites you to do good and persuades you to believe in Christ is sent by the power and gift of Christ. Because of this, you can know with complete certainty that it is from God.

But anything that persuades people to do evil, not believe in Christ, deny Him, and not serve God—you can know for sure that it comes from the devil. This is how the devil works, because he never persuades anyone to do good, not a single person; neither do his angels, nor those who follow him.

Now, my brothers, since you know the light by which you can judge, which is the light of Christ, make sure you don't judge incorrectly; because with the same judgment you use, you will also be judged.
I ask you, brothers, to carefully search in the light of Christ so you can know good from evil. If you accept every good thing and do not condemn it, you will surely be a child of Christ.
And now, my brothers, how is it possible for you to receive every good thing?
Now I will talk about faith, just as I said I would, and I will explain how you can receive every good thing.
God knows all things and is eternal. He sent angels to minister to the children of men and to reveal the coming of Christ. Through Christ, every good thing would come.
God also told the prophets himself that Christ would come.
There were many ways that he showed good things to the children of men; and all good things come from Christ. Otherwise, people would have fallen, and no good thing could come to them.

Through the ministering of angels and by every word that came from the mouth of God, people began to have faith in Christ. By faith, they were able to receive every good thing, and this continued until Christ came.

After he came, people were also saved by faith in his name; and by faith, they become the children of God. As surely as Christ lives, he spoke these words to our ancestors: Whatever you ask the Father in my name, if it is good and you ask in faith, believing that you will receive it, it will be done for you.
My beloved brothers, have miracles stopped because Christ has ascended into heaven and sat down at the right hand of God, to claim from the Father his rights of mercy for the children of men?

He has fulfilled the requirements of the law, and he claims all those who have faith in him. Those who have faith in him will hold on to every good thing. He advocates for the children of men, and he lives eternally in the heavens.
And because he has done this, my beloved brothers, have miracles stopped? I tell you, no; angels have not stopped ministering to the children of men.
They are subject to him, serving according to his command, showing themselves to those with strong faith and a firm mind in every form of godliness.

Their ministry is to call people to repentance, to fulfill and carry out the work of the Father's covenants that he has made with his children, to prepare the way among them by declaring the word of Christ to the Lord's chosen vessels, so they can testify of him.

By doing this, the Lord God prepares the way so that the rest of humanity can have faith in Christ, allowing the Holy Ghost to have a place in their hearts according to its power; and in this way, the Father fulfills the covenants he has made with the children of men.
And Christ has said: If you have faith in me, you will have power to do whatever is right in me.
He has said: Repent, all you ends of the earth, and come to me, and be baptized in my name, and have faith in me, so that you may be saved.
Now, my beloved brothers, if what I have told you is true, and God will show you with power and great glory on the last day that it is true, then if it is true, has the day of miracles ended?

Have angels stopped appearing to the children of men? Has he taken away the power of the Holy Ghost from them? Will he do so as long as time continues, or the earth remains, or there is even one person on it to be saved?

No; miracles happen because of faith, and angels appear and serve people because of faith. If these things have stopped, it is a tragedy for the children of men, because it is due to unbelief, and everything is pointless.

No one can be saved, according to the words of Christ, unless they have faith in his name. If these things have stopped, then faith has also stopped, and the state of man is terrible, because they are as if no redemption had been made.

My beloved brothers, I believe better things about you, because I believe you have faith in Christ due to your humility. If you do not have faith in him, then you are not worthy to be counted among the people of his church.
My beloved brothers and sisters, I want to talk to you about hope. How can you have faith unless you first have hope?

So what should you hope for? I tell you, you can have hope through the atonement of Christ and the power of his resurrection, to be raised to eternal life, and this happens because of your faith in him according to the promise.
If a person has faith, they must also have hope, because without faith there can be no hope.
I also tell you that a person cannot have faith and hope unless they are meek and humble in heart.

If that's the case, his faith and hope are useless, because no one is acceptable to God except those who are meek and humble in heart. If someone is meek and humble in heart and confesses by the power of the Holy Ghost that Jesus is the Christ, he must have charity. If he doesn't have charity, he is nothing, so he must have charity.

Charity is patient and kind. It does not envy, and it is not proud. It does not seek its own interests, is not easily angered, and thinks no evil. It does not rejoice in wrongdoing but rejoices in the truth. It bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, and endures all things.
My beloved brothers, if you do not have charity, you are nothing, because charity never fails. Hold on to charity, which is the greatest of all, because everything else will fail—
Charity is the pure love of Christ, and it lasts forever. Whoever is found to have it on the last day will be blessed.

So, my beloved brothers and sisters, pray to the Father with all the energy of your hearts, that you may be filled with this love, which he has given to all who are true followers of his Son, Jesus Christ; that you may become children of God; that when he appears we will be like him, because we will see him as he is; that we may have this hope; that we may be purified just as he is pure. Amen.
A letter from my father Mormon, written to me, Moroni, soon after I was called to the ministry. This is what he wrote to me:
My beloved son Moroni, I am extremely glad that your Lord Jesus Christ has remembered you and has called you to his ministry and his holy work.

I always remember you in my prayers, constantly asking God the Father in the name of his Holy Child, Jesus, that through his infinite goodness and grace, he will help you remain faithful to his name until the end.
Now, my son, I'm talking to you about something that troubles me deeply; it pains me that there are arguments arising among you.
If I understand correctly, there have been disagreements among you about baptizing your little children.
Now, my son, I want you to work diligently so that this serious error will be removed from among you, because this is why I have written this letter.
As soon as I learned these things from you, I asked the Lord about it. The word of the Lord came to me through the power of the Holy Ghost, saying:

Listen to the words of Christ, your Redeemer, your Lord, and your God. I came into the world not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance. Those who are healthy do not need a physician, but those who are sick do. Little children are whole, because they are not capable of committing sin. The curse of Adam is taken from them through me, so it has no power over them. The law of circumcision is done away in me.
In this way, the Holy Ghost revealed the word of God to me. My beloved son, I know that it is a serious mockery before God for you to baptize little children.

I tell you that you should teach this—repentance and baptism to those who are accountable and able to sin. Teach parents that they must repent, be baptized, and humble themselves like their little children, and they will all be saved with their little children.
Their little children don't need repentance or baptism. Baptism is for those who repent, to keep the commandments and receive forgiveness of sins.

Little children are alive in Christ, even from the foundation of the world. If this weren't true, God would be partial, changeable, and show favoritism, because so many little children have died without baptism.
So, if little children couldn't be saved without baptism, they would have gone to an endless hell.

I tell you, anyone who thinks that little children need baptism is filled with bitterness and bound by sin, for he has neither faith, hope, nor charity. If he dies holding this belief, he must go down to hell.
It is terrible wickedness to think that God saves one child because of baptism, and that another must be lost because he has not been baptized.

Those who pervert the ways of the Lord like this are in trouble, for they will be destroyed unless they repent. I speak boldly, with authority from God, and I am not afraid of what anyone can do, because perfect love casts out all fear.
I am filled with charity, which is everlasting love. All children are the same to me, and I love little children with a perfect love. They are all equal and able to receive salvation.
I know that God is not partial or changeable; he is unchangeable from eternity to eternity.
Little children cannot repent; so it is terribly wicked to deny them the pure mercies of God, because they are all alive in him because of his mercy.
Anyone who says that little children need baptism denies the mercy of Christ and rejects his atonement and the power of his redemption.

Sorrow awaits such people, for they are in danger of death, hell, and endless torment. I say this boldly because God has commanded me. Listen to them and pay attention, or they will stand as witnesses against you at the judgment seat of Christ.

All little children are alive in Christ, as are all those who are without the law. The power of redemption comes to all who have no law; so, anyone who is not condemned, or who is under no condemnation, cannot repent, and for such people, baptism does not help.
It is mocking God to deny the mercy of Christ and the power of his Holy Spirit, and to put your trust in dead works.
My son, this should not happen; repentance is for those who are under condemnation and under the curse of a broken law.
The first result of repentance is baptism, and baptism comes through faith by keeping the commandments, and keeping the commandments brings forgiveness of sins.

And the remission of sins brings meekness and humility; and because of meekness and humility, the Holy Ghost visits us. The Comforter fills us with hope and perfect love, and this love endures through diligent prayer until the end comes, when all the saints will live with God.
My son, I will write to you again if I do not go out soon against the Lamanites. The pride of this nation, or the people of the Nephites, has brought about their destruction unless they repent.

Pray for them, my son, that they may repent. But I fear that the Spirit has stopped striving with them; and in this part of the land they are also trying to destroy all power and authority that comes from God, and they are denying the Holy Ghost.
After rejecting such great knowledge, my son, they will soon be destroyed, fulfilling the prophecies spoken by the prophets and the words of our Savior himself.
Goodbye, my son, until I write to you again or see you again. Amen.
My beloved son, I'm writing to you again so you know that I am still alive, but I'm writing about something that is troubling.
I have had a terrible battle with the Lamanites, in which we did not win; Archeantus has been killed by the sword, along with Luram and Emron, and we have lost many of our best men.
Now, my son, I'm afraid the Lamanites will destroy this people, because they do not repent, and Satan continually stirs them up to anger against each other.

I am working with them constantly, and when I speak the word of God sharply, they tremble and get angry with me; but when I am not sharp, they harden their hearts against it. I am afraid that the Spirit of the Lord has stopped striving with them.
They are so extremely angry that it seems to me they have no fear of death; they have lost their love for each other, and they constantly crave blood and revenge.

Now, my beloved son, despite their hardness, let's work diligently; because if we stop working, we'll be condemned. We have a work to do while we're in this mortal body, so that we can overcome the enemy of all righteousness and find rest for our souls in the kingdom of God.

Now I'm writing a little about the suffering of these people. According to what I've learned from Amoron, the Lamanites have many prisoners they captured from the tower of Sherrizah, including men, women, and children.

The husbands and fathers of those women and children have been killed; and the women are fed the flesh of their husbands, and the children the flesh of their fathers; and they are given no water, except for a little.

Even though the Lamanites have committed terrible abominations, our people in Moriantum have done even worse. They have captured many of the daughters of the Lamanites, and after taking from them what was most dear and precious—their chastity and virtue—

After they did this, they murdered them in an extremely cruel way, torturing their bodies until they died. Then, they ate their flesh like wild animals because their hearts are so hardened, and they do this as a sign of bravery.
My beloved son, how can a people like this, who are without civilization—
And only a few years have passed, and they were a civilized and delightful people.
But my son, how can a people like this, who take pleasure in so much evil—
How can we expect that God will hold back his judgment against us?
My heart cries out: Woe to this people. Come in judgment, God, and hide their sins, wickedness, and abominations from your sight!

Also, my son, there are many widows and their daughters still in Sherrizah. The army of Zenephi has taken the rest of the provisions that the Lamanites didn't carry away, leaving these women to wander wherever they can for food. Many elderly women collapse along the way and die.
The army with me is weak, and the armies of the Lamanites are between Sherrizah and me. Everyone who has fled to Aaron's army has become a victim of their terrible brutality.
Oh, the wickedness of my people! They have no order and no mercy. I am just a man, and I have only the strength of a man, and I can't enforce my commands any longer.

They have become strong in their perversion, and they are equally brutal, sparing no one, not even the old or the young. They take pleasure in everything except what is good, and the suffering of our women and children throughout this land is greater than anything else. Words cannot describe it, nor can it be written.

Now, my son, I won't focus any longer on this horrible scene. You know the wickedness of these people; you know they have no principles and are past feeling, and their wickedness is even greater than that of the Lamanites.
My son, I cannot recommend them to God, or he might punish me.

My son, I commend you to God, and I trust in Christ that you will be saved. I pray to God that he will spare your life so you can witness either the return of his people to him or their complete destruction, because I know they will be destroyed unless they repent and return to him.
And if they perish, it will be like the Jaredites, because of the stubbornness of their hearts, seeking blood and revenge.

And if they do perish, we know that many of our brothers have deserted to the Lamanites, and many more will also desert to them. So write a few things if you are spared and I die and don't see you. But I hope that I may see you soon, because I have sacred records that I want to give to you.

My son, stay faithful in Christ, and don't let the things I've written trouble you so much that they overwhelm you. Instead, let Christ lift you up, and let his sufferings and death, his appearance to our ancestors, his mercy and patience, and the hope of his glory and eternal life stay in your mind forever.

May the grace of God the Father, whose throne is high in the heavens, and our Lord Jesus Christ, who sits at the right hand of his power until all things become subject to him, be with you and remain with you forever. Amen.
I, Moroni, am writing what I feel is right to my brothers, the Lamanites. I want you to know that more than four hundred and twenty years have passed since the sign was given of Christ's coming.
I seal up these records after I share a few words of encouragement with you.

I encourage you that when you read these things, if it is God's will that you do so, remember how merciful the Lord has been to the children of men from the creation of Adam up to the time you receive these things, and think about it in your hearts.

And when you receive these things, I encourage you to ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true. If you ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will show you the truth of it by the power of the Holy Ghost.
And by the power of the Holy Ghost, you can know the truth of all things.
Anything that is good is just and true; nothing that is good denies Christ, but acknowledges that he is.
